#↩

Preface

前言

The eighth edition is our small contribution to the collective effort to highlight the benefits of careful, rational assessment of reasoning. While we are immensely pleased by the success of this book with decades of readers in many countries and languages, we cannot help but notice the immense disrespect for evidence, sloppy use of language, and substitution of hollering for reason in so much of our public discussion. The mandate to be selective in the arguments we embrace is essential to successful daily living, as well as to the numerous frustrating dilemmas that will surely plague our future together. We have no realistic option to ignore problems when they arise. Ignore them for a while, and they will soon insist on grabbing our attention. So if we must eventually face them, we will need to develop as many critical thinkers as possible to sort and select optimal responses. Asking the Right Questions can be a strong tool for encouraging that development.

第八版是我们对强调审慎、理性评估推理益处这一共同努力的微薄贡献。本书数十年来在许多国家和地区、多种语言的读者中广受欢迎，我们对此深感欣慰。然而，我们也不得不注意到，在当今的公共讨论中，对证据的漠视、语言的草率使用以及以叫嚣代替理性的现象屡见不鲜。对于我们而言，有选择地接受论点至关重要，这不仅关乎日常生活的成功，也关乎我们未来将共同面对的诸多令人沮丧的困境。当问题出现时，我们别无选择，只能视而不见。如果置之不理，它们很快就会迫使我们正视它们。因此，既然我们最终必须面对这些问题，就需要培养尽可能多的批判性思考者，以便筛选和选择最佳应对方案。“提出正确的问题”正是促进这种能力培养的有力工具。

As a book ages, it becomes less and less the product of its original authors. The success of Asking the Right Questions : A Guide to Critical Thinking is a tribute to the sound advice we have received from the many readers who thought we could do better next time around and who told us so. In fact, one of our biggest challenges has been to pick and choose from among the suggestions.

随着书籍出版时间的推移，它越来越不像是最初作者的作品。《提出正确的问题：批判性思维指南》的成功，要归功于众多读者的宝贵建议，他们认为我们下次可以做得更好，并直接告诉我们。事实上，我们面临的最大挑战之一，就是如何从众多建议中挑选出真正有价值的内容。

Always uppermost in our mind has been the desire to retain the primary attributes of Asking the Right Questions , while adjusting to new emphases in our own thought and the evolving needs of our readers. For instance, while we can always think of dozens of additions that would, we believe, enhance new editions of Asking the Right Questions , we want most of all to keep the book readable and short. We are willing to pay the price of omitting several things that would be apposite in a more weighty treatment of critical thinking because those who adopt or learn from Asking the Right Questions have been so assertive in applauding the crispness and cohesion of our approach. Individual readers who do not see their suggestions included will surely understand that writing for a general audience requires us to omit many valuable components that we would certainly include were we writing for a more specialized group of readers.

我们始终将保留《提出正确问题》的核心特质放在首位，同时不断调整以适应我们自身思考的新方向和读者不断变化的需求。例如，我们总能想到许多可以提升《提出正确问题》新版本的内容，但我们最希望的是保持本书的易读性和简洁性。我们愿意为此牺牲一些在更深入探讨批判性思维时可能更为恰当的内容，因为那些采用或学习《提出正确问题》的人都对我们方法的简洁性和连贯性给予了高度评价。个别读者如果发现自己的建议没有被采纳，也完全可以理解，面向大众读者写作意味着我们必须省略许多有价值的内容，而这些内容在面向更专业的读者群体时，我们一定会包含在内。

This new edition, like its predecessors, has been modified while retaining the basic framework of a simplified guide to critical thinking. This latest version has especially benefited from the critical eyes of numerous students who have studied from the book. The special features of this edition include the following:

与之前的版本一样，新版在保留其作为简明批判性思维指南的基本框架的同时，也进行了修订。最新版本尤其受益于众多使用本书学习的学生的审阅和反馈。本版的特色包括：

  1. Rewriting most practice passages and many illustrative examples because the team of students and teachers we consulted preferred the new illustrations. They found them more fresh and relevant to the experience of contemporary students.
    我们重写了大部分练习文章和许多示例，因为我们咨询的学生和教师团队更喜欢新的插图。他们认为新的插图更新颖，也更贴近当代学生的学习体验。
  2. Emphasizing that critical thinking is not primarily an effort to demonstrate what is faulty about the thinking of others. Instead, it is a process for improving the beliefs and decisions each of us must make, and
    强调批判性思维的主要目的并非在于指出他人思维的缺陷，而在于改进我们每个人必须做出的信念和决策的过程。
  3. Expanding the companion Web site containing multiple, diverse practice opportunities in response to the needs of the increasing numbers of students and teachers who wish to have internet access to practice materials.
    为满足越来越多希望通过互联网获取练习材料的学生和教师的需求，我们扩展了配套网站，使其包含多种多样的练习机会。
  4. Highlighting the values of critical thinking to provide a stronger rationale for why critical thinking is essential for a thoughtful life.
    强调批判性思维的价值，为批判性思维对于深思熟虑的生活至关重要这一问题提供更有力的理由。

Critical thinking is initially a process of reaction. Someone has strung together a conclusion and some reasons that allegedly make the case for the conclusion. Our task is to decide whether the argument is one we wish to make our own. So any reasoning provides raw material for critical-thinking practice.

批判性思维最初是一个反应过程。有人将一个结论和一些据称能支持该结论的理由串联起来。我们的任务是决定是否接受这种论证。因此，任何推理都能为批判性思维的练习提供素材。

However, we are all more interested in some arguments than others, for some reasoning seems to have a more significant effect on our lives. So if those learning critical thinking are to be highly engaged in the hours of practice needed to become proficient at critical thinking, we require sample arguments that especially appeal to the primary users of the book. We decided to place greater reliance on student feedback about their interest in particular practice opportunities. The result is substantial improvement in the content and variety of the practice passages.

然而，我们对某些论证的兴趣远高于其他论证，因为某些推理似乎对我们的生活有着更为深远的影响。因此，如果希望学习批判性思维的人能够积极投入到所需的练习中，最终熟练掌握批判性思维，我们就需要一些能够特别吸引本书主要读者的论证范例。我们决定更加重视学生对特定练习机会的反馈。最终，练习文章的内容和种类都得到了显著提升。

The seventh edition stressed the importance of social skills that would encourage the use of critical thinking. We have kept this emphasis in the new edition, and we are supplementing it with persistent encouragement to frame critical thinking in a particular way. We learned this from our colleagues in Japan who found that Japanese students were not eager to criticize deficiencies in the reasoning of others. But once those same students viewed critical thinking as an avenue toward improved development of their own thinking, they fastened on critical thinking as a skill and habit. Our students are also reluctant to criticize reasoning because of the social effects of their criticisms. Their reluctance often disappears, however, when they begin to sense the positive effect of such criticisms on their own conscious reflection.

第七版强调了培养批判性思维所需的社交技能的重要性。新版延续了这一重点，并进一步鼓励学生以特定的方式构建批判性思维。我们从日本的同行那里汲取了这一经验。他们发现，日本学生并不热衷于批评他人推理中的不足。但一旦这些学生将批判性思维视为提升自身思维能力的途径，他们便会将其发展成为一项技能和习惯。我们的学生也同样不愿批评他人的推理，因为他们担心批评会带来社交影响。然而，当他们开始感受到此类批评对自身反思的积极作用时，这种顾虑往往会消失。

We worked especially hard for this edition to improve the Web site. It is organized by chapter and contains practice passages of varying size and complexity. In addition, learners also need to see arguments that are relatively strong. We want to highlight what is particularly strong about these arguments, to provide readers a model of what is possible when someone tries to reason well. We are attempting to include even more practice passages with feedback on the student Web site, as well as short self-graded objective quizzes for each chapter, and an expanded "Authors Answer Typical Student Questions" section. The Teachers' Web site will also be greatly expanded with more suggestions for student assignments and examples of high-quality student papers with comments explaining the basis for making that determination.

为了改进本版网站，我们投入了大量精力。网站按章节组织，包含不同长度和难度的练习文章。此外，学习者也需要看到一些论证较为有力的例子。我们希望突出这些论证的优势所在，为读者提供一个范例，展示如何才能进行有效的推理。我们正努力在学生网站上添加更多带有反馈的练习文章，以及每章的简短自测题，并扩充“作者解答学生常见问题”部分。教师网站也将大幅扩充，提供更多学生作业建议和高质量学生论文范例，并附上评语，解释评语的依据。

In the spirit of emphasizing the role of values in guiding careful thinking, this new edition takes every opportunity to highlight the values that unite those of us who hope to think critically. Were we not especially loyal to autonomy, reasonableness, curiosity, and commitment, we would not be as willing to do the hard work associated with critical thinking. This new edition focuses on making these assumptions transparent for learners.

为了强调价值观在引导深入思考中的作用，新版教材着重阐述了那些将我们这些渴望进行批判性思考的人们联系在一起的价值观。如果我们不特别忠于自主性、理性、好奇心和责任感，我们就不会如此乐于付出批判性思考所需的努力。新版教材旨在让学习者清晰地理解这些基本假设。

The success of previous editions of this book is potent testimony to our collective curiosity about what to believe. Our minds are under assault by experts and scam artists alike. Sorting among all their claims about what to eat, do, and believe is an incredibly difficult responsibility. We know that we need all the help we can get to protect ourselves from the dangers implicit in nonsense. We want to think carefully before we make a belief our own.

本书前几版的成功有力地证明了我们对信仰的好奇心。我们的思想正遭受着专家和骗子的双重冲击。在他们铺天盖地的关于饮食、行为和信仰的说法中甄别真伪，是一项极其艰巨的任务。我们深知，我们需要一切可能的帮助来保护自己，免受谬论中潜藏的危险。我们希望在接受某种信仰之前，能够深思熟虑。

From the start of this book's history, we have been motivated by a variety of personal experiences and observations. First, we have been dismayed by the degree to which students and citizens in general increasingly depend on "experts," textbook writers, teachers, lawyers, politicians, journalists, and TV commentators. As the complexity of the world seems to increase at an accelerating rate, there is a greater tendency to become passive absorbers of information, uncritically accepting what is seen and heard. We are concerned that too many of us are not actively making personal choices about what to accept and what to reject.

从本书构思之初，我们就受到各种个人经历和观察的启发。首先，我们感到沮丧的是，学生和普通民众越来越依赖“专家”，包括教科书作者、教师、律师、政治家、记者和电视评论员。随着世界复杂性似乎以惊人的速度增长，人们越来越倾向于被动地接受信息，不加批判地接受所见所闻。我们担心，太多的人没有积极主动地做出选择，决定接受什么、拒绝什么。

At the same time, each of us has little choice but to rely on experts on a regular basis. Life is far too complex for us to pretend that we can take care of all our decisions by simply relying on our own resources. So, if we must depend on experts, how do we select from among the crowd of experts -- each telling us he or she knows best? Critical thinking can help answer that question. It provides a set of filters that expert opinion needs to get through before you rely on it. In other words, all expert advice is not equally valuable. Critical thinking enables us to be more sensibly selective among experts.

与此同时，我们每个人几乎都不得不经常依赖专家。生活太过复杂，我们无法指望仅凭自身资源就能做出所有决定。那么，既然我们必须依赖专家，又该如何从众多自称最懂的专家中做出选择呢？批判性思维可以帮助我们解答这个问题。它提供了一套筛选机制，专家意见必须经过这套机制的检验才能被采纳。换句话说，并非所有专家的建议都具有相同的价值。批判性思维使我们能够更理性地选择专家。

Our experience in teaching critical-thinking skills to our students over a number of years has convinced us that when individuals with diverse abilities are taught these skills in a simplified format, they can learn to apply them successfully. In the process, they develop greater confidence in their ability to make rational choices about social issues, even those with which they have formerly had little experience.

多年来，我们在教授学生批判性思维技能方面的经验使我们确信，当不同能力水平的学生以简化的方式学习这些技能时，他们都能学会并成功运用这些技能。在这个过程中，他们会对自己就社会问题做出理性选择的能力更有信心，即使是那些他们以前很少接触的问题。

Thus, we have written a text that does a number of things that other books have failed to do. This text develops an integrated series of question-asking skills that can be applied widely. These skills are discussed in an informal style. (We have written to a general audience, not to any specialized group.)

因此，我们编写了一本能够做到其他书籍未能做到的教材。本书培养了一系列综合性的提问技巧，这些技巧可以广泛应用。本书以非正式的风格探讨了这些技巧。（我们的目标读者是普通大众，而非任何特定群体。）

The development of Asking the Right Questions has leaned heavily on our joint experience of 65 years as teachers of critical thinking. Our ideas have evolved in response to numerous classroom experiences with students at many different levels, from freshman to Ph.D. students.

《提出正确问题》一书的编写很大程度上借鉴了我们65年来作为批判性思维教师的共同经验。我们的理念是在与不同层次的学生（从大一新生到博士生）进行大量课堂教学实践后不断发展完善的。

These experiences have taught us certain emphases that are particularly effective in learning critical thinking. For instance, we provide many opportunities for the readers to apply their skills and to receive immediate feedback following the practice application. The book is replete with examples of writing devoted to controversial contemporary topics. The breadth of topics introduces the average reader to numerous controversies with which he may have little familiarity. The book is coherently organized, in that critical questions are discussed sequentially as the reader progresses from understanding to evaluating.

这些经验让我们认识到，某些方法对于培养批判性思维尤为有效。例如，我们为读者提供了许多运用技能的机会，并在实践应用后立即获得反馈。本书包含大量探讨当代争议性话题的文章范例。这些话题的广泛性使普通读者能够接触到许多他们可能不太熟悉的争议性议题。本书结构严谨，关键问题按顺序展开，引导读者从理解逐步过渡到评估。

One feature that deserves to be highlighted is the applicability of Asking the Right Questions to numerous life experiences extending far beyond the classroom. The habits and attitudes associated with critical thinking are transferable to consumer, medical, legal, and general ethical choices. When our surgeon says surgery is needed, it can be life sustaining to seek answers to the critical questions encouraged in Asking the Right Questions .

值得一提的是，《提出正确的问题》一书的适用范围远超课堂，涵盖了众多生活情境。批判性思维所培养的习惯和态度可以应用于消费、医疗、法律以及一般的伦理抉择。当外科医生建议手术时，寻求《提出正确的问题》一书中提出的关键问题的答案，可能关乎生死。

Who would find Asking the Right Questions especially beneficial? Because of our teaching experiences with readers representing many different levels of ability, we have difficulty envisioning any academic course or program for which this book would not be useful. In fact, the first seven editions have been used in law, English, pharmacy, philosophy, education, psychology, sociology, religion, and social science courses, as well as in numerous high-school classrooms.

哪些人会觉得《提出正确的问题》特别有益？由于我们拥有丰富的教学经验，读者涵盖了各种不同的能力水平，因此我们很难想象有什么学术课程或项目会不适合使用本书。事实上，前七版已被用于法律、英语、药学、哲学、教育、心理学、社会学、宗教和社会科学等课程，以及众多高中课堂。

A few uses for the book seem especially appropriate. Teachers in general education programs may want to begin their courses by assigning it as a coherent response to their students' requests to explain what is expected of them. English courses that emphasize expository writing could use this text both as a format for evaluating arguments prior to constructing an essay and as a checklist of problems that the writer should attempt to avoid as she writes. The book is especially functional in courses for training prospective teachers and graduate assistants because it makes explicit much that teachers will want to encourage in their students. Especially important, it encourages an orderly approach to evaluative thinking. While critical thinking need not be formulaic in any fashion, learning something as cognitively demanding as critical thinking is facilitated by an integrated approach. Supplementing their current content with our step-by-step description of the process of critical reading and thinking may enrich courses in study-skill development. The text can also be used as the central focus of courses designed specifically to teach critical reading and thinking skills.

本书的某些用途似乎尤为恰当。通识教育课程的教师可以将其作为课程的引言，以此回应学生提出的“课程目标”的疑问。注重说明文写作的英语课程可以将本书用作论文写作前评估论证的范式，以及写作过程中应避免的问题清单。本书对于未来教师和研究生助教的培训课程尤其有用，因为它明确阐述了许多教师希望在学生身上培养的品质。尤其重要的是，它鼓励学生采用系统的方法进行评估性思考。虽然批判性思维并非必须遵循某种固定的模式，但学习批判性思维这种认知要求较高的技能，采用综合方法会更加有效。将本书中对批判性阅读和思考过程的循序渐进的描述融入现有课程，可以丰富学习技能培养课程的内容。此外，本书还可以作为专门教授批判性阅读和思考技能的课程的核心教材。

While Asking the Bight Questions stems primarily from our classroom experiences, it is written so that it can guide the reading and listening habits of almost everyone. The skills that it seeks to develop are those that any critical reader needs to serve as a basis for rational decisions. The critical questions stressed in the book can enhance anyone's reasoning, regardless of the extent of his or her formal education.

《提出关键问题》一书虽然主要源于我们的课堂经验，但其写作目的在于指导几乎所有人的阅读和聆听习惯。本书旨在培养的技能是任何批判性读者进行理性决策所必需的。书中强调的关键问题能够提升任何人的推理能力，无论其受教育程度如何。

This eighth edition owes special debts to many people. We wish to acknowledge the valuable advice of the following Prentice Hall reviewers: Patricia Allen, MassBay Community College; Dr. Alan Baragona, Virginia Military Institute; Lisa Barnes, Delware Country Community College; Thomas J. Martin, University of North Carolina; Charlotte P. Brian, McNeece Imperial Valley College; Michael A. Schwartz, University of Florida; Brian Allan, Wooters Metropolitan Community College; Thomas Young, Mansfield University.

第八版的编写离不开许多人的帮助。我们谨此感谢以下 Prentice Hall 审稿人提出的宝贵建议：Patricia Allen，马萨诸塞湾社区学院；Alan Baragona 博士，弗吉尼亚军事学院；Lisa Barnes，特拉华县社区学院；Thomas J. Martin，北卡罗来纳大学；Charlotte P. Brian，麦克尼斯帝国谷学院；Michael A. Schwartz，佛罗里达大学；Brian Allan，伍特斯都市社区学院；Thomas Young，曼斯菲尔德大学。

While our students are always a major source of suggested improvements, a few distinguished themselves in that regard. The seventh edition benefited from the valuable assistance of Dan Tagliarina, Heather Tewksbury, and Steve Weigand.

虽然学生们一直是提出改进建议的重要来源，但有几位学生在这方面表现尤为突出。第七版的编写得益于 Dan Tagliarina、Heather Tewksbury 和 Steve Weigand 的宝贵帮助。

M. Neil Browne

M. 尼尔·布朗

Stuart M. Keeley

斯图尔特·M·基利

#↩

CHAPTER 1 THE BENEFIT OF ASKING THE RIGHT QUESTIONS

第一章 提出正确问题的好处

Introduction

介绍

Any of us who enjoy movies are curious about the content of the latest films. Should we go see them now, wait for them to show up at our preferred rental location, or avoid them altogether? Lots of film experts are available to advise us. But which of their opinions should we follow? Opinions are cheap; anyone can have one of those. But which film expert possesses the kind of knowledge that gives us an opinion on which we can rely?

任何喜欢电影的人都会对最新影片的内容感到好奇。我们应该现在就去看，还是等到它们出现在我们常去的租赁店里，或者干脆避而远之？有很多电影专家可以给我们提供建议。但我们应该听取谁的意见呢？意见很廉价，任何人都可以发表意见。但哪位电影专家拥有足够的专业知识，能够提供值得信赖的意见呢？

The authors of this book are film fanatics, but we both want to be selective in what we see. While we are fascinated by film as a medium, there are many films that we do not wish to see. Deciding which those are is hard work. To make the task easier, we often use one of our favorite web sites, http://www.rottentomatoes.com.

本书作者都是电影爱好者，但我们都希望在观看电影时有所选择。虽然我们对电影这种媒介非常着迷，但也有很多电影我们并不想看。决定哪些电影不适合观看是一项艰巨的任务。为了简化这项任务，我们经常使用我们最喜欢的网站之一：http://www.rottentomatoes.com。

However, one of the most obvious things one learns when reading dozens of reviews of a particular film is the certainty that human judgment will not be identical. Pick any movie you wish; check the reviews. Regardless of how many reviewers hated the movie, some reviewer somewhere will string together a positive review. Similarly, pick the most popular movie in history; go to the reviews. What do you find? Some expert thought it was a dog.

然而，阅读几十篇关于某部电影的影评后，最显而易见的一点就是：人类的判断绝不可能完全一致。随便挑一部电影，看看影评。无论有多少影评人讨厌这部电影，总会有人给出好评。同样地，挑一部史上最受欢迎的电影，看看影评。你会发现什么？某个专家竟然认为它是一部烂片。

This experience is a metaphor for much of life. Doctors, legislators, architects, plumbers, and detectives all disagree among themselves about the proper course of action in particular circumstances. How are we consumers of opinions to respond? The book you are about to read contains the best answer we know. You need to build skills and attitudes that will enable you to decide for yourself which opinions to make your own.

这种经历可以看作是人生诸多方面的隐喻。医生、立法者、建筑师、水管工和侦探，在特定情况下，对于正确的应对措施都会意见不一。作为意见的消费者，我们该如何应对？你即将读到的这本书包含了我们所知的最佳答案。你需要培养一些技能和态度，使你能够独立判断哪些观点值得采纳。

As a thoughtful person you must make a choice about how you will react to what you see and hear. One alternative is to just accept whatever you encounter; doing so automatically results in your making someone else's opinion your own. A more active alternative consists of asking questions in an effort to reach a personal decision about the worth of what you have experienced. This book is written for those who prefer the second alternative.

作为一个有思想的人，你必须选择如何回应你所见所闻。一种选择是全盘接受你所遇到的一切；这样做无异于将他人的观点据为己有。另一种更积极主动的选择是提出问题，努力对你所经历之事的价值做出个人判断。本书正是为那些倾向于第二种选择的人而作。

Critical Thinking to the Rescue

批判性思维来帮忙

Listening and reading critically -- that is, reacting with systematic evaluation to what you have heard and read -- requires a set of skills and attitudes. These skills and attitudes are built around a series of related critical questions. While we will learn them one by one, our goal is to be able to use them together to identify the best decision available.

批判性地聆听和阅读——即对所听所读的内容进行系统性的评估——需要一系列技能和态度。这些技能和态度围绕着一系列相关的批判性问题展开。虽然我们会逐一学习这些问题，但我们的目标是能够将它们结合起来，从而做出最佳决策。

We could have expressed them as a list of things you should do, but a system of questions is more consistent with the spirit of curiosity, wonder, and intellectual adventure essential to critical thinking. Thinking carefully is always an unfinished project, a story looking for an ending that will never arrive. Critical questions provide a stimulus and direction for critical thinking; they move us forward toward a continual, ongoing search for better opinions, decisions, or judgments.

我们本可以列出一系列你应该做的事情，但提问的方式更符合批判性思维所必需的好奇心、求知欲和探索精神。认真思考永远是一个未完成的项目，一个永远没有结局的故事。批判性问题为批判性思维提供刺激和方向；它们推动我们不断追求更佳的观点、决策或判断。

Consequently, critical thinking , as we will use the term, refers to the following:

因此，我们所用的“批判性思维”一词指的是以下内容：

  1. awareness of a set of interrelated critical questions;
    对一系列相互关联的关键问题的认识；
  2. ability to ask and answer critical questions at appropriate times; and the
    能够在适当的时候提出和回答关键问题；以及
  3. desire to actively use the critical questions.
    渴望积极运用批判性问题。

The goal of this book is to encourage you in all three of these dimensions.

本书旨在从这三个方面鼓励你。

Questions require the person being asked the question to act in response. By our questions, we are saying to the person: I am curious; I want to know more; help me. This request shows respect for the other person. The questions exist to inform and provide direction for all who hear them. In that respect, critical thinking begins with the desire to improve what we think. The point of your questions is that you need help to have a deeper understanding or appreciation of what is being said.

提问需要被提问者做出回应。我们通过提问向对方表达的是：我很好奇；我想了解更多；请帮帮我。这种请求体现了对对方的尊重。提问的目的是为了给所有听众提供信息和方向。从这个意义上讲，批判性思维始于我们渴望改进自身思维方式的愿望。你提问的目的是为了寻求帮助，以便更深入地理解或欣赏对方所说的话。

The critical questions will be shared with you one question at a time. As a package, they will be useful whenever you choose to react to what you are hearing or reading. They are also useful in improving your own writing and speaking because they will assist you when you:

我们会逐一向您介绍这些关键问题。这些问题作为一个整体，在您决定对所听所读的内容做出反应时都将非常有用。它们还有助于提升您的写作和口语能力，因为它们会在以下方面为您提供帮助：

  1. react critically to an essay or to evidence presented in a textbook, a periodical, or on a Web site;
    对文章或教科书、期刊或网站上提出的证据做出批判性反应；
  2. judge the quality of a lecture or speech;
    评价讲座或演讲的质量；
  3. form an argument;
    形成论点；
  4. write an essay based on a reading assignment; or
    根据阅读材料写一篇论文；或者
  5. participate in class.
    积极参与课堂讨论。
Attention : Critical thinking consists of an awareness of a set of interrelated critical questions, plus the ability and willingness to ask and answer them at appropriate times.
注意：批判性思维包括对一系列相互关联的批判性问题的认识，以及在适当的时候提出和回答这些问题的能力和意愿。

As a citizen and consumer, you should find them especially helpful in shaping your voting behavior and your purchasing decisions, as well as in improving your self-confidence by increasing your sense of intellectual independence.

作为公民和消费者，您应该会发现它们对塑造您的投票行为和购买决策特别有帮助，并且可以通过增强您的独立思考能力来提高您的自信心。

The Sponge and Panning for Gold: Alternative Thinking Styles

海绵和淘金：另类思维方式

One approach to thinking is similar to the way in which a sponge reacts to water: by absorbing. This commonly used approach has some clear advantages.

一种思考方式类似于海绵吸收水分的方式。这种常用的方法有一些明显的优势。

First, the more information you absorb about the world, the more capable you are of understanding its complexities. Knowledge you have acquired provides a foundation for more complicated thinking later.

首先，你吸收的世界信息越多，就越能理解世界的复杂性。你所获得的知识为日后更复杂的思考奠定了基础。

A second advantage of the sponge approach is that it is relatively passive. Rather than requiring strenuous mental effort, it tends to be rather quick and easy, especially when the material is presented in a clear and interesting fashion. The primary mental effort involves concentration and memory.

海绵式学习法的第二个优点是它相对被动。这种方法不需要耗费大量的脑力，往往快速简便，尤其是在学习材料以清晰有趣的方式呈现时。主要的脑力消耗在于集中注意力和记忆。

While absorbing information provides a productive start toward becoming a thoughtful person, the sponge approach has a serious disadvantage: It provides no method for deciding which information and opinions to believe and which to reject. If a reader relied on the sponge approach all the time, he would believe whatever he read last. The idea of being the mental puppet of whomever one happens to encounter is horrible imagery for a person and a community. Decisions become accidents of association, instead of reflective judgments.

虽然吸收信息是培养独立思考能力的一个有效开端，但“海绵式”信息吸收法存在一个严重的缺陷：它无法帮助人们判断哪些信息和观点值得相信，哪些应该摒弃。如果读者始终依赖这种吸收方式，他就会相信最后读到的内容。成为他人思想的傀儡，无论对方是谁，对个人还是对整个群体而言，都是极其可怕的。决策将沦为偶然联想的结果，而非深思熟虑的判断。

We think you would rather choose for yourself what to absorb and what to ignore. To make this choice, you must read with a special attitude -- a question-asking attitude. Such a thinking style requires active participation. The writer is trying to speak to you, and you should try to talk back to him, even though he is not present.

我们认为您应该自己选择吸收什么，忽略什么。为了做出这种选择，您必须以一种特殊的态度——提问的态度——去阅读。这种思考方式需要积极参与。作者试图与您对话，即使他不在场，您也应该尝试与他交流。

We call this interactive approach the panning-for-gold style of thinking. The process of panning for gold provides a model for active readers and listeners as they try to determine the worth of what they read and hear. The task is challenging and sometimes tedious, but the reward can be tremendous. To distinguish the gold from the gravel in a conversation requires you to ask frequent questions and to reflect on the answers.

我们将这种互动式方法称为淘金思维。淘金的过程为积极的读者和听众提供了一个模型，帮助他们判断所读所听内容的价值。这项任务充满挑战，有时甚至枯燥乏味，但回报却可能非常丰厚。要想在对话中分辨出精华和糟粕，你需要不断提问并认真思考答案。

The sponge approach emphasizes knowledge acquisition; the panning-for-gold approach stresses active interaction with knowledge as it is being acquired. Thus, the two approaches complement each other. To pan for intellectual gold, there must be something in your pan to evaluate. In addition, to evaluate arguments, we must possess knowledge, dependable opinions.

海绵式学习法强调知识的获取；淘金式学习法强调在获取知识的过程中积极互动。因此，这两种方法相辅相成。要想淘到知识的金子，你的“淘金盘”里必须有东西可供评估。此外，要想评估论点，我们必须拥有知识和可靠的观点。

Let us examine more closely how the two approaches lead to different behavior. What does the individual who takes the sponge approach do when he reads material? He reads sentences carefully, trying to remember as much as he can. He may underline or highlight key words and sentences. He may take notes summarizing the major topics and major points. He checks his underlining or notes to be sure that he is not forgetting anything important. His mission is to find and understand what the author has to say. He memorizes the reasoning, but doesn't evaluate it.

让我们更仔细地考察一下这两种方法如何导致不同的行为。采用海绵式阅读法的人在阅读材料时会做什么呢？他会仔细阅读句子，尽可能多地记住内容。他可能会划线或高亮关键词和句子。他可能会做笔记，总结主要主题和要点。他会检查划线或笔记，确保没有遗漏任何重要信息。他的目标是找到并理解作者想要表达的意思。他记住了作者的论证思路，但并不对其进行评估。

What does the reader who takes the panning-for-gold approach do? Like the person using the sponge approach, he approaches his reading with the hope that he will acquire new knowledge. There the similarity ends. The panning-for-gold approach requires that the reader asks himself a number of questions designed to uncover the best available decisions or beliefs.

采取淘金式阅读方法的读者会怎么做呢？和采用海绵式阅读方法的人一样，他们也希望通过阅读获得新知识。但相似之处仅限于此。淘金式阅读方法要求读者提出一系列问题，旨在找出最佳的决策或信念。

Exhibit 1.1 MENTAL CHECK: Am I Panning for Gold?

图表 1.1 心理检查：我是在淘金吗？

Did I ask "why" someone wants me to believe something?

我问过别人为什么想让我相信某些事情吗？

Did I take notes as I thought about potential problems with what was being said?

我在思考发言中可能存在的问题时，有没有做笔记？

Did I evaluate what was being said?

我是否对所说的话进行了评估？

Did I form my own conclusion about the topic?

我是否对这个问题形成了自己的结论？

The reader who uses the panning-for-gold approach frequently questions why the author makes various claims. He writes notes to himself in the margins indicating problems with the reasoning. He continually interacts with the material. His intent is to critically evaluate the material and formulate personal conclusions based on the evaluation.

采用淘金式阅读方法的读者经常质疑作者提出的各种论点。他会在书页空白处写下笔记，指出论证中存在的问题。他不断地与材料互动。他的目的是批判性地评估材料，并在此基础上形成自己的结论。

An Example of the Panning-for-Gold Approach

淘金方法示例

A major enduring issue in American society concerns what kind of gun control laws we need. Let's look at one position on this issue. Try to decide whether the argument is convincing.

美国社会长期存在的一个重大问题是，我们需要什么样的枪支管制法律。让我们来看一种关于这个问题的观点。试着判断一下这个论点是否令人信服。

Arguments for banning guns are mostly myths, and what we need now is not more laws, but more law enforcement. One myth is that most murderers are ordinary, law-abiding citizens who kill a relative or acquaintance in a moment of anger only because a gun is available. In fact, every study of homicide shows the overwhelming majority of murderers are career criminals, people with lifelong histories of violence. The typical murderer has a prior criminal history averaging at least six years, with four major felony arrests.
支持禁枪的论点大多是谬论，我们现在需要的不是更多的法律，而是更严格的执法。其中一个谬论是，大多数杀人犯都是普通的守法公民，他们只是因为手边有枪，才在盛怒之下杀害了亲友。事实上，每一项关于凶杀案的研究都表明，绝大多数杀人犯都是职业罪犯，他们有着长期的暴力犯罪史。典型的杀人犯平均至少有六年的犯罪前科，并曾因四项重罪被捕。
Another myth is that gun owners are ignorant rednecks given to senseless violence. However, studies consistently show that, on the average, gun owners are better educated and have more prestigious jobs than non-owners. To judge by their applications for permits to carry guns at all times, the following are (or were) gun owners: Eleanor Roosevelt, Joan Rivers, Donald Trump, and David Rockefeller.
另一个误解是，枪支拥有者都是些无知、粗鲁、动辄诉诸暴力的乡巴佬。然而，研究始终表明，平均而言，枪支拥有者比非枪支拥有者受教育程度更高，拥有更体面的工作。从他们申请随时携带枪支许可证的情况来看，以下人士（或曾经是）都是枪支拥有者：埃莉诺·罗斯福、琼·里弗斯、唐纳德·特朗普和大卫·洛克菲勒。
A further myth is that guns are not useful for self-defense. On the contrary! Every study has shown that handguns are used more often in repelling crimes than in committing them. While handguns are used in about 581,000 crimes yearly, they are used to repel about 645,000 crimes.
另一个误区是认为枪支对自卫没有用处。恰恰相反！所有研究都表明，手枪用于阻止犯罪的次数远多于用于实施犯罪的次数。虽然每年约有58.1万起犯罪案件中使用了手枪，但手枪却被用于阻止约64.5万起犯罪案件。
Even if gun laws do potentially reduce gun-related crime, the present laws are all that are needed if they are enforced. What good would stronger laws do when the courts have demonstrated that they will not enforce them?
即使枪支管制法确实有可能减少涉枪犯罪，但如果现行法律得到有效执行，也已经足够了。既然法院已经表明不会执行这些法律，那么更严格的法律又有什么用呢？

If you apply the sponge approach to the passage, you probably will try to remember the reasons that we don't need further controls on guns. If so, you will have absorbed some knowledge. However, how convinced should you be by the above reasons? You can't evaluate them until you have applied the panning-for-gold approach to the passage -- that is, until you have asked the right questions.

如果你用海绵吸纳的方式来阅读这篇文章，你可能会试图记住我们不需要进一步管制枪支的理由。如果是这样，你确实吸收了一些知识。然而，你对这些理由的信服程度究竟如何呢？在你用淘金的方式阅读这篇文章之前——也就是说，在你提出正确的问题之前——你无法评估这些理由。

By asking the right questions, you would discover a number of possible weaknesses in the communicator's arguments. For instance, you might be concerned about all of the following:

通过提出正确的问题，你会发现沟通者论点中可能存在的诸多漏洞。例如，你可能会关注以下所有方面：

  1. What does the author mean by "overwhelming majority" or by "typical murderer"? Is the minority still a substantial number of murderers who kill relatives in a moment of anger?
    作者所说的“绝大多数”或“典型杀人犯”是什么意思？少数在盛怒之下杀害亲属的杀人犯是否仍然数量可观？
  2. What does "gun owners" mean? Are they the ones who buy the kind of guns that gun control advocates are trying to ban?
    “枪支拥有者”指的是什么？他们是指那些购买枪支管制倡导者试图禁止的那种枪支的人吗？
  3. How adequate were the cited research studies? Were the samples sufficiently large, random, and diverse?
    所引用的研究是否充分？样本是否足够大、随机且多样化？
  4. Has the author lied with statistics by impressing us with large, rather precise numbers, like 581,000 and 645,000? What is the basis for these numbers? Can we rely on them?
    作者是否为了博取眼球而使用统计数据造假，比如列举581,000和645,000这样庞大而精确的数字？这些数字的依据是什么？它们可信吗？
  5. What possible benefits of gun control are not mentioned? Have important studies that disagree with the author's position been omitted?
    文中未提及枪支管制可能带来的哪些好处？是否遗漏了与作者观点相左的重要研究？
  6. Is it legitimate to assume that because some famous people own guns, then owning guns is desirable? Do these people have special expertise concerning the pros and cons of gun ownership?
    仅仅因为一些名人拥有枪支，就断定拥有枪支是可取的，这种假设合理吗？这些人是否对拥有枪支的利弊有特殊的见解？
  7. How many people are killed each year by handguns who would not have been killed were such guns not available?
    每年有多少人死于手枪，如果没有手枪，他们就不会丧命？
  8. Why did the person writing the essay fail to explain how we could encourage better enforcement of existing gun control laws to demonstrate his sensitivity to the harm that guns sometimes facilitate?
    为什么写这篇文章的人没有解释如何才能更好地执行现有的枪支管制法律，以表明他对枪支有时造成的危害的敏感性？

If you would enjoy asking these kinds of questions, this book is especially for you. Its primary purpose is to help you know when and how to ask questions that will enable you to decide what to believe.

如果你喜欢问这类问题，那么这本书特别适合你。它的主要目的是帮助你了解何时以及如何提出问题，从而帮助你决定相信什么。

The most important characteristic of the panning-for-gold approach is interactive involvement -- a dialogue between the writer and the reader, or the speaker and the listener.

淘金式写作方法最重要的特点是互动参与——作者与读者之间，或者说话者与听众之间的对话。

Clearly, there are times when the sponge approach is appropriate. Most of you have used it regularly and have acquired some level of success with it. It is much less likely that you are in the habit of employing the panning-for-gold approach -- in part, simply because you have not had the appropriate training and practice. This book will not only help you ask the right questions, but will also provide frequent opportunities for practicing their use.

显然，有些时候海绵法是适用的。你们大多数人都经常使用这种方法，并且取得了一定的成功。但你们不太可能习惯于使用淘金法——部分原因在于你们没有接受过相应的培训和练习。本书不仅会帮助你们提出正确的问题，还会提供大量的练习机会，让你们有机会运用这些问题。

Panning for Gold: Asking Critical Questions

淘金：提出关键问题

It would be relaxing if what other people were really saying were always obvious, if all their essential thoughts were clearly labeled for us, if the writer or speaker never made an error in her reasoning, and if all knowledgeable people agreed about answers to important questions. If this were the case, we could read and listen passively and let others do our thinking for us.

如果别人真正想表达的意思总是显而易见，如果他们所有的核心思想都被清晰地标示出来，如果作者或演讲者的推理从不出错，如果所有有学识的人对重要问题的答案都达成一致，那该有多轻松啊。如果真是这样，我们就可以被动地阅读和聆听，让别人替我们思考。

However, the true state of affairs is quite the opposite. A person's reasoning is often not obvious. Important elements are often missing. Many of the elements that are present are unclear. Consequently, you need critical reading and listening skills to help you determine what makes sense and distinguish this clear thinking from the sloppy thinking that characterizes much of what you will encounter.

然而，实际情况恰恰相反。一个人的推理过程往往并不清晰，常常缺少重要的要素，即使存在，很多要素也含糊不清。因此，你需要具备批判性阅读和倾听能力，才能判断哪些说法合情合理，并将清晰的思路与你将遇到的大量草率思维区分开来。

The inadequacies in what someone says will not always leap out at you. You must be an active reader and listener. You can do this by asking questions. The best search strategy is a critical-questioning strategy. A powerful advantage of these questions is that they permit you to ask searching questions even when you know very little about the topic being discussed. For example, you do not need to be an expert on childcare to ask critical questions about the adequacy of day-care centers.

别人话语中的不足之处并非总能立刻显现。你必须积极阅读和倾听。你可以通过提问来实现这一点。最佳的搜索策略是批判性提问策略。这类问题的强大优势在于，即使你对所讨论的主题知之甚少，也能提出深入的问题。例如，你无需成为儿童保育专家，也能就日托中心的合格性提出关键性问题。

The Myth of the "Right Answer"

“正确答案”的神话

Our ability to find definite answers to questions often depends on the type of question that puzzles us. Scientific questions about the physical world are the most likely to have answers that reasonable people will accept, because the physical world is in certain ways more dependable or predictable than the social world. While the precise distance to the moon or the age of a newly discovered bone from an ancient civilization may not be absolutely certain, agreement about the dimensions of our physical environment is widespread. Thus, in the physical sciences, we frequently can arrive at "the right answer."

我们能否找到问题的确切答案，往往取决于困扰我们的问题的类型。关于物理世界的科学问题最有可能找到理性之人都能接受的答案，因为物理世界在某些方面比社会世界更可靠或更可预测。虽然月球的精确距离或新发现的古代文明骨骼的年龄可能并非绝对确定，但我们对物理环境的尺度却普遍认同。因此，在物理科学领域，我们常常能够得出“正确答案”。

Questions about human behavior are different. The causes of human behavior are so complex that we frequently cannot do much more than form intelligent guesses about why or when certain behavior will occur. In addition, because many of us care a great deal about explanations and descriptions of human behavior, we prefer that explanations or descriptions of the rate of abortion, the frequency of unemployment, or the causes of child abuse be consistent with what we want to believe. Hence, we bring our preferences to any discussion of those issues and resist arguments that are inconsistent with them.

关于人类行为的问题则有所不同。人类行为的成因极其复杂，我们往往只能对某些行为发生的原因或时间做出合理的推测。此外，由于我们许多人非常重视对人类行为的解释和描述，我们更倾向于对堕胎率、失业率或虐待儿童原因的解释或描述与我们自身的认知相符。因此，我们会将自身的偏好带入到对这些问题的讨论中，并抵制与之相悖的论点。

Because human behavior is so controversial and complex, the best answers that we can find for many questions about our behavior will be probabilistic in nature. Even if we were aware of every bit of evidence about the effects of exercise on our mental health, we could still not expect certainty about those effects. We still need to commit to a particular course of action to prevent our becoming a "hollow man" or a "nowhere woman." But once we acknowledge that our commitments are based on probability and not certainty, we will be much more open to the reasoning of those who are trying to persuade us to change our minds. After all, we may well be wrong about some of our beliefs.

由于人类行为充满争议且错综复杂，对于许多关于自身行为的问题，我们所能找到的最佳答案本质上都是概率性的。即便我们掌握了所有关于运动对心理健康影响的证据，我们仍然无法确定这些影响是否真的存在。我们仍然需要采取特定的行动，以避免自己变成“空心人”或“一事无成的女人”。但是，一旦我们意识到我们的承诺是基于概率而非确定性，我们就会更容易接受那些试图说服我们改变想法的人的论证。毕竟，我们很可能在某些信念上是错误的。

Regardless of the type of questions being asked, the issues that require your closest scrutiny are usually those about which "reasonable people" disagree. In fact, many issues are interesting exactly because there is strong disagreement about how to resolve them. Any controversy involves more than one position. Several positions may be supported with good reasons. There will seldom be a position on a social controversy about which you will be able to say, "This is clearly the right position on the issue." If such certainty were possible, reasonable people would not be debating the issue. Our focus in this book will be on such social controversies.

无论提出何种问题，真正需要你仔细审视的，通常是那些“理性之人”意见相左的问题。事实上，许多问题之所以引人入胜，恰恰是因为人们对如何解决这些问题存在着激烈的争论。任何争议都涉及不止一种立场。多种立场可能都有其充分的理由支持。在社会争议中，你几乎不可能找到一个立场，让你能够断言“这显然是正确的”。如果真有如此确定性，理性之人就不会就此展开辩论了。本书的重点正是这类社会争议。

Even though you will not necessarily arrive at the "right answer" to social controversies, this book is designed to give you the skills to develop your best and most reasonable answer, given the nature of the problem and the available information. Decisions usually must be made in the face of uncertainty. Often we will not have the time or the ability to discover many of the important facts about a decision we must make. For example, it is simply unwise to ask all the right questions when someone you love is complaining of sharp chest pains and wants you to transport him to the emergency room.

即使你未必能找到社会争议的“正确答案”，本书旨在帮助你根据问题的性质和现有信息，找到最佳且最合理的答案。决策通常需要在不确定性中做出。我们往往没有时间或能力去了解与决策相关的诸多重要事实。例如，当你所爱的人抱怨胸口剧痛，并要求你送他去急诊室时，问遍所有相关问题反而是不明智的。

Thinking and Feeling

思考与感受

When you first encounter a conclusion, you do so with a history. You have learned to care about certain things, to support particular interests, and to discount claims of a particular type. So you always start to think critically in the midst of existing opinions. You have emotional commitments to these existing opinions. They are your opinions, and you quite understandably feel protective of them.

当你第一次接触某个结论时，你往往带着一段过往的经历。你已经学会了关心某些事物，支持特定的利益，并忽略某种特定类型的观点。因此，你总是在既有观点的包围下开始批判性思考。你对这些既有观点抱有情感上的依恋。它们是你的观点，你自然会想要维护它们。

This point deserves special emphasis. We bring lots of personal baggage to every decision we make -- experiences, dreams, values, training, and cultural habits.

这一点值得特别强调。我们做的每一个决定都带有浓厚的个人色彩——经历、梦想、价值观、教育背景和文化习惯。

However, if you are to grow, you need to recognize these feelings, and, as much as you are able, put them on a shelf for a bit. Only that effort will enable you to listen carefully when others offer arguments that threaten or violate your current beliefs. This openness is important because many of our own positions on issues are not especially reasonable ones; they are opinions given to us by others, and over many years we develop emotional attachments to them. Indeed, we frequently believe that we are being personally attacked when someone presents a conclusion contrary to our own. The danger of being emotionally involved in an issue is that you may fail to consider potential good reasons for other positions -- reasons that might be sufficient to change your mind on the issue if only you would listen to them.

然而，要想成长，你需要正视这些感受，并尽可能地暂时搁置它们。只有这样，你才能在别人提出可能威胁或违背你现有信念的论点时，认真倾听。这种开放的心态至关重要，因为我们对许多问题的立场并非完全合理；它们是别人灌输给我们的观点，而多年来，我们却对这些观点产生了情感依恋。事实上，当有人提出与我们相悖的结论时，我们常常会觉得受到了人身攻击。情感上的投入会带来危险，那就是你可能会忽略其他立场的潜在合理理由——而这些理由或许足以改变你对这个问题的看法，只要你愿意倾听。

Remember : Emotional involvement should not be the primary basis for accepting or rejecting a position. Ideally, emotional involvement should be most intense after reasoning has occurred. Thus, when you read, try to avoid letting emotional involvement cut you off from the reasoning of those with whom you initially disagree. A successful active learner is one who is willing to change his mind. If you are ever to change your mind, you must be as open as possible to ideas that strike you as weird or dangerous when you first encounter them.

记住：情感投入不应成为接受或拒绝某种观点的主要依据。理想情况下，情感投入应该在理性思考之后最为强烈。因此，阅读时，尽量避免让情感投入阻碍你理解那些你最初不认同的观点。一个成功的积极学习者是愿意改变想法的人。如果你想改变想法，就必须尽可能地对那些你最初觉得奇怪或危险的观点保持开放的态度。

Critical thinkers, however, are not machines. They care greatly about many issues. The depth of that concern can be seen in their willingness to do all the hard mental work associated with critical thinking. But any passion felt by critical thinkers is moderated by the recognition that their current beliefs are open to revision.

然而，批判性思考者并非机器。他们非常关心许多问题。这种关心的程度体现在他们愿意投入批判性思考所需的所有艰苦脑力劳动上。但批判性思考者的任何热情都会受到一种认知的制约，即他们认识到自己当前的信念是可以修正的。

The Efficiency of Asking the Question, "Who Cares?"

问“谁在乎？”这个问题的效率

Asking good questions is difficult but rewarding work. Some controversies will be much more important to you than others. When the consequences of a controversy for you and your community are minimal, you will want to spend less time and energy thinking critically about it than about more important controversies. For example, it makes sense to critically evaluate arguments for and against the protection of endangered species, because different positions on this issue lead to important consequences for society. It makes less sense to devote energy to evaluating whether blue is the favorite color of most corporate executives.

提出好问题并非易事，但却意义非凡。有些争议对你而言远比其他争议重要。当某个争议对你和你的社群的影响微乎其微时，你自然会希望把更多的时间和精力投入到更重要的争议上，而不是深入思考它。例如，批判性地评估支持和反对保护濒危物种的论点是有意义的，因为在这个问题上的不同立场会对社会产生重大影响。而把精力浪费在评估蓝色是否是大多数企业高管最喜欢的颜色上则意义不大。

Your time is valuable. Before taking the time to critically evaluate an issue, ask the question, "Who cares?"

你的时间很宝贵。在花时间认真评估某个问题之前，先问问自己：“谁会在意？”

Weak-Sense and Strong-Sense Critical Thinking

弱感知和强感知批判性思维

Previous sections mentioned that you already have opinions about many personal and social issues. You are willing right now to take a position on such questions as: Should prostitution be legalized? Is alcoholism a disease or willful misconduct? Was George Bush a successful president? You bring these initial opinions to what you hear and read.

前文提到，你对许多个人和社会问题已有自己的看法。你现在愿意就诸如以下问题表明立场：卖淫应该合法化吗？酗酒是疾病还是故意不当行为？乔治·布什是一位成功的总统吗？你会将这些初步看法带入你所听到和读到的内容中。

Critical thinking can be used to either (1) defend or (2) evaluate and revise your initial beliefs. Professor Richard Paul's distinction between weak-sense and strong-sense critical thinking helps us appreciate these two antagonistic uses of critical thinking.

批判性思维既可以用来（1）捍卫你的初始信念，也可以用来（2）评估和修正你的初始信念。理查德·保罗教授对弱意义批判性思维和强意义批判性思维的区分，有助于我们理解批判性思维的这两种截然相反的用途。

Attention : Weak-sense critical thinking is the use of critical thinking to defend your current beliefs. Strong-sense critical thinking is the use of the same skills to evaluate all claims and beliefs, especially your own.
注意：弱式批判性思维是指运用批判性思维来捍卫你现有的信念。强式批判性思维是指运用同样的技能来评估所有主张和信念，尤其是你自己的主张和信念。

If you approach critical thinking as a method for defending your initial beliefs or those you are paid to have, you are engaged in weak-sense critical thinking. Why is it weak? To use critical-thinking skills in this manner is to be unconcerned with moving toward truth or virtue. The purpose of weak-sense critical thinking is to resist and annihilate opinions and reasoning different from yours. To see domination and victory over those who disagree with you as the objective of critical thinking is to ruin the potentially humane and progressive aspects of critical thinking.

如果你把批判性思维当作捍卫你原有信念或那些你因工作而获得的信念的工具，那么你就是在进行弱意义的批判性思维。为什么说它是弱意义的呢？因为以这种方式运用批判性思维，意味着你对追求真理或美德漠不关心。弱意义的批判性思维的目的是抵制和消灭与你不同的观点和推理。将征服和战胜那些与你意见相左的人视为批判性思维的目标，会扼杀批判性思维中潜在的人道主义和进步意义。

In contrast, strong-sense critical thinking requires us to apply the critical questions to all claims, including our own. By forcing ourselves to look critically at our initial beliefs, we help protect against self-deception and conformity. It is easy to just stick with current beliefs, particularly when many people share them. But when we take this easy road, we run the strong risk of making mistakes we could otherwise avoid.

相反，强意识批判性思维要求我们将批判性问题应用于所有主张，包括我们自己的主张。通过强迫自己批判性地审视最初的信念，我们有助于避免自欺欺人和盲从。坚持现有信念很容易，尤其是在许多人都持有相同信念的情况下。但是，如果我们选择这条捷径，就极有可能犯下原本可以避免的错误。

Strong-sense critical thinking does not necessarily force us to give up our initial beliefs. It can provide a basis for strengthening them because critical examination of those beliefs will sometimes reinforce our original commitment to them. A long time ago, John Stuart Mill warned us of the emptiness of a set of opinions accumulated without the help of strong-sense critical thinking:

强有力的批判性思维并不一定会迫使我们放弃原有的信念。它反而可以为强化这些信念提供基础，因为对这些信念的批判性审视有时会巩固我们最初对它们的坚持。很久以前，约翰·斯图亚特·密尔就警告过我们，缺乏强有力的批判性思维而积累的观点是空洞的：

He who knows only his side of the case knows little of that. His reasons may have been good, and no one may have been able to refute them. But if he is equally unable to refute the reasons on the opposite side he has no ground for preferring either opinion.
只了解自己一方观点的人，对另一方的情况知之甚少。他的理由或许充分，或许无人能够反驳。但如果他同样无法反驳对方的理由，那么他就没有理由偏袒任何一方的观点。

To feel proud of a particular opinion, it should be one we have selected -- selected from alternative opinions that we have understood and evaluated.

要对某个观点感到自豪，这个观点应该是我们自己选择的——是从我们已经理解和评估过的各种观点中挑选出来的。

The Satisfaction of Using the Panning-for-Gold Approach

使用淘金法的满足感

Doing is usually more fun than watching; doing well is more fun than simply doing. If you start using the interactive process taught in this book, you can feel the same sense of pride in your reading and listening that you normally get from successful participation in physical activities.

实践通常比观看更有趣；做得好比仅仅做事更有趣。如果你开始运用本书中教授的互动方法，你就能在阅读和聆听中获得与成功参与体育活动时同样的成就感。

Critical thinkers find it satisfying to know when to say "no" to an idea or opinion and to know why that response is appropriate. If you regularly use the panning-for-gold approach, then anything that gets into your head will have been systematically examined first. When an idea or belief does pass the criteria developed here, it will make sense to agree with it -- at least until new evidence appears.

批判性思考者会发现，懂得何时对某种观点或想法说“不”，并明白为何这种拒绝是恰当的，是一件很有成就感的事情。如果你经常运用淘金法，那么任何进入你脑海的东西都会先经过系统的审视。当某种观点或信念符合本文提出的标准时，至少在出现新的证据之前，同意它是合理的。

Imagine how good you will feel if you know why you should ignore or accept a particular bit of advice. Frequently, those faced with an opinion different from their own respond by saying, "Oh, that's just your opinion." But the issue should not be whose opinion it is, but rather whether it is a good opinion. Armed with the critical questions discussed in this book, you can experience the satisfaction of knowing why certain advice is nonsense.

想象一下，如果你知道为什么应该接受或忽略某个建议，你会感觉多么棒。通常，当人们面对与自己不同的观点时，他们会回应说：“哦，那只是你的看法。”但问题的关键不在于这是谁的观点，而在于这是否是一个好的观点。本书探讨的关键问题将帮助你了解某些建议为何荒谬，从而获得成就感。

The sponge approach is often satisfying because it permits you to accumulate information. Though this approach is productive, there is much more gratification in being a participant in a meaningful dialogue with the writer or speaker. Reading and listening become much richer as you begin to see things that others may have missed. As you learn to select information and opinions systematically, you will probably desire to read more and more in a lifelong effort to decide which advice makes sense.

海绵式的吸收方式往往令人满意，因为它能让你积累信息。虽然这种方法卓有成效，但与作者或演讲者进行有意义的对话会带来更大的满足感。当你开始注意到别人可能忽略的细节时，阅读和聆听的意义会更加丰富。随着你学会系统地筛选信息和观点，你可能会渴望阅读更多，并终其一生努力去判断哪些建议是合理的。

Trying Out New Answers

尝试新的答案

Although there is often no absolutely right answer, this book tries to encourage your search for better answers. Certainly, some answers are more accurate, appropriate, useful, or moral than are others. For you to want to do the hard work necessary to find better answers, you need substantial curiosity and even courage.

虽然很多时候并没有绝对正确的答案，但本书旨在鼓励你探寻更佳的答案。诚然，有些答案比其他答案更准确、更恰当、更有用或更符合道德。要想愿意付出努力去寻找更佳答案，你需要强烈的好奇心，甚至勇气。

Courage is required because to keep looking for better answers we have to be willing to give up our current beliefs or positions. When we encounter a question, we probably already have an answer. Suppose someone says something to us about the appropriateness of behavior by abortion activists. In all probability, we already have an opinion about the matter. It often takes incredible courage to give up on an opinion we have held for some time after listening to someone else. As critical thinkers, we have to struggle to force ourselves to try out new answers. The interplay between our old answers and new ones provides a basis for our growth.

我们需要勇气，因为要不断寻求更好的答案，就必须愿意放弃现有的信念或立场。当我们遇到问题时，我们可能已经有了答案。假设有人就堕胎活动人士的行为是否恰当发表了看法。我们很可能已经对此有了自己的看法。在听取他人意见后，放弃自己长期以来坚持的观点往往需要极大的勇气。作为批判性思考者，我们必须努力强迫自己尝试新的答案。新旧答案之间的互动，为我们成长奠定了基础。

Effective Communication and Critical Thinking

有效沟通与批判性思维

Many of the skills you will learn, as you become a more critical thinker, will improve the quality of your writing and speaking. As you write and speak, it helps to be aware of the expectations careful thinkers will have. Because your objective is communication, many of the questions the thoughtful person will ask in evaluating your writing or speech should serve as guides for your own attempts to communicate well. Several of the critical questions that we urge you to ask highlight problems you will want to avoid as you write or speak.

随着你批判性思维能力的提升，你将掌握许多技能，这些技能将有助于提高你的写作和口语水平。在写作和口语表达中，了解那些善于思考的人的期望至关重要。因为你的目标是沟通，所以那些善于思考的人在评价你的写作或演讲时提出的许多问题，都可以作为你自身有效沟通的指导。我们建议你提出的几个关键问题，旨在帮助你发现写作或口语表达中需要避免的问题。

While the emphasis in this book is on effective thinking, the link to competent communication is so direct that it will be a theme throughout. Wherever appropriate, we will mention how the skill being encouraged is an aid to improved communication.

本书虽然侧重于有效思考，但其与有效沟通的联系如此紧密，以至于沟通能力将贯穿全书。在适当之处，我们会提及所倡导的技能如何有助于提升沟通能力。

The Importance of Practice

练习的重要性

Learning new critical-thinking skills is a lot like learning new physical skills. You cannot learn simply by being told what to do or by watching others. You have to practice, and frequently the practice will be both rewarding and hard work. Our goal is to make your learning as simple as possible. However, acquiring the habit of critical thinking will initially take a lot of practice.

学习新的批判性思维技能与学习新的身体技能非常相似。你不能仅仅通过被告知该怎么做或观察别人来学习。你必须练习，而且练习往往既充满挑战又富有成效。我们的目标是尽可能简化你的学习过程。然而，培养批判性思维的习惯最初需要大量的练习。

The practice exercises and sample responses at the end of each chapter are an important part of this text. Try to do the exercises and, only then, compare your answers with ours. Our answers are not necessarily the only correct ones, but they provide illustrations of how to apply the question-asking skills. We intentionally failed to provide sample answers for the third passage at the end of each chapter. Our objective is to give you the opportunity to struggle with the answer using your knowledge of the chapter you have just studied. We want you to feel the accomplishment of no longer necessarily needing us to guide you.

每章末尾的练习题和范例答案是本书的重要组成部分。请先尝试完成练习，然后再将你的答案与我们的答案进行比较。我们的答案不一定是唯一正确的答案，但它们可以帮助你了解如何运用提问技巧。我们特意没有为每章末尾的第三篇阅读理解提供范例答案。我们的目的是让你有机会运用刚刚学习的章节知识来思考答案。我们希望你能体会到不再需要我们指导的成就感。

The Right Questions

正确的问题

To give you an initial sense of the skills that Asking the Right Questions will help you acquire, we will list the critical questions for you here. By the end of the book, you should know when and how to ask these questions productively:

为了让您初步了解《提出正确问题》一书将帮助您掌握的技能，我们在此列出一些关键问题。读完本书后，您应该能够有效地知道何时以及如何提出这些问题：

  1. What are the issues and the conclusions?
    存在哪些问题？得出了哪些结论？
  2. What are the reasons?
    原因是什么？
  3. Which words or phrases are ambiguous?
    哪些词语或短语含义含糊不清？
  4. What are the value conflicts and assumptions?
    存在哪些价值冲突和假设？
  5. What are the descriptive assumptions?
    描述性假设是什么？
  6. Are there any fallacies in the reasoning?
    这种推理是否存在谬误？
  7. How good is the evidence?
    证据有多充分？
  8. Are there rival causes?
    是否存在相互竞争的事业？
  9. Are the statistics deceptive?
    统计数据是否具有欺骗性？
  10. What significant information is omitted?
    遗漏了哪些重要信息？
  11. What reasonable conclusions are possible?
    有哪些合理的结论是可能的？
#↩

Chapter 2 WHAT ARE THE ISSUE AND THE CONCLUSION?

第二章 问题是什么？结论是什么？

Before we evaluate someone's reasoning, we must first find it. Doing so sounds simple; it isn't. To get started as a critical thinker, you must practice the identification of the issue and the conclusion.

在评价一个人的推理之前，我们首先必须找到它。这听起来很简单，但实际上并非如此。要想成为一名批判性思考者，你必须练习识别问题和得出结论。

Cell phones are becoming a large part of today's society bringing with than benefits and drawbacks. They are beneficial for those with tight schedules and in case of emergencies. Cell phones can also come in handy for parents to check up on their children. Even though cell phones do carry benefits, the drawbacks are in their inappropriate use. When a cell phone rings or owners talk on them during a lecture or a concert, a major disruption in the concentration of others is inevitable. Even though there are suggestions in polite society to leave them off, perhaps we need stronger penalties associated with abuse of the growing population of cell phones.
手机已成为当今社会不可或缺的一部分，它既带来了诸多益处，也带来了一些弊端。对于日程繁忙的人以及遇到紧急情况的人来说，手机非常方便。家长也可以利用手机随时了解孩子的状况。尽管手机有很多优点，但其弊端在于不当使用。当手机铃声响起或有人在讲座或音乐会上打电话时，必然会严重干扰他人的注意力。虽然一些文明社会建议人们关掉手机，但或许我们应该对滥用手机的行为施以更严厉的惩罚，以应对日益增长的手机使用群体。

The person who wrote this assessment of cell phones very much wants you to believe something. But what is that something and why are we supposed to believe any such thing?

撰写这篇手机评论的人非常希望你相信某些事情。但究竟是什么事情？我们又为什么要相信这种说法呢？

In general, those who create Web pages, editorials, books, magazine articles, or speeches are trying to change your perceptions or beliefs. For you to form a reasonable reaction to their persuasive effort, you must first identify the controversy or issue as well as the thesis or conclusion being pushed onto you. (Someone's conclusion is her intended message to you. Its purpose is to shape your beliefs and/or behavior.) Otherwise, you will be reacting to a distorted version of the attempted communication.

一般来说，那些创作网页、社论、书籍、杂志文章或发表演讲的人，都试图改变你的认知或信念。为了对他们的说服努力做出合理的反应，你首先必须明确争议点或议题，以及他们试图灌输给你的论点或结论。（结论是某人想要传达给你的信息，其目的是塑造你的信念和/或行为。）否则，你将会对被扭曲的信息做出反应。

When we read or listen, it is so easy to ignore what was said in the previous paragraph. We often react to the images, dramatic illustrations, or tone of what was said instead of the reasoning that was intended by the person communicating with us. Each time we fail to react to the reasoning, human conversation has experienced a defeat. We are not connecting as the person who wrote or spoke to us intended. So, getting straight about the person's conclusion and issue is an essential first step in effective human interaction.

当我们阅读或聆听时，很容易忽略前一段的内容。我们常常会关注画面、生动的描述或语气，而不是对方真正想要表达的逻辑。每次我们忽略对方的逻辑，人际沟通就失去了意义。我们无法像对方希望的那样建立联系。因此，准确理解对方的结论和观点是有效人际交往的第一步。

When you have completed this chapter, you should be able to answer the first of our critical questions successfully:

完成本章后，你应该能够成功回答我们提出的第一个关键问题：

Critical Question : What are the issue and the conclusion?
关键问题：问题是什么？结论是什么？
Attention : An issue is a question or controversy responsible for the conversation or discussion. It is the stimulus for what is being said.
注意：议题是指引发对话或讨论的问题或争议，它是人们谈论内容的刺激因素。

Kinds of Issues

问题类型

It will be helpful at this point to identify two kinds of issues you will typically encounter. The following questions illustrate one of these:

此时，明确您通常会遇到的两种问题类型将很有帮助。以下问题举例说明了其中一种问题：

Do families who own pets have fewer arguments with one another?
养宠物的家庭之间争吵会更少吗？
What causes high blood pressure?
什么原因会导致高血压？
Who made the decision to increase our sales taxes?
是谁决定提高销售税的？
How much will college cost in the year 2010?
2010年大学学费是多少？

All these questions have one thing in common. They demand answers attempting to describe the way the world is, was, or is going to be. For example, answers to the first two questions might be, "In general, families with pets have fewer arguments with one another," and "Poor dietary habits cause high blood pressure."

所有这些问题都有一个共同点：它们都要求我们给出试图描述世界现在、过去或将来状态的答案。例如，前两个问题的答案可能是：“一般来说，有宠物的家庭争吵较少”和“不良的饮食习惯会导致高血压”。

Such issues are descriptive issues. They are commonly found in textbooks, magazines, the Internet, and television. Such issues reflect our curiosity about patterns or order in the world. Note the boldfaced words that begin each question above; when questions begin with these words, they will probably be descriptive questions.

这类问题属于描述性问题，常见于教科书、杂志、互联网和电视中。这类问题反映了我们对世界规律或秩序的好奇心。请注意上面每个问题开头的粗体字；以这些字开头的问题很可能是描述性问题。

Attention : Descriptive issues are those that raise questions about the accuracy of descriptions of the past, present, or future.
注意：描述性问题是指那些对过去、现在或未来的描述准确性提出质疑的问题。

Now let's look at examples of a second kind of question:

现在我们来看第二类问题的例子：

Should capital punishment be abolished?
死刑应该废除吗？
What ought to be done about social security?
社会保障制度应该如何改革？
Must we outlaw SUVs or face increasing rates of asthma?
我们是否必须禁止SUV，否则将面临哮喘发病率不断上升的局面？

All of these questions demand answers suggesting the way the world ought to be . For example, answers to the first two questions might be, "Capital punishment should be abolished," and "We aught to increase social security benefits."

所有这些问题都需要给出答案，以表明世界应该如何运转。例如，前两个问题的答案可能是：“应该废除死刑”和“我们应该提高社会保障福利”。

These issues are ethical, or moral, issues; they raise questions about what is right or wrong, desirable or undesirable, good or bad. They demand prescriptive answers. Thus, we will refer to these issues as prescriptive issues. Social controversies are often prescriptive issues.

这些问题属于伦理或道德问题；它们引发关于对错、可取与不可取、善与恶的思考。这些问题需要明确的答案。因此，我们将这些问题称为规范性问题。社会争议往往属于规范性问题。

We have somewhat oversimplified. Sometimes it will be difficult to decide what kind of issue is being discussed. It will be useful to keep these distinctions in mind, however, because the kinds of critical evaluations you eventually make will differ depending on the kind of issue to which you are responding.

我们在这里做了一些简化。有时很难判断讨论的是哪种类型的问题。不过，记住这些区别是有用的，因为你最终做出的批判性评价会因你所回应的问题类型而异。

Attention : Prescriptive issues are those that raise questions about what we should do or what is right or wrong, good or bad.
注意：规范性问题是指那些引发关于我们应该做什么、什么是对的、什么是错的、什么是好、什么是坏的问题。

Searching for the Issue

查找问题

How does one go about determining the basic question or issue? Sometimes it is very simple: The writer or speaker will tell you what it is. Alternatively, the issue may be identified in the body of the text, usually right at the beginning, or it may even be found in the title. When the issue is explicitly stated, it will be indicated by phrases such as the following:

如何确定基本问题或议题？有时很简单：作者或发言者会直接告诉你。或者，议题可能在正文中有所体现，通常位于开头，甚至可能出现在标题中。当议题被明确提出时，通常会用以下短语来表示：

The question I am raising is : Why must we have speed limits on our highways?
我提出的问题是：为什么我们的高速公路必须限速？
Lowering the legal drinking age: Is it the right thing to do?
降低法定饮酒年龄：这样做对吗？
Should sex education be taught in the schools?
学校应该开设性教育课程吗？

Unfortunately, the question is not always explicitly stated and instead must be inferred from other clues in the communication. For example, many writers or speakers are reacting to some current event that concerns them, such as a series of violent acts in schools. Asking "What is the author reacting to?" will often suggest the central issue of a communication. Another good clue is knowledge of the author's background, such as organizations to which she belongs. So check for background information about the author as you try to determine the issue.

遗憾的是，这个问题并非总是明确提出，而是需要从信息中的其他线索推断出来。例如，许多作者或演讲者都在对一些他们关心的时事做出回应，比如一系列校园暴力事件。询问“作者在回应什么？”通常可以提示信息的核心议题。另一个有用的线索是了解作者的背景，例如她所属的组织。因此，在试图确定议题时，请查看作者的背景信息。

When you are identifying the issue, try to resist the idea that there is one and only one correct way to state the issue. Once you have found a question that the entire essay or speech is addressing, and you can show the link between that question and the essay or speech, you have found the issue. Just make certain that what you are calling an issue meets the definitional criteria for that idea.

在确定议题时，要避免认为只有一种正确的表述方式。一旦你找到整篇文章或演讲都在探讨的问题，并且能够证明这个问题与文章或演讲之间的联系，你就找到了议题。只需确保你所认定的议题符合该概念的定义标准即可。

The surest way to detect an issue when it is not explicitly stated, however, is to locate the conclusion. In many cases, the conclusion must be found before you can identify the issue. Thus, in such cases, the first step in critical evaluation is to find the conclusion -- a frequently difficult step.

然而，当问题没有被明确指出时，最可靠的检测方法是找到结论。很多情况下，必须先找到结论才能识别问题。因此，在这种情况下，批判性评估的第一步是找到结论——这通常是一个困难的步骤。

We cannot critically evaluate until we find the conclusion!

只有得出结论，我们才能进行批判性评价！

Let's see how we go about looking for that very important structural element.

让我们来看看如何寻找这个非常重要的结构元素。

Attention : A conclusion is the message that the speaker or writer wishes you to accept.
注意：结论是说话者或作者希望你接受的信息。

Searching for the Author's or Speaker's Conclusion

查找作者或演讲者的结论

To identify the conclusion, the critical thinker must ask, "What is the writer or speaker trying to prove?" or "What is the communicator's main point?" The answer to either of these questions will be the conclusion. Any answer to the question provided by the speaker or writer will be the conclusion.

为了确定结论，批判性思考者必须问：“作者或演讲者试图证明什么？”或者“传播者的主要观点是什么？”这两个问题的答案就是结论。演讲者或作者对任何问题的回答都可以作为结论。

In searching for a conclusion, you will be looking for a statement or set of statements that the writer or speaker wants you to believe. She wants you to believe the conclusion on the basis of her other statements. In short, the basic structure of persuasive communication or argument is: This because of that . This refers to the conclusion; that refers to the support for the conclusion. This structure represents the process of inference .

在寻找结论时，你要寻找的是作者或发言者希望你相信的某个或一系列陈述。她希望你基于她其他的陈述而相信这个结论。简而言之，说服性沟通或论证的基本结构是：这是因为……。这里，“这是”指的是结论；“那”指的是支持结论的论据。这种结构体现了推理过程。

Conclusions are inferred; they are derived from reasoning. Conclusions are ideas that require other ideas to support them. Thus, whenever someone claims something is true or ought to be done and provides no statements to support her claim, that claim is not a conclusion because no one has offered any basis for belief. In contrast, unsupported claims are what we refer to as mere opinions.

结论是推断出来的，是通过推理得出的。结论是需要其他观点来支撑的观点。因此，当有人声称某事为真或应该做某事，却不提供任何论据来支持其主张时，这种主张就不是结论，因为没有人提供任何信念基础。相反，未经论证的主张我们称之为仅仅是观点。

The last paragraph says a lot. It would be a good idea for you to read it again. Understanding the nature of a conclusion is an essential step toward critical reading and listening. Let's look closely at a conclusion and at the inference process. Here is a brief paragraph; see whether you can identify the conclusion, then the statements that support it.

最后一段内容丰富，建议您再读一遍。理解结论的本质是批判性阅读和聆听的关键一步。让我们仔细分析一下结论及其推论过程。以下是一段简短的文字，请您找出结论以及支持结论的论据。

Factory farming should not be legal. There are other more natural ways to produce needed food supply.
工厂化养殖不应该合法。还有其他更自然的方式来生产所需的食物。

"Factory farming should not be legal." This is the author's answer to the question: should factory farming be legalized? It is her conclusion. The author supports this belief with another: "There are other more natural ways to produce needed food supply."

“工厂化养殖不应该合法化。”这是作者对“工厂化养殖是否应该合法化？”这一问题的回答，也是她的结论。作者还用另一点来佐证她的观点：“还有其他更自然的方式来生产所需的食物。”

Do you see why the supporting belief is not a conclusion? It is not the conclusion because it is used to prove something else. Remember. To believe one statement (the conclusion) because you think it is well supported by other beliefs is to make an inference. When people engage in this process, they are reasoning; the conclusion is the outcome of this reasoning.

你明白为什么支持某个观点的信念本身不是结论吗？因为它不是结论，而是用来证明其他观点的。记住，仅仅因为你认为某个陈述（结论）得到了其他信念的有力支持就相信它，这是一种推理。当人们进行推理时，他们就是在进行推理；结论是这种推理的结果。

Sometimes, communicators will not make their conclusions explicit; in such cases you will have to infer the conclusion from what you believe the author is trying to prove by the set of ideas she has presented.

有时，传播者不会明确表达他们的结论；在这种情况下，你必须根据作者提出的观点来推断她试图证明的内容。

USING THIS CRITICAL QUESTION

利用这个关键问题

Once you have found the conclusion, use it as the focus of your evaluation. It is the destination that the writer or speaker wants you to choose. Your ongoing concern is: Should I accept that conclusion on the basis of what is supporting the claim?

一旦你找到了结论，就把它作为你评估的重点。这是作者或演讲者希望你选择的最终结果。你始终要考虑的是：我是否应该基于支持该论点的论据接受这个结论？

Clues to Discovery: How to Find the Conclusion

发现的线索：如何找到结论

There are a number of clues to help you identify the conclusion.

有很多线索可以帮助你得出结论。

Clue No. 1: Ask what the issue is . Because a conclusion is always a response to an issue, it will help you find the conclusion if you know the issue. We discussed earlier how to identify the issue. First, look at the title. Next, look at the opening paragraphs. If this technique does not help, skimming several pages may be necessary.

线索一：先弄清楚问题是什么。因为结论总是对某个问题的回应，所以如果你知道问题是什么，就能更容易找到结论。我们之前讨论过如何确定问题。首先，看看标题。其次，看看开头几段。如果这种方法行不通，可能需要快速浏览几页。

Clue No. 2: Look for indicator words. The conclusion will frequently be preceded by indicator words that announce a conclusion is coming. When you see these indicator words, take note of them. They tell you that a conclusion may follow. A list of such indicator words follows:

线索二：留意提示词。结论之前通常会有一些提示词，预示着结论即将到来。当你看到这些提示词时，请记下来。它们告诉你接下来可能会有结论。以下是一些常见的提示词：

Read the following passage; then identify and highlight the indicator words. By doing so, you will have identified the statements containing the conclusion.

阅读以下段落；然后找出并标出提示词。这样，你就能找到包含结论的句子。

Because of the wording of the Constitution, it follows that prayer should not be allowed in public schools. When the schools favor any particular religion, they are hampering the freedom of those who embrace a different religion. The idea of freedom of religion is what the country was founded on.
根据宪法的措辞，公立学校不应允许祈祷。当学校偏袒任何特定宗教时，就等于侵犯了其他宗教信仰者的自由。宗教自由正是这个国家立国之本。

You should have highlighted the following phrase: it follows. The conclusion follows these words.

你应该标出以下短语：紧随其后。结论紧随这些文字之后。

Unfortunately, many written and spoken communications do not introduce the conclusion with indicator words. However, when you write, you should draw attention to your thesis with indicator words. Those words act as a neon sign, drawing attention to the point you want the reader to accept.

遗憾的是，许多书面和口头交流都没有用指示词引出结论。然而，写作时，你应该用指示词突出你的论点。这些词语就像霓虹灯一样，吸引读者注意你希望他们接受的观点。

Clue No. 3: Look in likely locations . Conclusions tend to occupy certain locations. The first two places to look are at the beginning and at the end. Many writers begin with a statement of purpose, containing what they are trying to prove. Others summarize their conclusions at the end. If you are reading a long, complex passage and are having difficulty seeing where it is going, skip ahead to the end.

线索三：寻找可能出现的位置。结论往往出现在某些特定位置。首先要查看的是文章的开头和结尾。许多作者会在文章开头陈述写作目的，阐明他们想要证明的观点。也有一些作者会在文章结尾总结结论。如果你正在阅读一篇冗长而复杂的文章，却难以理解其走向，不妨直接跳到结尾。

Clue No. 4: Remember what a conclusion is not . Conclusions will not be any of the following:

线索四：记住结论不是什么。结论不会是以下任何一种：

  • examples
    示例
  • statistics
    统计数据
  • definitions
    定义
  • background information
    背景信息
  • evidence
    证据

Clue No. 5: Check the context of the communication and the author's background. Often writers, speakers, or Internet sites take predictable positions on issues. Knowing probable biases of the source and the background of authors can be especially valuable clues when the conclusion is not explicit. Be especially alert to information about organizations with which writers or speakers may be associated.

线索五：查看信息来源的上下文和作者的背景。通常，作者、演讲者或网站对某些问题持有可预测的立场。当结论不明确时，了解信息来源可能存在的偏见和作者的背景就显得尤为重要。尤其要注意作者或演讲者可能所属的组织机构的信息。

Clue No. 6: Ask the question, "and therefore?" Because conclusions are often implied, ask for the identity of the "and therefore" element. Ask, "Does the author want us to draw an implied conclusion from the information communicated?" Conclusions like "candidate X will be soft on crime" are often left for the reader or viewer to infer from the limited information presented in a political ad.

线索六：问“因此？”。因为结论通常是隐含的，所以要弄清楚“因此”指的是什么。问问自己：“作者是想让我们从所传达的信息中得出隐含的结论吗？” 像“候选人X对犯罪态度软弱”这样的结论，通常留给读者或观众根据政治广告中有限的信息自行推断。

Critical Thinking and Your Own Writing and Speaking

批判性思维与你的写作和演讲

Because readers of your writing will be looking for your thesis or conclusion, help them by giving it the clarity it deserves. It is the central message you want to deliver. Emphasize it; leave no doubt about what it actually is. Making your conclusion easily identifiable not only makes a reader's task easier, it also may improve the logic of your writing. An effective way to emphasize the conclusion is to insert it at the beginning or end of your essay and precede it with an indicator word.

因为读者会寻找你的论点或结论，所以务必清晰地阐明它，帮助他们理解。这是你想传达的核心信息。强调它，让它清晰明了，不容置疑。让结论易于识别，不仅方便读者理解，还能提升文章的逻辑性。强调结论的一个有效方法是将其放在文章开头或结尾，并在前面加上一个指示词。

In addition, take a close look at your conclusion to make certain that it is a direct response to the issue you intended to address. For example, suppose the issue you are attempting to address is: Will owning a pet increase how long we live? If your conclusion is: "yes, it will increase our life span by an average of 15 years," there is a match between issue and conclusion. But were your conclusion, instead, that pets bring joy to the lives of everyone who owns them, your reasoning is confused. The latter conclusion is responding to a different issue, namely, do pets bring joy to our lives?

此外，仔细审视你的结论，确保它直接回应了你想要探讨的问题。例如，假设你试图探讨的问题是：养宠物会延长我们的寿命吗？如果你的结论是：“是的，平均而言，它会延长我们15年的寿命”，那么问题和结论就吻合。但如果你的结论是“宠物给所有养宠物的人带来快乐”，那么你的论证就出现了混乱。后一个结论回应的是另一个问题，即：宠物是否给我们的生活带来快乐？

Practice Exercises

练习题

Critical Question : What are the issue and the conclusion?
关键问题：问题是什么？结论是什么？

In the following passages, locate the issue and conclusion. As you search, be sure to look for indicator words.

在以下段落中，找出文章的主题和结论。查找时，请务必留意提示词。

Passage 1
第一段
Home schooling is a valid concept if the parent makes teaching a full time job, and has the insight, knowledge and patience to do so. However, the truth of the matter is that few parents who home school their child are capable of doing so.
如果家长能将教学作为一项全职工作，并且具备相应的洞察力、知识和耐心，那么在家教育无疑是一种可行的选择。然而，事实是，真正能够做到这一点的在家教育家长寥寥无几。
Parents may choose to pull their student out of public schools for the wrong reasons. Sometimes, when children are a discipline problem, the parents will pull them out of school rather than tolerating the rules associated with the punishment. Such a motivation does not speak well for the probable results of the home schooling that follows. In addition, when there are no other adults to monitor what is going on at home, it is likely that if there is a case of abuse in the home that it will go unnoticed. Society needs to know whether these children are getting the education and treatment they deserve.
家长选择让孩子退学的原因可能并不恰当。有时，当孩子出现纪律问题时，家长宁愿让孩子退学，也不愿容忍学校的惩罚规定。这种动机预示着家庭教育可能带来的不良后果。此外，如果没有其他成年人监督家中的情况，一旦发生虐待事件，很可能被忽视。社会需要了解这些孩子是否得到了应有的教育和待遇。

Passage 2
第二段
Television advertising agencies are very clever in the way that they construct ads. Often the ads are similar to the cartoons that the children enjoy. Children see these characters interacting with a certain product and associate their affection for the character with affection for the product. The companies do not want the children to perceive a difference between the shows they are watching and the advertisements. By using this strategy, these companies take advantage of the fact that children are often not able to discriminate between the cartoons and the ads and do not understand that these things offered come at a cost. Often the advertising is about sugary snacks or fatty foods, leading the children down a path to bad health. Advertising geared towards children should be regulated - just as there are regulations now about tobacco and alcohol ads targeted at children.
电视广告公司在广告制作方面非常狡猾。他们常常把广告做得和孩子们喜欢的动画片很像。孩子们看到动画片里的角色与某种产品互动，就会把对角色的喜爱和对产品的喜爱联系起来。广告公司不希望孩子们分辨出他们正在看的动画片和广告之间的区别。通过这种策略，广告公司利用了孩子们往往无法区分动画片和广告，也不明白这些东西背后是有代价的这一事实。广告内容通常是含糖零食或高脂肪食品，这会误导孩子们，让他们走上不健康的道路。针对儿童的广告应该受到监管——就像现在针对儿童的烟草和酒精广告一样。

Passage 3
第三段
Should the public be shown actual courtroom trials on television? It seems as though the system can easily be corrupted by having cameras in the courtroom. Victims are hesitant enough when testifying in front of a small crowd, but their knowledge that every word is being sent to countless homes would increase the likelihood that they would simply refuse to testify. There is little to no assumed innocence for the accused when their trial is put on television. People do not watch court television because they are concerned about our country's ability to effectively carry out the proceedings of the judicial system; instead, they are looking for the drama in witness testimony: entertainment. Thus, leave the cameras out of the courtrooms, and let the public view sitcom drama based off of the legal system.
是否应该在电视上向公众播放真实的法庭审判？似乎在法庭上架设摄像机很容易腐蚀司法系统。受害者在少数旁听者面前作证时就已经很犹豫了，如果他们知道自己说的每一句话都会被发送到无数家庭，那么他们很可能就会干脆拒绝作证。当审判在电视上播出时，被告的无罪推定几乎荡然无存。人们观看法庭电视并非出于对国家司法系统有效运作能力的担忧，而是为了从证人证词中寻求戏剧性：娱乐。因此，应该把摄像机留在法庭外，让公众观看以法律系统为背景的情景喜剧。

Sample Responses

示例回复

Passage 1
第一段
The author states her conclusion in the second sentence of the passage. The conclusion is identified by the phrase, "the truth of the matter is". The author does not explicitly state the issue, but it can be inferred by the conclusion and the reasons. There are listed reasons in the second paragraph that suggest why some parents' motivation to home school their children would lend to an ineffective home schooling experience. This example is prescriptive because it asks what ought to be done.
作者在文章第二句中阐明了她的结论。结论以“事实是……”这一短语呈现。作者并未明确指出问题所在，但可以从结论和理由中推断出来。第二段列举了一些理由，表明一些家长选择在家教育孩子的动机为何会导致家庭教育效果不佳。这个例子具有指导意义，因为它提出了应该采取的措施。
ISSUE: Should all parents be allowed to home school their children?
问题：是否应该允许所有家长在家教育子女？
CONCLUSION: No, most parents are not capable of home schooling.
结论：不，大多数家长没有能力在家教育孩子。

Passage 2
第二段
There are no indicator words to point towards the conclusion, but a good place to look for the conclusion is either at the beginning or end of the excerpt. In this case, the very last statement is the conclusion, and you can tell it is the conclusion because it gives finality to the passage using the phrase "should be". This phrase also indicates that this is a prescriptive issue. It is not talking about the way things are or are not, but how they ought to be. The issue is assumed from the conclusion and from the preceding statements explaining why the author came to her conclusion.
虽然没有直接指向结论的提示词，但通常可以在文章开头或结尾找到结论。在本例中，最后一句话就是结论，你可以通过它使用“应该”一词来判断它是结论，因为它为文章画上了句号。这个短语也表明这是一个规范性问题。它不是在讨论事物现在的样子或现在的样子，而是在讨论事物应该是什么样子。这个问题可以从结论以及前面解释作者得出结论的陈述中推断出来。
ISSUE: Should advertisements geared towards children be regulated?
问题：是否应该对面向儿童的广告进行监管？
CONCLUSION: Advertisements geared toward children should be regulated.
结论：针对儿童的广告应该受到监管。

CRITICAL QUESTION SUMMARY: WHY THIS QUESTION IS IMPORTANT

关键问题总结：为什么这个问题很重要

What Are the Issue and the Conclusion?

问题是什么？结论是什么？

Before you can evaluate an author's argument, you must clearly identify the issue and conclusion. How can you evaluate an argument if you don't know exactly what the author is trying to persuade you to believe? Finding an author's main point is the first step in deciding whether you will accept or reject it.

在评估作者的论点之前，你必须先明确其核心问题和结论。如果你不清楚作者究竟想说服你相信什么，又该如何评估其论点呢？找到作者的主要观点是决定接受还是拒绝该观点的第一步。

#↩

CHAPTER 3 WHAT ARE THE REASONS?

第三章 原因是什么？

Reasons provide answers for our human curiosity about why someone makes a particular decision or holds a particular opinion.

理由可以解答我们人类的好奇心，即为什么有人会做出某个决定或持有某个观点。

Every class should conclude with student evaluations.
每节课都应该以学生评价作为结尾。
A pig is smarter than a mule.
猪比骡子聪明。
Employers should be able to fire any employee who refuses to take a drug test.
雇主应该有权解雇任何拒绝接受药物测试的员工。

Those three claims are each missing something. We may or may not agree with them, but in their current form they are neither weak nor strong. None of the claims contains an explanation or rationale for why we should agree. Thus, if we heard someone make one of those three assertions, we would be left hungry for more.

这三个论点都存在缺陷。我们或许同意它们，或许不同意，但就目前而言，它们既不强也不弱。这些论点都没有提供任何解释或理由来说明我们为何应该同意。因此，如果我们听到有人提出这三个论点中的任何一个，我们都会感到意犹未尽，渴望了解更多。

What is missing is the reason or reasons responsible for the claims. Reasons are beliefs, evidence, metaphors, analogies, and other statements offered to support or justify conclusions. They are the statements that together form the basis for creating the credibility of a conclusion. Chapter 2 gave you some guidelines for locating two very important parts of the structure of an argument—the issue and the conclusion. This chapter focuses on techniques for identifying the third essential element of an argument— the reasons.

缺失的是支撑这些论断的理由。理由包括信念、证据、比喻、类比以及其他用于支持或证明结论的陈述。这些陈述共同构成了结论可信度的基础。第二章提供了一些指导原则，帮助你找到论证结构中两个非常重要的组成部分——论点和结论。本章将重点介绍识别论证第三个必要要素——理由的技巧。

When a writer has a conclusion she wants you to accept, she must present reasons to persuade you that she is right and to show you why.

当一位作者想要你接受她的结论时，她必须提出理由来说服你她是正确的，并向你展示为什么。

It is the mark of a rational person to support her beliefs with adequate proof, especially when the beliefs are of a controversial nature. For example, when someone asserts that we should exclude inexperienced lawyers from representing those charged with felonies, this assertion should be met with the challenge, "Why do you say that?" You should raise this question whether you agree or disagree.

理性之人应当用充分的证据来支持自己的观点，尤其是在观点具有争议性时。例如，当有人声称我们应该禁止经验不足的律师代理重罪被告时，我们应该质问：“你为什么这么说？”无论你是否同意对方的观点，都应该提出这个问题。

The person's reasons may be either strong or weak, but you will not know until you have asked the question and identified the reasons. If the answer is "because I think so," you should be dissatisfied with the argument, because the "reason" is a mere restatement of the conclusion.
