导致这些不同结论的一个极其重要的原因是价值冲突的存在，或者说源于不同参照框架的不同价值观。对于伦理或规范性论证而言，个人的价值观会影响其提供的理由，进而影响其结论。事实上，只有在推理中加入价值假设，这些理由才能在逻辑上支持结论。以下的小例子说明了价值假设在规范性论证中的作用。

We should not legalize recreational drugs. Illegal drugs cause too much street violence and other crimes.

我们不应该将娱乐性毒品合法化。非法毒品会导致太多的街头暴力和其他犯罪。

Value assumptions are very important assumptions for such arguments because they are directing the reasoning from behind a screen. The person trying to communicate with you may or may not be aware of these assumptions. You should make it a habit to identify the value assumptions on which the reasons are based.

价值假设对于这类论证至关重要，因为它们在幕后左右着推理过程。与你沟通的人可能意识到这些假设，也可能没有。你应该养成习惯，识别出论证所依据的价值假设。

By value assumption , we mean a taken-for-granted belief about the relative desirability of certain competing values. When authors take a position on a social controversy, they typically prefer one value over another value—they have value priorities or preferences . The rest of this chapter is devoted to increasing your awareness of the role played by value conflicts and value priorities in determining a person's opinions or conclusions. This awareness will help you locate and evaluate this important type of assumption.

所谓价值假设，指的是人们对某些相互竞争的价值的相对优劣所持有的不言而喻的信念。当作者就某个社会争议表明立场时，他们通常会倾向于某种价值而非其他价值——他们具有价值优先顺序或偏好。本章余下部分将致力于提升你对价值冲突和价值优先顺序在决定一个人观点或结论中所起作用的认识。这种认识将有助于你识别和评估这类重要的假设。

Discovering Values

发现价值观

Before you can discover the importance of values in shaping conclusions, you must have some understanding of what a value is. Values, as we will use the term, are ideas that someone thinks are worthwhile. You will find that it is the importance one assigns to abstract ideas that has the major influence on one's choices and behavior.

在了解价值观对形成结论的重要性之前，你必须先理解价值观的含义。我们这里所说的价值观，是指人们认为有价值的想法。你会发现，一个人赋予抽象概念的重视程度，对其选择和行为有着至关重要的影响。

Usually objects, experiences, and actions are desired because of some idea we value. For example, we may choose to do things that provide us with contacts with important people. We value "important people" (concrete idea) because we value "status" (abstract idea). When we use the word value in this chapter, we will be referring to an (abstract) idea representing what someone thinks is important and good.

通常，我们渴望拥有某些物品、经历或行为，是因为我们珍视某种理念。例如，我们可能会选择去做一些能让我们结识重要人物的事情。我们珍视“重要人物”（具体理念），是因为我们珍视“地位”（抽象理念）。在本章中，当我们使用“价值”一词时，我们指的是一种（抽象的）理念，它代表了某人认为重要和美好的事物。

Attention : Values are the unstated ideas that people see as worthwhile. They provide standards of conduct by which we measure the quality of human behavior.
注意：价值观是人们认为有价值的、但未被明确表达出来的观念。它们为我们衡量人类行为的质量提供了行为准则。

To better familiarize yourself with values, write down some of your own values. Try to avoid writing down the names of people, tangible objects, or actions. Pizza and playing tennis may be important to you, but it is the importance you assign to abstract ideas that most influences your choices and behavior concerning controversial public issues. Your willingness to argue for or against capital punishment, for instance, is strongly related to the importance you assign to the sanctity of human life—an abstract idea. The sanctity of human life is a value that affects our opinions about war, abortion, drug usage, and mercy killing. As you create your list of values, focus on those that are so significant that they affect your opinions and behavior in many ways.

为了更好地了解价值观，不妨写下一些你自己的价值观。尽量避免写下人名、具体物品或行为。披萨和网球或许对你很重要，但真正影响你对争议性公共议题的选择和行为的，是你赋予抽象概念的重视程度。例如，你是否愿意就死刑进行辩论，与你对生命神圣性的重视程度密切相关——而生命神圣性本身就是一个抽象概念。生命神圣性这一价值观会影响我们对战争、堕胎、吸毒和安乐死的看法。在列出你的价值观清单时，重点关注那些对你影响深远、在多方面影响你的观点和行为的价值观。

Did you have problems making your list? We can suggest two further aids that may help. First, another definition! Values are standards of conduct that we endorse and expect people to meet. When we expect our political representatives to "tell the truth," we are indicating to them and to ourselves that honesty is one of our most cherished values. Ask yourself what you expect your friends to be like. What standards of conduct would you want your children to develop? Answers to these questions should help you enlarge your understanding of values.

您在列清单时遇到困难了吗？我们可以提供两种辅助方法，或许能帮到您。首先，我们来看另一个定义！价值观是我们认可并期望人们遵守的行为准则。当我们期望我们的政治代表“说真话”时，我们既是在向他们表明，也是在向自己表明，诚实是我们最珍视的价值观之一。问问自己，您希望您的朋友是什么样的人？您希望您的孩子培养怎样的行为准则？这些问题的答案应该能帮助您更深入地理解价值观。

Now let us give you an aid for identifying values—a list of some commonly held values. Every value on our list may be an attractive candidate for your list. Thus, after you look at our list, pause for a moment and choose those values that are most important to you. They will be those values that most often play a role in shaping your opinions and behavior.

现在，我们为您提供一些识别价值观的辅助工具——一份常见价值观清单。清单上的每一项价值观都可能对您有所启发。因此，在您浏览完清单后，请稍作停顿，选择对您而言最重要的价值观。这些价值观将最常影响您的观点和行为。

From Values to Value Assumptions

从价值观到价值假设

To identify value assumptions, we must go beyond a simple listing of values. Others share many of your values. Wouldn't almost anyone claim that flexibility, cooperation, and honesty are desirable?

要识别价值假设，我们不能仅仅列出价值观。其他人也拥有许多与你相同的价值观。几乎没有人会认为灵活、合作和诚实是可取的品质吗？

Look again at the definition, and you will immediately see that, by definition, most values will be on everyone's list. Because many values are shared, values by themselves are not a powerful guide to understanding. What leads you to answer a prescriptive question differently from someone else is the relative intensity with which you hold specific values.

再仔细看看这个定义，你会立刻发现，根据定义，大多数价值观都会出现在每个人的清单上。因为很多价值观是共通的，所以价值观本身并不能有效地帮助我们理解事物。真正导致你对某个规范性问题的回答与他人不同的，是你对特定价值观的重视程度不同。

That we attach different levels of intensity to specific values can be appreciated by thinking about responses to controversies when pairs of values collide or conflict. While it is not very enlightening to discover that most people value both competition and cooperation, we do gain a more complete understanding of prescriptive choices as we discover who prefers competition to cooperation when the two values conflict.

我们赋予特定价值观不同程度的重视程度，可以通过思考当两种价值观发生冲突或碰撞时人们的反应来理解。虽然发现大多数人既重视竞争也重视合作并不令人感到意外，但当我们了解当两种价值观发生冲突时，哪些人更倾向于竞争而非合作时，我们就能更全面地理解规范性选择。

A writer's preference for particular values is often unstated, but that value preference, nevertheless, will have a major impact on her conclusion and on how she chooses to defend it. These unstated assertions about value priorities function as value assumptions. Some refer to these assumptions as value judgments. Recognition of relative support for conflicting values or sets of values provides you with both an improved understanding of what you are reading and a basis for eventual evaluation of prescriptive arguments.

作者对特定价值观的偏好通常不会明说，但这种价值观偏好却会对她的结论以及她如何捍卫这一结论产生重大影响。这些关于价值优先顺序的未明言的断言构成了价值假设。有些人将这些假设称为价值判断。认识到对相互冲突的价值观或价值观体系的相对支持度，既能帮助你更好地理解所读内容，也能为最终评估规范性论证奠定基础。

When a writer takes a stand on controversial prescriptive issues, she is usually depreciating one commonly shared value while upholding another. For example, when someone advocates the required licensing of prospective parents, collective responsibility is being treated as more important than individual responsibility. So when you look for value assumptions, look for an indication of value priorities. Ask yourself what values are being upheld by this position and what values are being relatively downgraded in importance.

当一位作者就颇具争议的规范性问题表明立场时，她通常会贬低一种普遍认同的价值观，同时维护另一种。例如，当有人倡导要求准父母持有执照时，她实际上是将集体责任置于个人责任之上。因此，在探究价值假设时，要寻找价值优先顺序的蛛丝马迹。扪心自问：这种立场维护了哪些价值观？又有哪些价值观的重要性被相对降低了？

Attention : A value assumption is an implicit preference for one value over another in a particular context. We use value preferences and value priorities as synonyms.
注意：价值假设是指在特定语境下对某种价值而非其他价值的隐含偏好。我们将价值偏好和价值优先级视为同义词。

When you have found a person's value preference in a particular argument, you should not expect that same person to necessarily have the same value priority when discussing a different controversy. A person does not have the same value priorities without regard to the issue being discussed. The context and factual issues associated with a controversy also greatly influence how far we're willing to go with a particular value preference. We hold our value preferences only up to a point. Thus, for example, those who prefer freedom of choice over the welfare of the community in most situations (such as wearing clothing that displays an image of the flag) may shift that value preference when they see the possibility of too much damage to the welfare of the community (such as in the case of the right of a person to give a racist speech).

当你发现某人在某个特定论点中的价值偏好时，不应期望同一个人在讨论其他争议时也必然持有相同的价值优先顺序。一个人的价值优先顺序并非一成不变，而是会随着讨论议题的不同而变化。争议的背景和事实也会极大地影响我们对特定价值偏好的坚持程度。我们的价值偏好是有界限的。例如，那些在大多数情况下（例如穿着印有国旗图案的衣服）更倾向于选择自由而非社区福祉的人，一旦意识到这种选择可能对社区福祉造成过大损害（例如在某人发表种族主义言论的权利问题上），他们的价值偏好就可能会发生转变。

In other words, value assumptions are very contextual; they apply in one setting, but we may make quite a different value priority when the specifics of the prescriptive issue change. Critical thinking plays a major role in thinking deeply about whether we want to assign priority to particular values in a given instance. Because our minds tend to like to put things in neat compartments, you have to work hard to tolerate the complexity of a person's value preferences. While we can say that particular people tend to make particular value assumptions, we never can be certain about that presumption. Instead, we have to listen and observe closely before we can get a solid understanding of the value preferences that a person is using in a particular instance.

换句话说，价值假设具有很强的情境性；它们在一种情境下适用，但当具体问题发生变化时，我们可能会做出截然不同的价值优先排序。批判性思维在深入思考我们是否要在特定情况下优先考虑某些价值方面发挥着重要作用。因为我们的思维倾向于将事物归类，所以我们需要努力去包容一个人价值偏好的复杂性。虽然我们可以说某些人倾向于做出某些特定的价值假设，但我们永远无法确定这种假设是否正确。相反，我们必须仔细聆听和观察，才能真正理解一个人在特定情况下所采用的价值偏好。

Typical Value Conflicts

典型的价值冲突

If you are aware of typical conflicts, you can more quickly recognize the assumptions being made by a writer when she reaches a particular conclusion. We have listed some of the more common value conflicts that occur in ethical issues and have provided you with examples of controversies in which these value conflicts are likely to be evident. We anticipate that you can use this list as a starting point when you are trying to identify important value assumptions.

如果您了解常见的价值冲突，就能更快地识别作者在得出特定结论时所做的假设。我们列举了一些伦理问题中常见的价值冲突，并提供了这些价值冲突可能显现的争议案例。我们希望这份清单能作为您识别重要价值假设的起点。

As you identify value conflicts, you will often find that there are several value conflicts that seem important in shaping conclusions with respect to particular controversies. When evaluating a controversy, try to find several value conflicts, as a check on yourself. Some controversies will have one primary value conflict; others may have several.

在识别价值冲突的过程中，你往往会发现，在特定争议中，有几个价值冲突似乎对得出结论至关重要。评估争议时，试着找出几个价值冲突，以此来检验自己的判断。有些争议可能只有一个主要的价值冲突；而有些争议则可能有多个。

Take another look at number 7 in the preceding list. It is quite possible that other value conflicts besides that between generosity and material success affect your decision about whether to give financial help to a beggar. For instance, all the following value conflicts may affect a person's willingness to help a beggar:

请再看一下前面列表中的第7项。除了慷慨与物质成功之间的价值冲突之外，很可能还有其他价值冲突会影响你是否向乞丐提供经济援助的决定。例如，以下所有价值冲突都可能影响一个人帮助乞丐的意愿：

  1. individual responsibility-collective responsibility
    个人责任——集体责任
  2. competition-cooperation
    竞争与合作
  3. efficiency-social stability
    效率-社会稳定性

By identifying as many of the relevant value assumptions as possible, you have a better chance of not missing any of the important dimensions of the argument. However, you may have no way of knowing which value assumptions most influence the author's reasoning.

通过尽可能多地识别相关的价值假设，你更有可能避免遗漏论证中的任何重要层面。然而，你可能无法得知哪些价值假设对作者的推理影响最大。

The Communicator's Background as a Clue to Value Assumptions

沟通者的背景是其价值观假设的线索

We suggested earlier that a good starting point in finding value assumptions is to check the background of the author. Find out as much as you can about the value preferences usually held by a person like the writer. Is she a corporate executive, a union leader, a Republican Party official, a doctor, or an apartment tenant? What interests does such a person naturally wish to protect? There is certainly nothing inherently wrong with pursuing self-interest, but such pursuits often limit the value assumptions a particular writer will tolerate. For example, it is highly unlikely that the president of a major automobile firm would place a high value on efficiency when a preference for efficiency rather than stability would lead to his losing his job. Consequently, you as a critical reader or listener can often quickly discover value preferences by thinking about the probable assumptions made by a person like the writer.

我们之前提到过，寻找价值假设的一个好方法是了解作者的背景。尽可能多地了解像作者这样的人通常持有的价值偏好。她是企业高管、工会领袖、共和党官员、医生还是公寓租户？这样的人自然会想要维护哪些利益？追求自身利益本身当然无可厚非，但这种追求往往会限制特定作者能够容忍的价值假设。例如，一家大型汽车公司的总裁不太可能高度重视效率，因为如果他选择效率而非稳定性，就可能导致丢掉工作。因此，作为一位批判性的读者或听众，你通常可以通过思考像作者这样的人可能做出的假设，迅速发现其价值偏好。

One caution is important. It isn't necessarily true that, because a person is a member of a group, she shares the particular value assumptions of the group. It would be a mistake to presume that every individual who belongs to a given group thinks identically. We all know that business people, farmers, and firefighters sometimes disagree among themselves when discussing particular controversies. Investigating the writer's background as a clue to her value assumptions is only a clue, and, like other clues, it can be misleading unless it is used with care.

有一点需要特别注意。一个人身处某个群体并不意味着她就认同该群体的所有价值观。假定群体中的所有成员都持有完全相同的观点是错误的。我们都知道，商人、农民和消防员在讨论某些争议性问题时，彼此之间也常常存在分歧。调查作者的背景来推断其价值观仅仅是一种线索，而且与其他线索一样，如果不谨慎使用，也可能产生误导。

Consequences as Clues to Value Assumptions

后果作为价值假设的线索

In prescriptive arguments, each position with respect to an issue leads to different consequences or outcomes. Each of the potential consequences will have a certain likelihood of occurring, and each will also have some level of desirability or undesirability.

在规范性论证中，针对某一问题的不同立场都会导致不同的后果或结果。每一种潜在后果都有一定的发生概率，并且每一种后果也都具有一定程度的可取性或不可取性。

How desirable a consequence is will depend on a writer's or reader's personal value preferences. The desirability of the conclusions in such cases will be dictated by the probability of the potential consequences and the importance attached to them. Thus, an important means of determining an individual's value assumptions is to examine the reasons given in support of a conclusion and then to determine what value priorities would lead to these reasons being judged as more desirable than reasons that might have been offered on the other side of the issue. Let's take a look at a concrete example.

结果是否可取取决于作者或读者的个人价值偏好。在这种情况下，结论的可取性取决于潜在结果发生的概率以及人们赋予这些结果的重要性。因此，确定个人价值假设的一个重要方法是，考察支持某个结论的理由，然后确定哪些价值优先顺序会使这些理由被认为比反方理由更可取。让我们来看一个具体的例子。

Nuclear power plants should not be built because they will pollute our environment.
不应该建造核电站，因为它们会污染我们的环境。

The reason provided here is a rather specific potential consequence of building nuclear plants. This writer clearly sees environmental pollution as very undesirable. Why does this consequence carry so much weight in this person's thinking? What more general value does preventing pollution help achieve? We are only guessing, but probably health or conservation are being weighted especially heavily by this person. Someone else might stress a different consequence in this argument, such as the effect on the supply of electricity to consumers. Why? Probably because he values efficiency very highly! Thus, this reason supports the conclusion if a value assumption is made that conservation is more important than efficiency.

这里给出的理由是建造核电站的一个相当具体的潜在后果。这位作者显然认为环境污染非常不可取。为什么这个后果在他的思考中如此重要？防止污染究竟能带来哪些更广泛的价值？我们只能猜测，但很可能这位作者特别重视健康或环境保护。其他人可能会在这个论点中强调其他后果，例如对消费者电力供应的影响。为什么？很可能是因为他非常重视效率！因此，如果假设环境保护比效率更重要，那么这个理由就支持了结论。

Note that the magnitude of a consequence may have a major impact on value preferences. One may value conservation over efficiency only when efficiency may cause "significant" damage to the environment. And, one may value economic freedom over economic security only as long as unemployment stays below a given level. It is possible for people to have different conclusions, while having identical value assumptions, because they disagree about the likelihood or magnitude of consequences.

需要注意的是，后果的严重程度可能会对价值偏好产生重大影响。人们可能只有在提高效率可能对环境造成“重大”损害时才会重视环境保护而非提高效率。同样，人们可能只有在失业率低于特定水平时才会重视经济自由而非经济保障。即使人们拥有相同的价值假设，也可能得出不同的结论，因为他们对后果发生的可能性或严重程度存在分歧。

One important means of determining value assumptions, then, is to ask the question, "Why do the particular consequences or outcomes presented as reasons seem so desirable to the writer or speaker?"

因此，确定价值假设的一个重要方法是提出这样的问题：“为什么作者或演讲者认为所提出的具体后果或结果如此令人向往？”

Remember: When you identify value assumptions, you should always try to state value priorities. With controversial topics, stating value assumptions in this way will be a continual reminder both of what the writer is giving up and of what she is gaining. Try to resist the temptation to stop your analysis prematurely by just identifying the values of the speaker or writer. Identifying those values is a step on the way to finding the value assumptions, but by itself it provides very little assistance in understanding an argument. Values, by their nature, are possessed by us all.

记住：在识别价值假设时，务必尝试阐明价值的优先顺序。对于有争议的话题，以这种方式阐明价值假设，能够不断提醒读者作者放弃了什么，又获得了什么。切勿仅仅因为识别出说话者或作者的价值观就过早地结束分析。识别这些价值观是找到价值假设的第一步，但仅凭这一点对理解论证本身帮助甚微。价值观，就其本质而言，是每个人都拥有的。

More Hints for Finding Value Assumptions

寻找价值假设的更多提示

Another useful technique for generating value conflicts is to reverse role-play. Ask the question, "What do those people who would take a different position from the writer's care about?" When someone argues that we should not use monkeys in experimental research, you should ask yourself, "If I wanted to defend the use of monkeys, what would I be concerned about?" Remember, when someone takes a position on a controversial topic, she will be revealing a value priority—a preference for one value over another . Your knowledge of that preference will help you to decide whether to agree with her conclusion.

另一种产生价值冲突的有效方法是角色互换。问问自己：“那些与作者立场不同的人会关心什么？”当有人认为我们不应该在实验研究中使用猴子时，你应该问问自己：“如果我想为使用猴子辩护，我会关心什么？”记住，当有人就一个有争议的话题表明立场时，她实际上是在展现一种价值优先顺序——一种对某种价值的偏好。你对这种偏好的了解将有助于你决定是否同意她的结论。

Finally, you can always check to see whether the disagreement results from a value conflict concerning the rights of an individual to behave in a particular fashion and the welfare of the group affected by the behavior in question. Many arguments rest implicitly on a stance with respect to this enduring value conflict. Like other common value conflicts, we can all recall numerous instances when our thinking required us to weigh these two important values and their effects.

最后，你还可以检查一下分歧是否源于价值冲突，即个人以特定方式行事的权利与受该行为影响的群体的福祉之间的冲突。许多争论都隐含地建立在这一长期存在的价值冲突上的立场之上。与其他常见的价值冲突一样，我们都能想起很多次这样的情况：我们的思考需要权衡这两个重要的价值及其影响。

For example, when we wonder about the use of metal detectors in the public schools, we often begin to construct our arguments in terms of thinking about the privacy rights of the individual students and the threats to the student body if a student were to bring a weapon to school. Then, we try to balance those values against other values: Does the individual's right to privacy deserve greater protection than the welfare of the other students in the school in this instance? What other issues involve this value conflict? What about the request of "skinheads" to parade through ethnic neighborhoods?

例如，当我们质疑公立学校使用金属探测器的必要性时，我们通常会从学生个人的隐私权以及学生携带武器到校可能对其他学生构成的威胁入手来构建论点。然后，我们会尝试权衡这些价值与其他价值：在这种情况下，个人隐私权是否应该比学校其他学生的福祉更受重视？还有哪些问题涉及这种价值冲突？比如，要求“光头党”在少数族裔聚居区游行的事件又该如何看待？

Avoiding a Typical Difficulty When Identifying Value Assumptions

避免在识别价值假设时遇到的典型困难

Try to keep your eye on the goal of identifying value assumptions; if you stop your analysis after you have identified the primary values of the person who created the argument, you will have cut yourself off from the downside associated with the argument. Let us explain with an illustration:

务必始终关注识别价值假设这一目标；如果你在识别出论点提出者的主要价值观后就停止分析，那么你就错过了该论点可能带来的负面影响。让我们用一个例子来说明：

Drug research is a long, complicated, and expensive process. There are innumerable factors that researchers and medical professionals have to consider when looking for new discoveries in drugs. It is unfair for outsiders to criticize something they do not understand.
药物研发是一个漫长、复杂且耗资巨大的过程。研究人员和医疗专业人员在寻求新药时，需要考虑无数因素。外行人对他们不了解的事物妄加评论是不公平的。
Yes, prescription prices are high. But that high price actually has little to do with the cost of research. The price of prescription drugs is the responsibility of someone other than the researchers, mainly drug companies (companies that solely exist to market and sell prescription drugs). Do not punish the research companies when they ask for donations just because your prescription costs are high—the two are not related.
是的，处方药价格确实很高。但高昂的价格实际上与研究成本关系不大。处方药的价格并非由研究人员承担，而是由制药公司（其存在的唯一目的就是销售处方药）等其他方负责。不要因为处方药价格高就责怪那些寻求捐款的制药公司——这两者之间并无关联。

Suppose you read the argument and then say: I believe the person values prescription drug research. At one level, you have identified what the person who made the argument sees as important. She does indicate a desire to encourage society to fund this research. But that response is too concrete to serve as an avenue toward deeper thinking about this prescriptive issue.

假设你读完这段论证后说：“我相信这个人重视处方药研究。” 从某种程度上说，你已经了解了提出论证的人认为什么最重要。她确实表达了希望鼓励社会资助这项研究的愿望。但这种回应过于具体，不足以引导人们更深入地思考处方药问题。

To move in a more productive way toward a better understanding of the issue, take another look at the definition of values. That definition suggests a need to place drug research into a more abstract framework. Once that need is recognized, a common response is to say: She values health. That recognition is a step in the right direction. This value is at work in this argument, propelling the reasoning. The same value is relevant to any number of issues surrounding health care and the medical profession. But were we to stop at this point, we would miss much of the understanding that would emerge were we to pursue the value assumptions in the argument.

为了更有效地深入理解这个问题，我们不妨重新审视一下价值观的定义。这个定义表明，我们需要将药物研究置于一个更为抽象的框架中。一旦认识到这一点，我们通常会说：她重视健康。这种认识是朝着正确方向迈出的一步。这种价值观贯穿于整个论证，推动着推理的进行。同样的价值观也适用于围绕医疗保健和医疗行业的诸多问题。但如果我们止步于此，就会错过深入探究论证中价值观假设所带来的诸多理解。

In that values are in tension with one another, we are missing a lot when we just call out the values a person has. The relative ranking of the values that affect this argument is what assists in determining the person's conclusions. That someone values the health of others over the values associated with alternative uses of public funds is what pushes them in the direction of the conclusion.

鉴于各种价值观之间存在着内在的冲突，如果我们仅仅指出一个人的价值观，就会忽略很多重要信息。影响这一论点的各种价值观的相对优先级，才是决定其最终结论的关键。例如，如果一个人更看重他人的健康，而不是公共资金的其他用途，那么正是这种对他人健康的重视程度，最终会促使他们得出某个结论。

So push yourself all the way to finding value assumptions. Don't stop your search at levels of analysis that are less revealing.

所以，要坚持不懈地寻找价值假设。不要止步于那些揭示信息量较小的分析层面。

Finding Value Assumptions on Your Own

自行寻找价值假设

Let's work on an example together to help you become more comfortable with finding value assumptions.

让我们一起来看一个例子，帮助你更好地掌握价值假设的寻找方法。

Different workplaces have different working environments. Some offer competitive wages, where performance is evaluated and compared with that of others and they may or may not get a pay raise accordingly. Some places like to encourage an environment where everyone works together as a group. Pay raises in this environment are usually done by amount of education or experience. This type of workplace allows for workers to form good relationships and work together as a team. Which work environment would really have the best productivity? One where everyone was pitted against everyone else and productivity was the only basis for pay raises, or one where the environment fosters a team that works together to up the productivity?
不同的工作场所拥有不同的工作环境。有些工作场所提供具有竞争力的薪酬，员工的绩效会被评估并与他人进行比较，并可能因此获得加薪，也可能不会。有些工作场所则鼓励团队合作，在这种环境下，加薪通常取决于员工的学历或工作经验。这种工作场所有利于员工建立良好的人际关系，并像一个团队一样共同努力。那么，哪种工作环境才能真正带来最高的生产力呢？是那种人人竞争、生产力是加薪唯一依据的环境，还是那种鼓励团队合作、共同提高生产力的环境？
The structure of the two positions is outlined here for you:
这两个职位的具体结构概述如下：
CONCLUSION: The workplace should offer competitive wages.
结论：工作场所应提供有竞争力的工资。
REASON: The only basis for salary increases is productivity—therefore, this type of workplace creates optimal incentives for hard work.
原因：工资增长的唯一依据是生产力——因此，这种类型的工作场所为努力工作创造了最佳激励。
CONCLUSION: The workplace should offer a team environment.
结论：工作场所应提供团队合作环境。
Reason: If the staff respects each other, they create an environment that can be healthy and effectively productive.
原因：如果员工互相尊重，就能创造一个健康高效的工作环境。

Notice that the work environment where wages are based on individual productivity values competition. Those who organize that kind of environment believe that competition would create more productivity because it motivates the individual. Thus, they contend that a team environment would get in the way of the productivity of the competitive environment.

值得注意的是，以个人生产力为基础的工资环境重视竞争。营造这种环境的人认为，竞争能够激励个人，从而提高生产力。因此，他们认为团队环境会阻碍竞争环境的生产力。

VALUE ASSUMPTION: In this context, competition is valued over cooperation.
价值假设：在这种背景下，竞争比合作更受重视。

On the other hand, those who think the team environment would be the most productive value cooperation. They believe that working together helps the group become motivated to be more productive, not just for themselves, but for the company (the team). They think that the group work would create a better working environment than one that offered competitive wages.

另一方面，那些认为团队合作环境最高效的人重视合作。他们相信，共同协作能激发团队成员的积极性，从而提高生产力，这不仅对个人有益，对公司（团队）也同样重要。他们认为，团队合作比单纯提供高薪更能创造良好的工作环境。

VALUE ASSUMPTION: In this situation, cooperation is valued over competition.
价值假设：在这种情况下，合作比竞争更有价值。

Therefore, the major value conflict is cooperation versus competition. A supporter of the competitive wage environment believes the value assumption that competition, rather than cooperation, among co-workers over pay will create the most productive environment. Her stance on this issue does not mean that she does not value cooperation; both values are probably very important to her. In the instance of the work place, however, competition has taken over.

因此，主要的价值观冲突在于合作与竞争。支持竞争性薪酬环境的人认为，同事之间围绕薪酬展开的竞争而非合作，能够创造最高效的工作环境。她对此问题的立场并不意味着她不重视合作；对她而言，这两种价值观可能都非常重要。然而，在工作场所，竞争已经占据了主导地位。

Remember that complete reasoning with respect to prescriptive issues requires reasons and value assumptions. Let's complete one more example together.

请记住，对于规范性问题，完整的推理需要理由和价值假设。让我们一起完成另一个例子。

Let's complete one more example together.

我们一起来完成最后一个例子。

Public libraries should not ban certain books. Some books are not considered to be politically correct or are considered offensive and therefore not supported by the public library system here. But their policy is hampering people's access to certain types of literature from a significant public source.
公共图书馆不应该禁书。有些书籍被认为不符合政治正确，或者具有冒犯性，因此不被本地公共图书馆系统所支持。但他们的政策阻碍了人们从重要的公共资源中获取某些类型的文学作品。
Let's first outline the structure of the argument.
我们先来概述一下论证的结构。
CONCLUSION: Libraries should not ban certain books.
结论：图书馆不应该禁阅某些书籍。
REASON: People should have easy access to books of their choice at public libraries.
理由：人们应该能够方便地在公共图书馆借阅自己喜欢的书籍。

What value assumption do you think would result in someone's opposition to book bans? Look back at the table on page 60. Would any of the sample value conflicts affect one's reaction to the consoling of certain books and the use of the above reasoning? Try to explain how a preference for freedom of speech over order might affect your reaction to this controversy.

你认为什么样的价值观假设会导致人们反对禁书？回顾第60页的表格。表格中列举的价值观冲突是否会影响人们对某些书籍的禁售以及上述推理方式的反应？试着解释一下，如果人们更倾向于言论自由而非社会秩序，会如何影响他们对这场争议的反应。

USING THIS CRITICAL QUESTION

利用这个关键问题

Once you have found a value assumption, what do you do with it? First, recall the purpose of every critical question—to move you toward the evaluation of reasoning! Because you know that thoughtful people have different value assumptions, you have the right to wonder why any single value assumption is being made. Thus, as a critical thinker, you would want to point out the need for anyone who is making an argument to offer some explanation for why you should accept the particular value assumption that is implicit in that argument.

一旦你发现了一个价值假设，该如何处理它呢？首先，要记住所有批判性问题的目的——引导你对论证进行评估！因为你知道，有思想的人会持有不同的价值假设，所以你有权质疑任何特定价值假设背后的原因。因此，作为一名批判性思考者，你应该指出，任何提出论点的人都需要解释为什么你应该接受该论点中隐含的价值假设。

Values and Relativism

价值观与相对主义

We do not want to give the impression in this chapter that value preferences are like ice cream, such that when I choose blueberry cheesecake as my flavor, you have no basis for trying to persuade me that the lemon chiffon is a better choice. Ice cream is just a matter of personal preference—end of story!

本章我们不想给人留下这样的印象：价值偏好就像冰淇淋一样，如果我选择蓝莓芝士蛋糕口味，你就没有任何理由试图说服我柠檬戚风冰淇淋是更好的选择。冰淇淋的选择纯粹是个人喜好——仅此而已！

However, the choice of value preferences requires reasoning. That reasoning, like any other, can be informed, thoughtful, and caring. But it can also be sloppy and self-absorbed. Hence, value preferences require some justification that critical thinkers can consider. A value preference requires supporting reasons just as does any other conclusion. Then each of us can study the reasoning to form our own reaction.

然而，价值偏好的选择需要推理。这种推理，如同其他任何推理一样，可以是经过深思熟虑、考虑周全的，也可以是草率的、以自我为中心的。因此，价值偏好需要一些批判性思考者可以审视的理由。价值偏好需要像其他任何结论一样，有理由支撑。然后，我们每个人都可以研究这些推理，从而形成自己的反应。

Summary

概括

Assumptions are unstated ideas, taken for granted in the reasoning. Within the context of social controversies, they consist of a preference for one value over another in a particular context. The author's background, reaction to projected consequences of acting on a particular value assumption, analogous controversies, and reverse role-playing all provide possible clues for finding a person's value assumptions in a particular controversy.

假设是指推理过程中未明确表达、被视为理所当然的观点。在社会争议中，假设指的是在特定情境下对某种价值的偏好。作者的背景、对基于特定价值假设采取行动的预期后果的反应、类似的争议以及反向角色扮演，都可能为探究某人在特定争议中的价值假设提供线索。

Practice Exercises

练习题

Critical Question: What are the value conflicts and assumptions?
关键问题：存在哪些价值冲突和假设？

Identify the value conflicts that could lead to agreement or disagreement with the following points of view; then identify the value priorities assumed by the writer.

找出可能导致同意或不同意以下观点的价值冲突；然后找出作者所秉持的价值优先顺序。

Passage 1
第一段
Sometimes it is not always best to be completely honest. Some conclusions are better left unsaid. For instance, if you are talking to a friend and he asks for your opinion about something, the truth should be avoided if there is no way to deliver it without harming the relationship.
有时候，完全坦诚并非总是最佳选择。有些结论最好还是不说。例如，如果你和朋友聊天，他征求你对某件事的看法，如果实在无法在不损害彼此关系的情况下说出真相，那就应该避免说出真相。
The truth is not always necessary. If you were a doctor and you had to give your patient bad health news, then it is important to maintain honesty. However sometimes, in the case of friendship, the honesty may need some buffering.
并非总是需要说实话。如果你是一名医生，必须告知病人坏消息，那么保持诚实至关重要。然而，在友谊中，有时诚实可能需要一些缓冲。
Passage 2
第二段
Graffiti should be considered art. It seems that a lot of people associate graffiti with gang related activities, but that linkage is not always true. Graffiti is an expression of art, just as any other work by recognized artists: the canvas is just different. When graffiti damages property there is a problem, but if there were designated places for this art, then the people who are creating it would be less likely to deface the property of others.
涂鸦应该被视为一种艺术。很多人似乎将涂鸦与帮派活动联系起来，但这种联系并非总是正确的。涂鸦是一种艺术表达形式，就像其他任何知名艺术家的作品一样：只不过创作的载体不同而已。当涂鸦损坏他人财产时，这当然是个问题，但如果设立专门的涂鸦场所，那么创作者破坏他人财产的可能性就会降低。
Passage 3
第三段
Eating healthy is important. Doctors and physical fitness advisors tell you about all the advantages of health foods. Then why are these foods so expensive? Companies selling these foods are raising prices for simple things such as fruits and vegetables. Six dollars for a bag of salad should be an indicator that the prices are too high. People want to be healthy, but it seems as if corporate America really does not want to make that prospect cheap. You should avoid wasting money just to eat healthy; go buy those cheap frozen vegetables at the grocery store!
健康饮食很重要。医生和健身顾问都会告诉你健康食品的种种好处。那么，为什么这些食品这么贵呢？销售这些食品的公司正在提高水果蔬菜等简单商品的价格。一袋沙拉要六美元，这足以说明价格过高。人们都想健康饮食，但美国企业似乎并不想让健康饮食变得便宜。你不应该为了健康饮食而浪费钱；去超市买那些便宜的冷冻蔬菜吧！

Sample Responses

示例回复

Passage 1
第一段
CONCLUSION: Lying to spare someone's feelings is appropriate in certain situations.
结论：在某些情况下，为了顾及他人的感受而撒谎是合适的。
REASON: Telling the truth could harm a friendship.
原因：说出真相可能会损害友谊。

One value conflict that relates to this argument is that between honesty and harmony. Of course, others would argue that honesty is the best foundation for the kind of friendship they seek. A value preference for harmony over honesty links the reason to the conclusion.

与此论点相关的一个价值冲突是诚实与和谐之间的冲突。当然，也有人会认为诚实是他们所追求的那种友谊的最佳基础。对和谐而非诚实的价值偏好将论证的理由与结论联系起来。

As with most prescriptive controversies, more than one value conflict is involved in this dilemma. For example, this controversy also requires us to think about comfort over courage.

如同大多数规范性争议一样，这一困境涉及不止一种价值冲突。例如，这场争议也要求我们思考舒适与勇气之间的权衡。

Passage 2
第二段
CONCLUSION: Graffiti should be treated as an art form.
结论：涂鸦应该被视为一种艺术形式。
REASONS: 1. Graffiti is not always gang related; there are other motivators.2. Graffiti is an artist's expression, just not on a traditional canvas.
原因：1. 涂鸦并不总是与帮派有关；还有其他动机。2. 涂鸦是艺术家的一种表达方式，只不过不是在传统的画布上。

A value assumption is that of freedom of expression over order. The author believes that graffiti does not unduly harm the public. If one valued order over freedom of expression, one might well reject the reasoning suggested in this passage.

这里存在一种价值假设，即言论自由高于秩序。作者认为涂鸦不会对公众造成过度的伤害。如果一个人重视秩序而非言论自由，那么他很可能会否定这段文字中提出的论点。

CRITICAL QUESTION SUMMARY: WHY THIS QUESTION IS IMPORTANT

关键问题总结：为什么这个问题很重要

What Are the Value Conflicts and Assumptions?

价值冲突和假设是什么？

While an author usually offers explicit reasons why she comes to a certain conclusion, she also makes certain assumptions that lead her to a certain conclusion. By identifying value conflicts, you determine whether the author's value preferences match your value preferences. Consequently, you have a tool for determining whether you will accept or reject an author's conclusion.

作者通常会给出明确的理由来解释她得出某个结论的原因，但她也会做出一些假设来引导她得出该结论。通过识别价值冲突，你可以判断作者的价值偏好是否与你的价值偏好相符。因此，你可以利用这一工具来决定是否接受作者的结论。

#↩

CHAPTER 6 What Are the Descriptive Assumptions?

第六章 描述性假设是什么？

You should now be able to identify value assumptions—very important hidden components of prescriptive arguments. When you find value assumptions, you know pretty well what a writer or speaker wants the world to be like—what goals she thinks are most important. But you do not know what she takes for granted about the nature of the world and the people who inhabit it. Are they basically lazy or achievement oriented, cooperative or competitive, and rational or whimsical? Her visible reasoning depends on these ideas, as well as upon her values. Such unstated ideas are descriptive assumptions, and they too are essential hidden elements of an argument.

现在你应该能够识别价值假设——规范性论证中非常重要的隐藏组成部分。当你发现价值假设时，你就能大致了解作者或演讲者希望世界是什么样子——她认为最重要的目标是什么。但你并不知道她对世界的本质以及生活在其中的人们有哪些想当然的假设。他们本质上是懒惰的还是追求成就的？是合作的还是竞争的？是理性的还是随性的？她显而易见的推理依赖于这些观念以及她的价值观。这些未明言的观念就是描述性假设，它们也是论证中不可或缺的隐藏要素。

The following brief argument about a car depends on hidden assumptions. Can you find them?

以下关于汽车的简短论证基于一些隐藏的假设。你能找到这些假设吗？

This car will get you to your destination, whatever it may be. I have driven this model of car on multiple occasions.
无论目的地是哪里，这辆车都能把你送到。我曾多次驾驶过这款车型。

This chapter focuses on the identification of descriptive assumptions, > Critical Question : What are the descriptive assumptions?

本章重点讨论描述性假设的识别，> 关键问题：描述性假设是什么？

Descriptive assumptions are beliefs about the way the world is; prescriptive or value assumptions, you remember, are beliefs about how the world should be.

描述性假设是关于世界现状的信念；规范性或价值假设，你还记得吗，是关于世界应该如何的信念。

Illustrating Descriptive Assumptions

说明描述性假设

Let's examine our argument about the car to illustrate more clearly what we mean by a descriptive assumption.

让我们审视一下关于汽车的论点，以便更清楚地说明描述性假设的含义。

The reasoning structure is:
推理结构如下：
CONCLUSION: This particular car will get you where you want to go.
结论：这辆车能带你去你想去的地方。
REASON: This model of car has functioned well on multiple occasions.
原因：这款车型在多次使用中表现良好。

The reasoning thus far is incomplete. We know that, by itself a reason just does not have the strength to support a conclusion; the reason must be connected to the conclusion by certain other (frequently unstated) ideas. These ideas, if true, justify treating the reason as support for the conclusion. Thus, whether a reason supports, or is relevant to, a conclusion depends on whether we can locate unstated ideas that logically connect the reason to the conclusion. When such unstated ideas are descriptive, we call them descriptive assumptions. Let us present two such assumptions for the above argument.

目前的论证并不完整。我们知道，理由本身并不足以支撑结论；理由必须通过某些其他（通常是未明确表达的）观点与结论联系起来。如果这些观点为真，就能证明该理由可以作为结论的支撑。因此，一个理由是否支持结论，或者是否与结论相关，取决于我们能否找到那些逻辑上将该理由与结论联系起来的未明确表达的观点。当这些未明确表达的观点是描述性的时，我们称之为描述性假设。下面我们为上述论证提出两个这样的假设。

ASSUMPTION 1: From year to year a particular model of car has a consistent quality.
假设 1：某一款车型的汽车每年都具有一致的质量。

First, no such statement was provided in the argument itself. However, if the reason is true and if this assumption is true, then the reason provides some support for the conclusion. But if not all model years have the same level of dependability (and we know they do not), then experience with a model in previous years cannot be a reliable guide to whether one should buy the car in the current model year. Note that this assumption is a statement about the way things are, not about the way things should be. Thus, it is a descriptive connecting assumption.

首先，论证本身并未提供这样的陈述。然而，如果理由成立，且该假设成立，那么理由确实为结论提供了一定的支持。但如果并非所有年份的车型都具有相同的可靠性（我们知道事实并非如此），那么以往年份车型的使用经验就不能作为判断是否应该购买当前年份车型的可靠依据。请注意，该假设是对现状的陈述，而非对理想状态的描述。因此，它是一个描述性的连接性假设。

ASSUMPTION 2: The driving that would be done with the new car is the same kind of driving that was done by the person recommending the car.
假设 2：新车的驾驶方式与推荐这辆车的人的驾驶方式相同。

When we speak about "driving" a car, the ambiguity of driving can get us into trouble if we do not clarify the term. If the "driving" of the person recommending the car refers to regular trips to the grocery store on a quiet suburban street with no hills, that driving experience is not very relevant as a comparator when the new car is to be driven in Colorado, while pulling a heavy trailer. Thus, this conclusion is supported by the reason only if a certain definition of driving is assumed.

当我们谈论“驾驶”汽车时，如果不加以明确定义，驾驶一词的歧义性可能会给我们带来麻烦。如果推荐人所说的“驾驶”是指在郊区平坦安静的街道上定期去杂货店购物，那么当新车要在科罗拉多州拖着重型拖车行驶时，这种驾驶经验作为比较标准就显得不太恰当了。因此，只有对“驾驶”一词做出明确的定义，这个结论才能得到合理的解释。

We can call this kind of descriptive assumption a definitional assumption because we have taken for granted one meaning of a term that could have more than one meaning. Thus, one important kind of descriptive assumption to look for is a definitional assumption —the taking for granted of one meaning

我们可以将这种描述性假设称为定义性假设，因为我们想当然地认为某个术语只有一种含义，而它实际上可能有多种含义。因此，需要注意的一种重要的描述性假设就是定义性假设——即想当然地认为某个术语只有一种含义。

for a term that has multiple possible meanings. Let's see what this process looks like in argument form:

对于一个有多种可能含义的术语，让我们看看这个过程在论证形式中是如何体现的：

Once you have identified the connecting assumptions, you have answered the question, "On what basis can that conclusion be drawn from that reason?" The next natural step is to ask, "Is there any basis for accepting the assumptions?" If not, then, for you, the reason fails to provide support for the conclusion. If so, then the reason provides logical support for the conclusion. Thus, you can say reasoning is sound when you have identified connecting assumptions and you have good reason to believe those assumptions.

一旦你确定了相互关联的假设，你就回答了“基于什么理由可以得出这个结论？”这个问题。接下来自然而然地会问：“是否有任何理由接受这些假设？”如果没有，那么对你而言，这个理由就无法为结论提供支持。如果有，那么这个理由就为结论提供了逻辑支持。因此，当你确定了相互关联的假设，并且有充分的理由相信这些假设时，你就可以说你的推理是合理的。

Attention : A descriptive assumption is an unstated belief about how the world was, is, or will become.
注意：描述性假设是对世界过去、现在或将来如何的未明言的信念。

When you identify assumptions, you identify ideas the communicator needs to take for granted so that the reason is supportive of the conclusion. Because writers and speakers frequently are not aware of their own assumptions, their conscious beliefs may be quite different from the ideas you identify as implicit assumptions. When you then make the hidden connecting tissue of an argument visible, you also contribute to their understanding of their own argument and may thereby guide them to better beliefs and decisions.

当你识别出假设时，你实际上是在指出沟通者为了支撑结论而必须默认接受的观点。由于作者和演讲者常常意识不到自身的假设，他们有意识的信念可能与你识别出的隐含假设大相径庭。当你揭示论证中隐藏的内在联系时，你也有助于他们理解自身的论证，从而引导他们形成更合理的信念和决策。

USING THIS CRITICAL QUESTION

利用这个关键问题

After you have found descriptive assumptions, you want to think about whether there is a strong basis for accepting them. It is certainly fair for you to expect the person making the argument to provide you with some justification for why you should accept these particular assumptions. Finally, if the assumption is not supported and you find it questionable, you are behaving responsibly when you decide not to buy the argument. Your point in rejecting it is not to disagree with the conclusion. Instead, you are saying that you cannot accept the conclusion based on the reasons offered so far. In other words, you are quite willing to believe what you are being told, but as a critical thinker you are in the business of personal development. That development can take place only when you accept only those conclusions that have persuasive reasons.

在找到描述性假设之后，你需要思考这些假设是否有充分的理由被接受。你当然有理由期望提出论点的人提供一些理由，解释你为何应该接受这些假设。最后，如果假设缺乏依据，且你对其存疑，那么当你决定不接受该论点时，你的行为是负责任的。你拒绝它的目的并非反对结论，而是表明你无法基于目前提供的理由接受该结论。换句话说，你其实很愿意相信别人告诉你的内容，但作为一名批判性思考者，你致力于个人发展。而这种发展只有在你只接受那些有充分理由的结论时才能实现。

Clues for Locating Assumptions

寻找假设的线索

Your task in finding assumptions is to reconstruct the reasoning by filling in the missing links. You want to provide ideas that help the communicator's reasoning "make sense." Once you have a picture of the entire argument, both the visible and the invisible parts, you will be in a much better position to determine its strengths and weaknesses.

你的任务是找出假设，通过填补缺失的环节来重构推理过程。你需要提供一些思路，帮助理解沟通者的推理是否“合情合理”。一旦你掌握了整个论证的全貌，包括显性和隐性部分，你就能更好地判断其优缺点。

How does one go about finding these important missing links? It requires hard work, imagination, and creativity. Finding important assumptions is a difficult task.

如何找到这些重要的缺失环节？这需要付出艰辛的努力、丰富的想象力和创造力。找到重要的假设是一项艰巨的任务。

You have been introduced to two types of assumptions—value assumptions and descriptive assumptions. In the previous chapter, we gave you several hints for finding value assumptions. Here are some clues that will make your search for descriptive assumptions successful.

您已经了解了两种类型的假设——价值假设和描述性假设。在前一章中，我们给出了一些寻找价值假设的提示。以下是一些能帮助您成功找到描述性假设的线索。

Keep thinking about the gap between the conclusion and reasons . Why are you looking for assumptions in the first place? You are looking because you want to be able to judge how well the reasons support the conclusions. Thus, look for what the writer or speaker would have had to take for granted to link the reasons and conclusion. Keep asking, "How do you get from the reason to the conclusion?" Ask, 11 If the reason is true, what else must be true for the conclusion to follow?" And, to help answer that question, you will find it very helpful to ask, _"Supposing the reason(s) were true, is there any way in which the conclusion nevertheless could be false!?"

持续思考结论与理由之间的差距。你为什么要寻找假设呢？因为你想判断理由对结论的支持力度。因此，要寻找作者或发言者为了将理由和结论联系起来而必须假定的前提。不断追问：“你是如何从理由推导出结论的？” 问问自己：“如果理由为真，那么为了使结论成立，还必须有哪些前提成立？” 为了更好地回答这个问题，你会发现问自己“假设理由为真，结论是否仍然可能为假？”会很有帮助。

Searching for the gap will be helpful for finding both value and descriptive assumptions.

寻找差距有助于发现价值假设和描述性假设。

Look for ideas that support reasons. Sometimes a reason is presented with no explicit support; yet the plausibility of the reason depends on the acceptability of ideas that have been taken for granted. These ideas are descriptive assumptions. The following brief argument illustrates such a case:

寻找能够支撑论点的观点。有时，论点本身并没有明确的论据支持；然而，论点的合理性取决于一些被认为是理所当然的观点是否被接受。这些观点属于描述性假设。以下简短的论证就说明了这种情况：

CONCLUSION: All high-school English classes will go see at least one Shakespeare play.
结论：所有高中英语课都将至少观看一部莎士比亚戏剧。
REASON: It is beneficial to experience Shakespeare's works first hand.
原因：亲身体验莎士比亚的作品是有益的。

What ideas must be taken for granted for this reason to be acceptable? We must assume:

为了使这种观点被接受，哪些观念必须被视为理所当然？我们必须假设：

(a) The performance will be well done and reflective of what Shakespeare would encourage, and
（a）演出将会非常精彩，并体现莎士比亚所鼓励的风格，而且
(b) students will understand the play and be able to relate it to Shakespeare.
（b）学生将理解该剧，并能将其与莎士比亚联系起来。

Both (a) and (b) are ideas that have to be taken for granted for the reasons to be acceptable and, thus, supportive of the conclusion.

（a）和（b）都是必须被视为理所当然的想法，其理由才能被接受，从而支持结论。

Identify with the writer or speaker. Locating someone's assumptions is often made easier by imagining that you were asked to defend the conclusion. If you can, crawl into the skin of a person who would reach such a conclusion. Discover his background. Whether the person whose conclusion you are evaluating is a corporate executive, a labor leader, a boxing promoter, or a judge, try to play the role of such a person and plan in your mind what he would be thinking as he moves toward the conclusion. When an executive for a coal company argues that strip mining does not significantly harm the beauty of our natural environment, he has probably begun with a belief that strip mining is beneficial to our nation. Thus, he may assume a definition of beauty that would be consistent with his arguments, while other definitions of beauty would lead to a condemnation of strip mining.

设身处地地与作者或发言者对话。想象自己被要求为某个结论辩护，往往能更容易地找到对方的假设。如果可以，试着设身处地地站在得出该结论的人的角度思考。了解他的背景。无论你评估结论的人是企业高管、工会领袖、拳击推广人还是法官，都要尝试扮演这样的角色，并在脑海中设想他在得出结论的过程中会如何思考。例如，当一家煤炭公司的高管辩称露天采矿不会对自然环境造成显著破坏时，他很可能一开始就认为露天采矿对国家有益。因此，他可能预设了一种与他的论点相符的“美”的定义，而其他对“美”的定义则会导致对露天采矿的谴责。

Identify with the opposition. If you are unable to locate assumptions by taking the role of the speaker or writer, try to reverse roles. Ask yourself why anyone might disagree with the conclusion. What type of reasoning would prompt someone to disagree with the conclusion you are evaluating? If you can play the role of a person who would not accept the conclusion, you can more readily see assumptions in the explicit structure of the argument.

设身处地地站在反对者的角度思考。如果你无法通过扮演发言者或作者的角色来发现其中的假设，那就尝试角色互换。问问自己，为什么有人会反对这个结论？什么样的推理会促使人们反对你正在评估的结论？如果你能扮演一个不接受这个结论的人，你就能更容易地在论证的显性结构中发现假设。

Recognize the potential existence of other means of attaining the advantages referred to in the reasons. Frequently, a conclusion is supported by reasons that indicate the various advantages of acting on the author's conclusion. When there are many ways to reach the same advantages, one important assumption linking the reasons to the conclusion is that the best way to attain the advantages is through the one advocated by the communicator.

要认识到可能存在其他途径来实现理由中提及的优势。通常，结论会得到理由的支持，这些理由表明了采取该结论行动的各种优势。当有多种途径可以达到相同的优势时，将理由与结论联系起来的一个重要假设是：实现这些优势的最佳途径是传播者所倡导的途径。

Let's try this technique with one brief example. Experts disagree about how a person should establish financial stability. Many times young people are encouraged to establish credit with a credit card. But aren't there many ways to establish financial stability? Might not some of these alternatives have less serious disadvantages than those that could result when a young person spends too much on that credit card? For example, investing some money in a savings account or establishing credit by maintaining a checking account are viable routes to establishing financial stability. Thus, those who suggest that people get credit cards to help establish financial stability are not taking into account the risks involved with their solution or the possibility of fewer risks with an alternative.

让我们用一个简单的例子来尝试一下这种方法。专家们对于如何建立财务稳定存在分歧。很多时候，年轻人被鼓励通过信用卡来建立信用。但是，难道就没有其他建立财务稳定的方法吗？难道这些替代方案的弊端不比年轻人过度使用信用卡可能带来的后果要小吗？例如，将部分资金存入储蓄账户或通过持有支票账户来建立信用都是建立财务稳定的可行途径。因此，那些建议人们通过信用卡来建立财务稳定的人，并没有考虑到这种方案存在的风险，也没有考虑到其他风险更小的替代方案。

Avoid stating incompletely established reasons as assumptions . When you first attempt to locate assumptions you may find yourself locating a stated reason, thinking that the reason has not been adequately established, and asserting, "That's only an assumption. You don't know that to be the case." Or you might simply restate the reason as the assumption. You may have correctly identified a need on the part of the writer or speaker to better establish the truth of her reason. While this clarification is an important insight on your part, you have not identified an assumption in the sense that we have been using it in these two chapters. You are simply labeling a reason "an assumption."

避免将尚未完全证实的理由当作假设。当你初次尝试寻找假设时，你可能会发现某个已陈述的理由，但认为该理由尚未得到充分证实，于是断言：“这只是一个假设。你并不知道事实是否如此。”或者，你可能只是简单地将该理由重新表述为假设。你或许正确地指出了作者或发言者需要更好地证实其理由的正确性。虽然你的这种澄清很有见地，但你并没有按照我们在前两章中对“假设”的定义来识别它。你只是将某个理由贴上了“假设”的标签。

Here is an example of stating an incompletely established reason as an assumption.

以下是一个将未经充分证实的理由作为假设的例子。

The ratings are going through the roof for Science Fiction shows. The advertising agencies have done a great job.
科幻剧的收视率一路飙升。广告公司干得漂亮！

Now, challenge the argument by identifying the following assumption: The writer is assuming that advertising is causing the ratings to rise.

现在，请通过指出以下假设来质疑该论点：作者假设广告导致收视率上升。

Do you see that when you do this, all you are doing is stating that the author's reason is her assumption—when what you are probably really trying to stress is that the author's reason has not been sufficiently established by evidence.

你难道没意识到，当你这样做的时候，你实际上是在说作者的理由是她的假设——而你真正想强调的可能是，作者的理由还没有得到充分的证据证明。

Applying the Clues

运用线索

Let's look at an argument about the importance of planning and see whether we can identify descriptive and value assumptions.

让我们来看一个关于规划重要性的论点，看看我们能否找出描述性假设和价值假设。

Planning is a valuable tool. Students need to be taught how to budget time and write down tasks. The best way to show college students how helpful careful planning can be for them is to require them to use a planner. Given the average course load that students take, they will have a difficult time remembering all of their assignments. Unlike high school, colleges do not have concerned adults who will remind them about assignments or ask them whether they have done their homework before they go out. Requiring the use of a planner will help students become the goal-oriented students that every college professor wants to have in his classroom. Such a requirement will not only help students tremendously, but will also create a more successful college environment for everyone involved.
计划是一项宝贵的工具。学生需要学习如何合理安排时间并记录任务。向大学生展示周密计划的益处的最佳方式是要求他们使用计划表。考虑到大学生的平均课程负担，他们很难记住所有的作业。与高中不同，大学里没有关心他们的成年人会提醒他们作业，或者在他们外出前询问他们是否完成了作业。要求使用计划表将有助于学生成为每位大学教授都希望在课堂上遇到的目标导向型学生。这样的要求不仅对学生大有裨益，还能为所有相关人员创造一个更成功的大学环境。
CONCLUSION Planning should be a requirement for students, and the best way to accomplish this goal is to require than to use a planner .
结论：规划应该是学生的一项基本要求，而实现这一目标的最佳方法是要求学生使用规划工具。
REASONS: 1. Students out of high school are not ready or independent enough to for classes—planning can change that. 2. Students will become goal-oriented.
原因：1. 高中毕业的学生尚未做好充分准备或具备足够的独立性来适应课程——制定计划可以改变这种情况。2. 学生将变得更加目标明确。

First, note that the author provides no "proof' for her reasons. Thus, you might be tempted to state, "Those reasons are only assumptions; she does not know that." Wrong! They are not assumptions! Remember: identifying less-than-fully established reasons, though important, is not the same as identifying assumptions—ideas that are taken for granted as a basic part of the argument.

首先，请注意作者并未提供任何“证据”来支持她的理由。因此，你可能会想：“这些理由只是假设；她并不知道这一点。” 错！它们并非假设！记住：识别尚未完全确立的理由固然重要，但这与识别假设——那些被视为论证基本组成部分的理所当然的观点——截然不同。

Now, let's see whether any descriptive assumptions can be found in the argument. Remember to keep thinking about the gap between the conclusion and the reasons as you look. First, ask yourself, "Is there any basis for believing that the reason(s) might not be true?" Then ask, "Supposing the reason(s) were true, is there any way in which the conclusion nevertheless could be false?" Try to play the role of a person who does not believe a planner should be a requirement.

现在，让我们看看论证中是否存在任何描述性假设。在分析过程中，请记住要不断思考结论与理由之间的差距。首先，问问自己：“是否有任何理由认为这些理由可能不成立？” 然后问：“假设这些理由成立，结论仍然可能为假吗？” 试着扮演一个不认为规划师是必要条件的人的角色。

Look at the two reasons. The first would be true if it were the case that the students being described are independent learners. This author is assuming that no such ability to take initiative for one's own academic success exists. How can she know such a thing? Perhaps forcing students to plan would only cause the students to have another disorderly thing to do. Thus, one descriptive assumption is that students cannot learn to become responsible learners independently.

看看这两个理由。第一个理由成立的前提是，文中描述的学生都是独立学习者。但作者假定学生不具备主动学习的能力。她怎么知道这一点呢？或许强迫学生制定学习计划只会让他们更加无所事事。因此，作者的一个描述性假设是，学生无法学会独立自主地学习。

Let's now suppose that the second reason is true. Planning still might not be useful to the student. Just because the author believes in the value of planning does not mean that it will change the lives or the study habits of students. Thus, an assumption connecting the first reason to the conclusion is that students will learn how to plan and then will implement that strategy later . This assumption also links with the second reason closely.

现在假设第二个理由成立。即便如此，制定计划对学生来说可能仍然没有用。作者相信计划的价值，并不意味着它就能改变学生的生活或学习习惯。因此，第一个理由与结论之间的一个假设是：学生会学习如何制定计划，然后之后会运用这些策略。这个假设也与第二个理由密切相关。

Consider the second reason. It is true only if the student not only absorbs the ideas of planning, but also uses them. The author is also assuming that the ideas learned through planning will then lead to a goal-oriented lifestyle. Another important assumption is that students will change their learning styles after mastering the concepts of planning.

考虑第二个原因。这只有在学生不仅吸收了计划的概念，而且还能运用它们的情况下才成立。作者还假设，通过计划学习到的理念将引导学生养成目标导向的生活方式。另一个重要的假设是，学生在掌握计划的概念后会改变他们的学习方式。

Note also that there is a prescriptive quality to this essay; thus, important value assumptions underlie the reasoning. What is the author concerned about preserving? Try reverse role-playing. What would someone who disagreed with this position care about? What are the disadvantages to forcing students to plan? Your answers to these questions should lead you to the essay's value preference. For example, can you see how a preference for orderliness over independence links the reasons to the conclusion?

还要注意的是，这篇文章具有指导性；因此，其论证背后存在重要的价值假设。作者究竟想要维护什么？不妨反向思考一下。如果有人不同意这种观点，他们会关心什么？强制学生制定计划有哪些弊端？你对这些问题的回答应该能引导你理解文章的价值取向。例如，你能否看出，对秩序而非独立的偏好是如何将论证与结论联系起来的？

Avoiding Analysis of Trivial Assumptions

避免分析琐碎的假设

Writers and speakers take for granted, and should take for granted, certain self-evident things. You will want to devote your energy to evaluating important assumptions, so we want to warn you about some potential trivial assumptions. By trivial, we mean an assumption that is self-evident.

作者和演讲者往往会想当然地认为某些不言自明的事情是理所当然的，而且也应该如此认为。您需要将精力投入到评估重要假设上，因此我们想提醒您注意一些可能被忽略的假设。所谓“忽略”，指的是那些不言自明的假设。

You as a reader or listener can assume that the communicator believes his reasons are true. You may want to attack the reasons as insufficient, but it is trivial to point out the writer's or speaker's assumption that the reasons are true.

作为读者或听众，你可以假定说话者相信他所提出的理由是正确的。你或许会质疑这些理由的充分性，但指出作者或说话者假定这些理由是正确的，却是轻而易举的事。

Another type of trivial assumption concerns the reasoning structure. You may be tempted to state that the writer believes that the reason and conclusion are logically related. Right—but trivial. What is important is how they are logically related. It is also trivial to point out that an argument assumes that we can understand the logic, that we can understand the terminology, or that we have the appropriate background knowledge.

另一种常见的假设与推理结构有关。你或许会认为作者相信理由和结论在逻辑上是相关的。没错——但这无关紧要。重要的是它们在逻辑上是如何关联的。同样，指出某个论证假设我们能够理解其逻辑、理解其术语或具备相应的背景知识，也是无关紧要的。

Avoid spending time on analyzing trivial assumptions. Your search for assumptions will be most rewarding when you locate hidden, debatable missing links.

避免把时间浪费在分析无关紧要的假设上。当你找到那些隐藏的、值得商榷的缺失环节时，你对假设的探寻才会最有价值。

Assumptions and Your Own Writing and Speaking

假设以及你自己的写作和演讲

When you attempt to communicate with an audience, either by writing or speaking, you will be making numerous assumptions. Communication requires them. But, once again out of respect for your audience, you should acknowledge those assumptions, and, where possible, provide a rationale for why you are making those particular assumptions.

当你尝试与听众沟通时，无论是写作还是演讲，你都会做出许多假设。沟通离不开这些假设。但是，出于对听众的尊重，你应该承认这些假设，并在可能的情况下，解释你做出这些假设的理由。

The logic of this approach on your part is to assist the audience in accepting your argument. You are being open and fair with them. An audience should appreciate your willingness to present your argument in its fullness.

你这样做的逻辑在于帮助听众接受你的论点。你对他们坦诚相待，公平公正。听众应该会欣赏你愿意完整地阐述你的论点。

Summary

概括

Assumptions are ideas that, if true, enable us to claim that particular reasons provide support for a conclusion.

假设是指如果为真，就可以声称特定理由支持某个结论的想法。

Clues for Discovering Descriptive Assumptions

发现描述性假设的线索

  1. Keep thinking about the gap between the conclusion and reasons.
    不断思考结论与理由之间的差距。
  2. Look for ideas that support reasons.
    寻找能够佐证理由的观点。
  3. Identify with the opposition.
    认同反对派的观点。
  4. Recognize the potential existence of other means of attaining the advantages referred to in the reasons.
    认识到可能存在其他途径来实现理由中所述的优势。
  5. Learn more about the issues.
    了解更多相关信息。

Practice Exercises

练习题

Critical Question : What are the descriptive assumptions?
关键问题：描述性假设是什么？

For each of the three passages, locate important assumptions made by the author. Remember first to determine the conclusion and the reasons.

对于这三段文字，找出作者做出的重要假设。记住，首先要确定结论及其理由。

Passage 1
第一段
Everyone should consider playing poker to win money. It has gained great popularity. You can see people play on television daily, and there are many opportunities to play against real people online. This trend is an exciting opportunity for people everywhere to try and win money. Poker is simple to learn after one understands the rules and concepts behind the game. It is a game that people of all ages and experience can play!
每个人都应该考虑玩扑克赢钱。扑克已经非常流行。你每天都能在电视上看到人们玩扑克，而且有很多机会可以在网上与真人玩家对战。这种趋势为世界各地的人们提供了一个令人兴奋的赢钱机会。只要理解了游戏规则和概念，扑克就很容易上手。无论年龄和经验如何，每个人都可以玩扑克！
Passage 2
第二段
Adopted children should have the right to find out who their biological parents are. They should be able to find out for personal and health reasons. Most children would want to know what happened to these people and why they were given up for adoption. Even though this meeting may not be completely the way the child had imagined it, this interaction could provide a real sense of closure for adopted children. There are people who believe that it does not matter who the biological parents are as long as the child has loving parents. It is true that having a supportive environment is necessary for children, but there will always be nagging questions for these children that will be left unanswered if they are not able to find out their biological parents. There are also health risks that can be avoided by allowing a child to find out who their parents are. A lot of diseases have hereditary links that would be useful for the child and the new family to know.
被收养的孩子应该有权知道自己的亲生父母是谁。出于个人和健康原因，他们应该能够了解这一点。大多数孩子都想知道这些人经历了什么，以及他们为什么被送养。即使这次见面可能与孩子想象中的有所不同，但这种互动可以给被收养的孩子带来一种真正的释怀感。有些人认为，只要孩子拥有充满爱的父母，亲生父母是谁并不重要。拥有一个充满支持的环境对孩子来说固然重要，但如果这些孩子无法找到自己的亲生父母，他们心中总会有一些挥之不去的疑问。此外，让孩子知道亲生父母是谁还可以避免一些健康风险。许多疾病都与遗传有关，了解这些信息对孩子和新家庭都很有帮助。
Passage 3
第三段
Recently, we have lost community members in a large fire. It only seems logical now that we start implementing fire safety presentations or courses in our schools. The last thing we want to happen is for more tragedies to occur, especially in our schools.
最近，一场大火夺去了我们社区成员的生命。现在看来，在学校开展消防安全宣讲或课程是理所当然的。我们最不希望看到的就是更多悲剧发生，尤其是在学校里。
The fire safety training will prevent this community from losing any more lives. Educational programs provide the best way to go if we are to avoid future disasters of this type.
消防安全培训将防止社区再次发生生命损失。如果我们想要避免未来再次发生此类灾难，教育项目是最佳途径。

Sample Responses

示例回复

In presenting assumptions for the following arguments, we will list only some of the assumptions being made—those which we believe are among the most significant.

在提出以下论点的假设时，我们将仅列出一些假设——我们认为其中最重要的假设。

Passage 1
第一段
CONCLUSION: Everyone should play poker to win money.
结论：人人都应该玩扑克赢钱。
REASONS: 1. It is a popular game. 2. People of all ages and experience can play.
原因：1. 这是一款热门游戏。2. 所有年龄段和经验水平的人都可以玩。

In looking at the first reason, there seems to be a missing link between that reason and the conclusion. The author omits two main assumptions. One, poker is enjoyable because many people play this game. And second, that "enjoyable" means profitable. The author needs these two assumptions for him to make the jump to the idea that we should all join the poker craze.

在审视第一个理由时，我们发现该理由与结论之间似乎存在缺失环节。作者忽略了两个主要假设。第一，扑克之所以有趣是因为很多人都在玩。第二，“有趣”意味着有利可图。作者需要这两个假设才能得出我们都应该加入扑克热潮的结论。

The second reason should leave the reader wondering whether it makes sense to assume that because something can happen, it should happen. Yes, we can all certainly play poker; we can also all start forest fires, but our capacity to do so is not exactly an endorsement of the activity.

第二个理由应该会让读者思考：仅仅因为某件事可能发生，就认为它应该发生，这种想法是否合理？没错，我们都会玩扑克；我们也会引发森林火灾，但我们有能力这样做，并不代表我们赞同这种行为。

Passage 2
第二段
CONCLUSION: Adopted children should be allowed to find their biological parents' identities.
结论：应该允许被收养的孩子寻找他们的亲生父母。
REASON: 1. Knowing ones birth parents can provide many health benefits.(Supporting Reasons)
理由：1. 了解自己的亲生父母可以带来许多健康益处。（佐证理由）
a. Psychological closure can be achieved by finding answer to enduring questions.
a. 通过找到长期存在的问题的答案，可以实现心理上的释怀。
b. Able to find out what their biological parents are like.
b. 能够了解自己的亲生父母是什么样的人。
2. Permits one to assess health risks.
2. 允许人们评估健康风险。

Try reverse role-playing, taking the position of someone who values the parents' right to privacy.

尝试反向角色扮演，扮演一个重视父母隐私权的人。

For the first reason to be true, it must be the case that the child is bothered by not knowing their biological parentage. Surely this assumption would be true for some adopted children. Is there data that suggests a widespread burning desire to know the birth parents? If so, please present the data so we can move toward agreeing with the argument. There are many reasons to think that the child may either be satisfied not knowing or may not even be aware that he is adopted. Also, for the main reason to be enhanced by the supporting reasons, we would need to assume that meeting the biological parent would not create sharp new tensions between the individual and the adoptive parent.

要使第一个理由成立，孩子必须因为不知道自己的亲生父母而感到困扰。对于一些被收养的孩子来说，这个假设当然成立。是否有数据表明，许多孩子都渴望知道亲生父母是谁？如果有，请提供数据，以便我们能够进一步支持这个论点。有很多理由表明，孩子可能乐于不知道亲生父母是谁，甚至可能根本不知道自己是被收养的。此外，为了使主要理由得到其他论据的支持，我们需要假设与亲生父母见面不会在孩子和养父母之间造成新的紧张关系。

CRITICAL QUESTION SUMMARY: WHY THIS QUESTION IS IMPORTANT

关键问题总结：为什么这个问题很重要

What Are the Descriptive Assumptions?

描述性假设是什么？

When you identify descriptive assumptions, you are identifying the link between a reason and the author's conclusion. If this link is flawed, the reason does not necessarily lead to the conclusion. Consequently, identifying the descriptive assumptions allows you to determine whether an author's reasons lead to a conclusion. You will want to accept a conclusion only when there are good reasons that lead to the conclusion. Thus, when you determine that the link between the reasons and conclusion is flawed, you will want to be reluctant to accept the author's conclusion.

当你识别描述性假设时，你实际上是在识别理由与作者结论之间的联系。如果这种联系存在缺陷，那么理由未必能得出结论。因此，识别描述性假设可以帮助你判断作者的理由是否能够得出结论。只有当结论有充分的理由支撑时，你才会接受它。所以，当你发现理由与结论之间的联系存在缺陷时，你应该谨慎对待作者的结论。

#↩

CHAPTER 7 Are There Any Fallacies in the Reasoning?

第七章 推理中是否存在谬误？

Thus far, you have been working at taking the raw materials a writer or speaker gives you and assembling them into a meaningful overall structure. You have learned ways to remove the irrelevant parts from your pan as well as how to discover the "invisible glue" that holds the relevant parts together—that is, the assumptions. All these things have been achieved by asking critical questions. Let's briefly review these questions:

到目前为止，你一直在努力将作者或演讲者提供的素材整合到一个有意义的整体结构中。你已经学会了如何剔除无关部分，以及如何发现将相关部分粘合在一起的“隐形粘合剂”——也就是假设。所有这些都是通过提出批判性问题实现的。让我们简要回顾一下这些问题：

  1. What are the issue and the conclusion?
    问题是什么？结论是什么？
  2. What are the reasons?
    原因是什么？
  3. What words or phrases are ambiguous?
    哪些词语或短语含义模糊？
  4. What are the value conflicts and assumptions?
    存在哪些价值冲突和假设？
  5. What are the descriptive assumptions?
    描述性假设是什么？

Asking these questions should give you a clear understanding of the communicator's reasoning as well as a sense of where there might be strengths and weaknesses in the argument. Most remaining chapters focus on how well the structure holds up after being assembled. Your major question now is, "How acceptable is the conclusion in light of the reasons provided?" You are now ready to make your central focus evaluation. Remember: The objective of critical reading and listening is to judge the acceptability or worth of conclusions.

提出这些问题应该能让你清楚地理解沟通者的推理过程，并了解论证中可能存在的优势和劣势。接下来的大部分章节将着重探讨结构在构建完成后是否依然成立。你现在的主要问题是：“根据所提供的理由，结论是否合理？” 现在，你可以进行核心评估了。记住：批判性阅读和聆听的目标是判断结论的合理性或价值。

While answering our first five questions has been a necessary beginning to the evaluation process, we now move to questions requiring us to make judgments more directly and explicitly about the worth or the quality of the reasoning. Our task now is to separate the "Fools Gold" from the genuine gold. We want to isolate the best reasons—those that we want to treat most seriously.

回答前五个问题是评估过程的必要开端，现在我们要转向一些需要我们更直接、更明确地判断论证价值或质量的问题。我们现在的任务是区分“愚人金”和真金。我们要找出最佳论证——那些我们最想认真对待的论证。

Your first step at this stage of the evaluation process is to examine the reasoning structure to determine whether the communicator's reasoning has depended on false or highly doubtful assumptions or has "tricked" you through either a mistake in logic or other forms of deceptive reasoning. Chapter 6 focused on finding and then thinking about the quality of assumptions. This chapter, on the other hand, highlights those reasoning "tricks" that others and we call fallacies.

评估过程的第一步是检查推理结构，以确定沟通者的推理是否依赖于错误或高度可疑的假设，或者是否通过逻辑错误或其他形式的欺骗性推理“蒙蔽”了你。第六章重点讨论了如何发现并思考假设的质量。而本章则着重阐述那些我们和其他人称之为谬误的推理“技巧”。

Three common tricks are:

三种常见的伎俩是：

  1. providing reasoning that requires erroneous or incorrect assumptions;
    提供的推理需要错误或不正确的假设；
  2. distracting us by making information seem relevant to the conclusion when it is not; and
    通过使信息看起来与结论相关（而实际上并非如此）来分散我们的注意力；
  3. providing support for the conclusion that depends on the conclusion's already being true.
    为依赖于结论本身为真的结论提供支持。

Spotting such tricks will prevent us from being unduly influenced by them. Let's see what a fallacy in reasoning looks like.

识破这些伎俩可以避免我们受其过度影响。让我们来看看推理谬误是什么样的。

Dear editor: I was shocked by your paper's support of Senator Spendall's arguments for a tax hike to increase state money available for improving highways. Of course the Senator favors such a hike. What else would you expect from a tax and spend liberal.
尊敬的编辑：我对贵报支持斯彭德尔参议员提出的增税以增加州政府用于改善公路资金的论点感到震惊。当然，这位参议员支持增税是理所当然的。毕竟，他是一位主张高税收高支出的自由派人士，还能指望他有什么别的主张呢？

Note that the letter at first appears to be presenting a "reason" to dispute the tax-hike proposal, by citing the senator's liberal reputation. But the reason is not relevant to the conclusion. The question is whether the tax hike is a good idea. The letter writer has ignored the senator's reasons and has provided no specific reasons against the tax hike; instead, she has personally attacked the senator by labeling him a "tax and spend liberal." The writer has committed a fallacy in reasoning, because her argument requires an absurd assumption to be relevant to the conclusion, and shifts attention from the argument to the arguer—Senator Spendall. An unsuspecting reader not alert to this fallacy may be tricked into thinking that the writer has provided a persuasive reason.

请注意，这封信乍看之下似乎是在以参议员的自由派形象为由，提出反对增税提案的“理由”。但这个理由与结论无关。问题的关键在于增税是否明智。写信人忽略了参议员的理由，也没有提供任何反对增税的具体理由；相反，她对参议员进行了人身攻击，称他为“高税收高支出的自由派”。写信人犯了推理谬误，因为她的论证需要一个荒谬的假设才能与结论相关，并将注意力从论证本身转移到了论证者——斯彭德尔参议员身上。不知情的读者可能会被误导，认为写信人提供了一个令人信服的理由。

This chapter gives you practice in identifying such fallacies so that you will not fall for such tricks.

本章将帮助你练习识别此类谬误，以免落入此类陷阱。

Critical Question : Are there any fallacies in the reasoning?
关键问题：这种推理是否存在谬误？
Attention : A fallacy is a reasoning "trick" that an author might use while trying to persuade you to accept a conclusion.
注意：谬误是作者在试图说服你接受某个结论时可能使用的推理“技巧”。

A Questioning Approach to Finding Reasoning Fallacies

以质疑的方式发现推理谬误

There are numerous reasoning fallacies. And they can be organized in many different ways. Many are so common that they have been given formal names. You can find many lengthy lists of fallacies in numerous texts and Web sites. Fortunately, you don't need to be aware of all the fallacies and their names to be able to locate them. If you ask yourself the right questions, you will be able to find reasoning fallacies—even if you can't name them.

推理谬误种类繁多，分类方式也多种多样。许多谬误非常常见，甚至拥有正式的名称。你可以在许多书籍和网站上找到冗长的谬误列表。幸运的是，你无需了解所有谬误及其名称就能找到它们。只要问对问题，即使你叫不出它们的名字，也能找到推理谬误。

Thus, we have adopted the strategy of emphasizing self-questioning strategies, rather than asking you to memorize an extensive list of possible kinds of fallacies. We believe, however, that knowing the names of the most common fallacies can sensitize you to fallacies and also act as a language "short cut" in communicating your reaction to faulty reasoning to others familiar with the names. Thus, we provide you with the names of fallacies as we identify the deceptive reasoning processes and encourage you to learn the names of the common fallacies described on page 98 at the end of the chapter.

因此，我们采取的策略是强调自我质疑，而不是要求你记忆一长串的谬误类型。然而，我们相信，了解最常见谬误的名称可以提高你对谬误的敏感度，也能让你在与熟悉这些名称的人交流时，更便捷地表达你对错误推理的反应。因此，我们在讲解欺骗性推理过程时会提供谬误的名称，并鼓励你学习本章末尾第98页描述的常见谬误的名称。

We have already introduced one common fallacy to you in our Dear Editor example above. We noted that the writer personally attacked Senator Spendall instead of responding directly to the senator's reasons. Seeing such an argument, the critical thinker should immediately ask, "But what about the arguments that Senator Spendall made?" The Dear Editor reasoning illustrates the Ad Hominem fallacy. The Latin phrase Ad Hominem means "against the man or against the person." There are a variety of ways of making irrelevant attacks against a person making a claim, the most common of which is attacking his character or shifting attention to his circumstances or interests. Arguing Ad Hominem is a fallacy because the character or interests of individuals making arguments usually are not relevant to the quality of the argument being made. It is attacking the messenger instead of addressing the message.

我们在上面的“致编辑的信”示例中已经向您介绍了一种常见的谬误。我们注意到，作者没有直接回应斯彭德尔参议员的理由，而是对他进行了人身攻击。看到这样的论证，批判性思考者应该立即提出疑问：“那么斯彭德尔参议员提出的论点呢？”“致编辑的信”的论证体现了人身攻击谬误。拉丁语“Ad Hominem”意为“攻击人或人格”。有很多方法可以对提出论点的人进行无关的攻击，最常见的是攻击其人格或将注意力转移到其处境或利益上。人身攻击谬误在于，提出论点的人的品格或利益通常与论点的质量无关。它攻击的是信息传递者，而不是信息本身。

Here is another brief example of Ad Hominem reasoning.

以下是人身攻击推理的另一个简短例子。

Sandy: "I believe that joining sororities is a waste of time and money."
桑迪：“我认为加入姐妹会是浪费时间和金钱。”
Julie: "Of course you would say that, you didn't get accepted by any sorority."
朱莉：“你当然会这么说，你又没被任何姐妹会录取。”
Sandy: "But what about the arguments I gave to support my position?"
桑迪：“但是我用来支持我立场的论点呢？”
Julie: "Those don't count. You're just a sore loser."
朱莉：“那些都不算数。你只是个输不起的人。”

You can start your list of fallacy names with this one. Here is the definition:

你可以从这个谬误开始列出谬误名称。以下是它的定义：

F: Ad hominem : An attack, or an insult, on the person, rather than directly addressing the person's reasons.

F：人身攻击：攻击或侮辱对方，而不是直接针对对方的理由。

Evaluating Assumptions as a Starting Point

以评估假设为起点

If you have been able to locate assumptions (see Chapters 5 and 6), especially descriptive assumptions, you already possess a major skill in determining questionable assumptions and in finding fallacies. The more questionable the assumption, the less relevant the reasoning. Some "reasons," such as Ad Hominem arguments, will be so irrelevant to the conclusion that you would have to supply blatantly erroneous assumptions to provide a logical link. Such reasoning is a fallacy, and you should immediately reject it.

如果你已经能够找到假设（参见第5章和第6章），尤其是描述性假设，那么你已经掌握了判断假设是否合理以及发现谬误的重要技能。假设越是可疑，其推理就越不相关。有些“理由”，例如人身攻击论证，与结论完全无关，以至于你必须提供明显错误的假设才能建立逻辑联系。这种推理是一种谬误，你应该立即驳斥它。

In the next section, we take you through some exercises in discovering other common fallacies. Once you know how to look, you will be able to find most fallacies. We suggest that you adopt the following thinking steps in locating fallacies:

下一节，我们将通过一些练习，帮助你发现其他常见的谬误。一旦你掌握了观察方法，就能发现大多数谬误。我们建议你采用以下思考步骤来识别谬误：

  1. Identify the conclusions and reasons.
    找出结论和理由。
  2. Always keep the conclusion in mind and consider reasons that you think might be relevant to it; contrast these reasons with the author's reasons.
    始终牢记结论，并考虑你认为可能与结论相关的理由；将这些理由与作者的理由进行对比。
  3. If the conclusion supports an action, determine whether the reason states a specific and/or concrete advantage or a disadvantage; if not, be wary!
    如果结论支持某项行动，请确定理由是否陈述了具体和/或实际的优点或缺点；如果没有，就要谨慎！
  4. Identify any necessary assumption by asking yourself, "If the reason were true, what would one have to believe for it to logically support the conclusion, and what does one have to believe for the reason to be true?"
    通过问自己以下问题来确定任何必要的假设：“如果这个理由是正确的，那么为了从逻辑上支持这个结论，人们必须相信什么？而为了使这个理由是正确的，人们必须相信什么？”
  5. Ask yourself, "Do these assumptions make sense?" If an obviously false assumption is being made, you have found a fallacy in reasoning, and that reasoning can then be rejected.
    问问自己，“这些假设合理吗？”如果存在明显错误的假设，那么你就发现了推理中的谬误，这种推理就可以被驳斥。
  6. Check the possibility of being distracted from relevant reasons by phrases that strongly appeal to your emotions.
    检查一下是否有可能因为某些强烈诉诸情感的话语而分散注意力，从而忽略真正重要的事。

To demonstrate the process you should go through to evaluate assumptions and thus recognize many fallacies, we will examine the quality of the reasoning in the following passage. We will begin by assembling the structure.

为了演示评估假设并识别多种谬误的过程，我们将分析以下段落的推理质量。首先，我们将构建其结构。

The question involved in this legislation is not really a question of whether alcohol consumption is or is not detrimental to health. Rather, it is a question of whether Congress is willing to have the Federal Communications Commission make an arbitrary decision that prohibits alcohol advertising on radio and television. If we should permit the FCC to take this action in regard to alcohol, what is there to prevent it from deciding next year that candy is detrimental to the public health in that it causes obesity, tooth decay, and other health problems? What about milk and eggs? Milk and eggs are high in saturated animal fat and no doubt increase the cholesterol in the bloodstream, believed by many heart specialists to be a contributing factor in heart disease. Do we want the FCC to be able to prohibit the advertising of milk, eggs, butter, and ice cream on TV?
这项立法所涉及的问题并非饮酒是否有害健康，而是国会是否愿意让联邦通信委员会（FCC）做出任意决定，禁止在广播和电视上播放酒精广告。如果我们允许FCC对酒精采取这种行动，那么明年又有什么能阻止它认定糖果有害健康，导致肥胖、蛀牙和其他健康问题呢？牛奶和鸡蛋呢？牛奶和鸡蛋富含饱和动物脂肪，无疑会增加血液中的胆固醇，而许多心脏病专家认为胆固醇过高是心脏病的一个诱发因素。我们真的希望FCC有权禁止在电视上播放牛奶、鸡蛋、黄油和冰淇淋的广告吗？
Also, we all know that no action by the federal government, however drastic, can or will be effective in eliminating alcohol consumption completely. If people want to drink alcoholic beverages, they will find some way to do so.
此外，我们都知道，联邦政府采取的任何行动，无论多么严厉，都无法彻底消除酒精消费。如果人们想喝酒，他们总会找到其他途径。
CONCLUSION: The FCC should not prohibit alcohol advertising on radio and television.
结论：联邦通信委员会不应禁止在广播和电视上播放酒精广告。
REASONS: 1. If we permit the FCC to prohibit advertising on radio and television, the FCC will soon prohibit many kinds of advertising, because many products present potential health hazards. 2. No action by the federal government can or will be effective in eliminating alcohol consumption completely.
理由：1. 如果我们允许联邦通信委员会（FCC）禁止在广播和电视上投放广告，FCC很快就会禁止许多类型的广告，因为许多产品都存在潜在的健康危害。2. 联邦政府的任何行动都无法也绝不会有效地彻底消除酒精消费。

First, we should note that both reasons refer to rather specific disadvantages of the prohibition—a good start. The acceptability of the first reason, however, depends on a hidden assumption that once we allow actions to be taken on the merits of one case, it will be impossible to stop actions on similar cases. We do not agree with this assumption, because we believe that there are plenty of steps in our legal system to prevent such actions if they appear unjustified. Thus, we judge this reason to be unacceptable. Such reasoning is an example of the slippery slope fallacy .

首先，我们应该注意到，这两个理由都指向了禁令的具体弊端——这是一个好的开始。然而，第一个理由的合理性取决于一个隐含的假设：一旦我们允许对某个案件的案情采取行动，就无法阻止类似案件的类似行动。我们不认同这一假设，因为我们相信，如果此类行动显得不合理，我们的法律体系中有很多措施可以阻止它们。因此，我们认为这个理由不可接受。这种推理正是滑坡谬误的一个例子。

F: Slippery Slope: Making the assumption that a proposed step will set off an uncontrollable chain of undesirable events, when procedures exist to prevent such a chain of events.

F：滑坡谬误：假设提出的步骤会引发一系列无法控制的不良事件，而实际上存在防止此类事件发生的程序。

The relevance of the second reason is questionable because even if this reason were true, the assumption linking the reason to the conclusion—the major goal of prohibiting alcohol advertising on radio and television is to eliminate alcohol consumption completely —is false. A more likely goal is to reduce consumption. Thus we reject this reason. We call this fallacy the searching for perfect solutions fallacy. It takes the form: A solution to X does not deserve our support unless it destroys the problem entirely. If we ever find a perfect solution, then we should adopt it. But because the fact that part of a problem would remain after a solution is tried does not mean the solution is unwise. A particular solution may be vastly superior to no solution at all. It may move us closer to solving the problem completely.

第二个理由的相关性值得怀疑，因为即便这个理由成立，将其与结论联系起来的假设——禁止在广播和电视上投放酒精广告的主要目标是彻底消除酒精消费——也是错误的。更可能的目标是减少酒精消费。因此，我们否定这个理由。我们将这种谬误称为“寻求完美解决方案谬误”。它的形式是：除非某个解决方案能够彻底解决问题，否则它不值得我们支持。如果我们找到了完美的解决方案，就应该采纳它。但是，即使尝试某种解决方案后问题的一部分仍然存在，也不意味着该解决方案不明智。某个特定的解决方案可能远胜于没有解决方案。它或许能让我们更接近彻底解决问题。

If we waited for perfect solutions to emerge, we would often find ourselves paralyzed, unable to act. Here is another example of this fallacy: Why try to restrict people's access to abortion clinics in the United States? Even if you were successful, a woman seeking an abortion could still fly to Europe to acquire an abortion.

如果我们等待完美的解决方案出现，往往会发现自己陷入瘫痪，无法采取行动。以下是这种谬误的另一个例子：为什么要试图限制美国民众前往堕胎诊所？即使限制成功，想要堕胎的女性仍然可以飞往欧洲进行堕胎手术。

F: Searching for Perfect Solution: Falsely assuming that because part of a problem would remain after a solution is tried, the solution should not be adopted.

F：寻找完美解决方案：错误地认为，即使尝试了某种解决方案，问题的一部分仍然会存在，因此不应该采用该解决方案。

Discovering Other Common Reasoning Fallacies

发现其他常见的推理谬误

We are now going to take you through some exercises in discovering more common fallacies. As you encounter each exercise, try to apply the fallacy, finding hints that we listed above. Once you have developed good fallacy-detection habits, you will be able to find most fallacies. Each exercise presents some reasoning that includes fallacies.
