  • There is a car accident at a busy intersection. The drivers blame each other. Witnesses alternately blame the drivers and a third car that sped off.
    繁忙的十字路口发生一起车祸。两名司机互相指责。目击者则轮流指责两名司机以及肇事逃逸的第三辆车。
  • You send what you believe to be a friendly e-mail to a friend. Your friend responds to you wanting to know why you sent such a mean note to her.
    你给朋友发了一封你认为很友好的电子邮件。你的朋友回复你，想知道你为什么给她发了一封这么刻薄的邮件。

While personal observations can often be valuable sources of evidence, we need to recognize that they are not unbiased "mirrors of reality"; and when they are used to support controversial conclusions, we should seek verification by other observers as well as other kinds of evidence to support the conclusion. For example, if an employee complains that certain remarks made by her boss are discriminatory, the claim is more credible if others who heard the remarks also think the comments were discriminatory. Also, remember that observational reports get increasingly problematic as the time between the observation and the report of the observation increases.

虽然个人观察往往是宝贵的证据来源，但我们需要认识到，它们并非客观的“现实镜子”；当用个人观察来支持有争议的结论时，我们应该寻求其他观察者的验证以及其他类型的证据来支持该结论。例如，如果一名员工投诉其老板的某些言论具有歧视性，那么如果其他听到这些言论的人也认为这些言论具有歧视性，那么该投诉就更具可信度。此外，请记住，观察报告的可靠性会随着观察和报告之间的时间间隔的增加而不断下降。

When reports of observations in newspapers, magazines, books, television, and the Internet are used as evidence, you need to determine whether there are good reasons to rely on such reports. The most reliable reports will be based on recent observations made by several people observing under optimal conditions who have no apparent, strong expectations or biases related to the event being observed.

当报纸、杂志、书籍、电视和互联网上的观察报道被用作证据时，你需要判断是否有充分的理由相信这些报道。最可靠的报道应基于近期由多位观察者在最佳条件下进行的观察，且这些观察者对所观察的事件没有明显的强烈预期或偏见。

Research Studies as Evidence

研究案例作为证据

"Studies show..."
“研究表明……”
"Research investigators have found in a recent survey that..."
“研究人员在最近的一项调查中发现……”
"A report in the New England Journal of Medicine indicates ..."
《新英格兰医学杂志》上的一份报告显示……

One form of authority that relies a great deal on observation and often carries special weight is the research study: usually a systematic collection of observations by people trained to do scientific research. How dependable are research findings? Like appeals to any authority, we cannot tell about the dependability of research findings until we ask lots of questions.

研究报告是一种高度依赖观察且往往具有特殊分量的权威形式：它通常是由受过科学研究训练的人员系统地收集观察结果。研究结果的可靠性如何？如同任何权威一样，我们只有提出大量问题才能判断研究结果的可靠性。

Society has turned to the scientific method as an important guide for determining the facts because the relationships among events in our world are very complex, and because humans are fallible in their observations and theories about these events. The scientific method attempts to avoid many of the built-in biases in our observations of the world and in our intuition and common sense.

社会之所以将科学方法视为探寻事实的重要指南，是因为我们世界中各种事件之间的关系极其复杂，而且人类在观察和推断这些事件时难免会犯错。科学方法力求避免我们在观察世界、运用直觉和常识时所固有的诸多偏见。

What is special about the scientific method? Above all, it seeks information in the form of publicly verifiable data —that is, data obtained under conditions such that other qualified people can make similar observations and see whether they get the same results. Thus, for example, if one researcher reports that she was able to achieve cold fusion in she lab, the experiment would seem more credible if other researchers could obtain the same results.

科学方法有何特别之处？最重要的是，它寻求的是可公开验证的数据——也就是说，在其他合格人员可以进行类似观察并验证结果的条件下获得的数据。例如，如果一位研究人员报告说她在实验室实现了冷核聚变，那么如果其他研究人员也能获得相同的结果，那么这项实验就更具可信度。

A second major characteristic of scientific method is control—that is, the using of special procedures to reduce error in observations and in the interpretation of research findings. For example, if bias in observations may be a major problem, researchers might try to control this kind of error by using multiple observers to see how well they agree with one another. Physical scientists frequently maximize control by studying problems in the laboratory so that they can minimize extraneous factors. Unfortunately, control is usually more difficult in the social world than in the physical world; thus it is very difficult to successfully apply the scientific method to many questions about complex human behavior.

科学方法的第二个主要特征是控制——即运用特殊程序来减少观察和研究结果解释中的误差。例如，如果观察偏差可能是一个主要问题，研究人员可能会尝试通过安排多名观察者来控制这种误差，并检验他们之间的一致性。物理科学家经常通过在实验室中研究问题来最大限度地控制误差，从而最大限度地减少无关因素的影响。然而，在社会领域，控制通常比在物理领域更难；因此，将科学方法成功应用于许多关于复杂人类行为的问题非常困难。

Precision in language is a third major component of the scientific method. Concepts are often confusing, obscure, and ambiguous. Scientific method tries to be precise and consistent in its use of language.

语言的精确性是科学方法的第三个重要组成部分。概念往往令人困惑、晦涩难懂且含义模糊。科学方法力求在使用语言时做到精确和一致。

While there is much more to science than we can discuss here, we want you to keep in mind that scientific research, when conducted well, is one of our best sources of evidence because it emphasizes verifiability, control, and precision.

虽然科学涉及的内容远不止我们在这里能够讨论的，但我们希望您记住，科学研究如果进行得当，是我们最好的证据来源之一，因为它强调可验证性、可控性和精确性。

Problems with Research Findings

研究结果存在的问题

Unfortunately, the fact that research has been applied to a problem does not necessarily mean that the research evidence is dependable evidence or that the interpretations of the meaning of the evidence are accurate. Like appeals to any source, appeals to research evidence must be approached with caution. Also, some questions, particularly those that focus on human behavior, can be answered only tentatively even with the best of evidence. Thus, there are a number of important questions we want to ask about research studies before we decide how much to depend on their conclusions.

遗憾的是，研究成果应用于某个问题并不一定意味着研究证据可靠，也不意味着对证据含义的解读准确无误。如同引用任何其他来源一样，引用研究证据也必须谨慎。此外，有些问题，特别是那些关注人类行为的问题，即使拥有最佳证据，也只能给出初步答案。因此，在决定对研究结论的依赖程度之前，我们需要提出一些关于这些研究的重要问题。

When communicators appeal to research as a source of evidence, you should remember the following:

当传播者引用研究作为证据来源时，你应该记住以下几点：

  1. Research varies greatly in quality , we should rely more on some research studies than others. There is well-done research and there is poorly done research, and we should rely more on the former. Because the research process is so complex and subject to so many external influences, even those well-trained in research practices sometimes conduct research studies that have important deficiencies; publication in a scientific journal does not guarantee that a research study is not flawed in important ways.
    研究质量参差不齐，我们应该更重视某些研究而非其他研究。研究有好有坏，我们应该更重视前者。由于研究过程极其复杂，且易受诸多外部因素影响，即使是受过良好研究训练的人员，有时也会开展存在重大缺陷的研究；在科学期刊上发表论文并不能保证研究本身不存在重大缺陷。
  2. Research findings often contradict one another. Thus, single research studies presented out of the context of the family of research studies that -investigate the question often provide misleading conclusions. Research findings that most deserve our attention are those that have been repeated by more than one researcher or group of researchers. We need to always ask the question: "Have other researchers verified the findings?"
    研究结果常常相互矛盾。因此，脱离相关研究体系单独呈现的研究往往会得出误导性的结论。最值得我们关注的研究结果是那些被不止一位研究者或多个研究团队重复验证的结果。我们始终需要问自己：“其他研究者是否验证过这些结果？”
  3. Research findings do not prove conclusions. At best, they support conclusions. Research findings do not speak for themselves! Researchers must always interpret the meaning of their findings, and all findings can be interpreted in more than one way. Thus, researchers' conclusions should not be treated as demonstrated "truths." When you encounter statements such as "research findings show..." you should retranslate them into "researchers interpret their research findings as showing ..."
    研究结果并不能证明结论。充其量，它们只是对结论的支持。研究结果本身并不能说明一切！研究人员必须始终对研究结果进行解读，而所有研究结果都可以有多种解读。因此，研究人员的结论不应被视为已被证实的“真理”。当你遇到“研究结果表明……”这样的表述时，你应该将其重新翻译为“研究人员将他们的研究结果解读为……”。
  4. Like all of us, researchers have expectations, attitudes, values, and needs that bias the questions they ask, the way they conduct their research, and the way they interpret their research findings. For example, scientists often have an emotional investment in a particular hypothesis. When the American Sugar Institute is paying for your summer research grant, it is very difficult to then "find" that sugar consumption among teenagers is excessive. Like all fallible human beings, scientists may find it difficult to objectively treat data that conflict with their hypothesis. A major strength of scientific research is that it tries to make public its procedures and results so that others can judge the merit of the research and then try to replicate it. However, regardless of how objective a scientific report may seem, important subjective elements are always involved.
    和我们所有人一样，研究人员也有自己的期望、态度、价值观和需求，这些都会影响他们提出的问题、开展研究的方式以及对研究结果的解读。例如，科学家往往对某个假设抱有情感上的依恋。如果美国糖业协会资助了你的暑期研究项目，那么你很难“发现”青少年糖摄入量过高。和所有会犯错的人一样，科学家可能难以客观地处理与自身假设相悖的数据。科学研究的一大优势在于，它会努力公开研究过程和结果，以便其他人能够评判研究的价值，并尝试重复验证。然而，无论科学报告看起来多么客观，其中始终都包含重要的主观因素。
  5. Speakers and writers often distort or simplify research conclusions. Major discrepancies may occur between the conclusion merited by the original research and the use of the evidence to support a communicator's beliefs. For example, researchers may carefully qualify their own conclusions in their original research report only to have the conclusions used by others without the qualifications.
    演讲者和作者常常会歪曲或简化研究结论。原始研究得出的结论与传播者利用这些证据来支持自身观点的做法之间可能存在重大差异。例如，研究人员可能在原始研究报告中仔细限定了自己的结论，但其他人却在未加限定的情况下使用了这些结论。
  6. Research "facts" change over time, especially claims about human behavior. For example, all of the following research "facts" have been reported by major scientific sources, yet have been "refuted" by recent research evidence: Prozac is completely safe when taken by children. It is important to drink eight glasses of water a day. Depression is caused entirely by chemical imbalances in the brain. Improper attachment to parents causes anti-social behavior in children.
    研究“事实”会随着时间推移而改变，尤其是关于人类行为的论断。例如，以下所有研究“事实”都曾被主要科学机构报道，但已被近期研究证据“驳斥”：儿童服用百忧解完全安全；每天喝八杯水很重要；抑郁症完全是由大脑化学物质失衡引起的；与父母依恋关系不当会导致儿童出现反社会行为。
  7. Research varies in how artificial it is. Often, to achieve the goal of control, research loses some of its "real-world" quality. The more artificial the research, the more difficult it is to generalize from the research study to the world outside. The problem of research artificiality is especially evident in research studying complex social behavior. For example, social scientists will have people sit in a room with a computer to play "games" that involve testing people's reasoning processes. The researchers are trying to figure out why people make certain decisions when confronted with different scenarios. However, we should ask, "Is sitting at the computer while thinking through hypothetical situations too artificial to tell us much about the way people make decisions when confronted with real dilemmas?"
    研究的“人为性”程度各不相同。通常，为了达到控制的目的，研究会牺牲一些“真实世界”的特质。研究的人为性越强，就越难将研究结果推广到现实世界。研究的人为性问题在研究复杂社会行为时尤为突出。例如，社会科学家会让参与者坐在电脑前玩一些“游戏”，这些游戏旨在测试人们的推理过程。研究人员试图弄清人们在面对不同情境时做出特定决策的原因。然而，我们应该扪心自问：“坐在电脑前思考假设情境是否过于人为，以至于无法让我们了解人们在面对真实困境时是如何做出决策的？”
  8. The need for financial gain, status, security, and other factors can affect research outcomes. Researchers are human beings, not computers. Thus, it is extremely difficult for them to be totally objective. For example, researchers who want to find a certain outcome through their research may interpret their results in such a way to find the desired outcome. Pressures to obtain grants, tenure, or other personal rewards might ultimately affect the way in which researchers interpret their data.
    对经济利益、地位、安全感和其他因素的需求会影响研究结果。研究人员是人，不是电脑。因此，他们很难做到完全客观。例如，希望通过研究得出特定结果的研究人员可能会以某种方式解读结果，以达到预期目的。获得科研经费、终身教职或其他个人回报的压力最终可能会影响研究人员对数据的解读方式。

As you can see, despite the many positive qualities of research evidence, we need to avoid embracing research conclusions prematurely.

正如你所看到的，尽管研究证据有很多积极的方面，但我们需要避免过早接受研究结论。

Clues for Evaluating Research Studies

评估研究的线索

Apply these questions to research findings to determine whether the findings are dependable evidence.

运用这些问题来检验研究结果，以确定这些结果是否是可靠的证据。

  1. What is the quality of the source of the report? Usually, the most dependable reports are those published in peer-review journals, those in which a study is not accepted until it has been reviewed by a series of relevant experts. Usually—but not always—the more reputable the source, the better designed the study. So, try to find out all you can about the reputation of the source.
    报告来源的质量如何？通常来说，最可靠的报告发表在同行评审期刊上，这类研究必须经过一系列相关专家的评审才能被接受。通常情况下（但并非总是如此），来源越权威，研究设计就越完善。因此，尽可能多地了解报告来源的声誉。
  2. Other than the quality of the source, are there other clues included in the communication suggesting the research was well done? For example, does the report detail any special strengths of the research?
    除了信息来源的质量之外，沟通中是否还有其他线索表明这项研究做得很好？例如，报告是否详细介绍了这项研究的任何特殊优势？
  3. Has the study been replicated? Has more than one study reached the same conclusion? Findings, even when "statistically significant," can arise by chance alone. For example, when an association is repeatedly and consistently found in well-designed studies, like the link between smoking and cancer, then there is reason to believe it, at least until those who disagree can provide persuasive evidence for their point of view.
    这项研究是否已被重复验证？是否有多项研究得出相同结论？即使研究结果“具有统计学意义”，也可能纯属偶然。例如，当某种关联在设计严谨的研究中反复且一致地被发现时，比如吸烟与癌症之间的联系，那么至少在持不同意见者能够提供令人信服的证据之前，我们有理由相信这种关联。
  4. How selective has the communicator been in choosing studies? For example, have relevant studies with contradictory results been omitted? Has the researcher selected only those studies that support his point?
    传播者在选择研究时有多谨慎？例如，是否遗漏了结果相互矛盾的相关研究？研究者是否只选择了那些支持其观点的研究？
  5. Is there any evidence of strong-sense critical thinking? Has the speaker or writer showed a critical attitude toward earlier research that was supportive of her point of view? Most conclusions from research need to be qualified because of research limitations. Has the communicator demonstrated a willingness to qualify?
    是否存在任何强有力的批判性思维表现？发言者或作者是否对先前支持其观点的研究表现出批判态度？大多数研究结论都需要加以限定，因为研究本身存在局限性。传播者是否表现出愿意对结论进行限定？
  6. Is there any reason for someone to have distorted the research? We need to be wary of situations in which the researchers need to find certain kinds of results.
    是否有人有理由歪曲研究结果？我们需要警惕研究人员为了得出特定结果而采取的手段。
  7. Are conditions in the research artificial and therefore distorted? Always ask, "How similar are the conditions under which the research study was conducted to the situation the researcher is generalizing about?"
    研究条件是否人为设定，因而存在偏差？务必问：“研究开展的条件与研究者想要概括的情况有多相似？”
  8. How far can we generalize, given the research sample? We discuss this question in depth in our next section.
    鉴于研究样本的限制，我们的结论能推广到什么程度？我们将在下一节深入探讨这个问题。
  9. Are there any biases or distortions in the surveys, questionnaires, ratings, or other measurements that the researcher uses? We need to have confidence that the researcher has measured accurately what she has wanted to measure. The problem of biased surveys and questionnaires is so pervasive in research that we discuss it in more detail in a later section.
    研究者使用的调查、问卷、评分或其他测量方法是否存在任何偏差或扭曲？我们需要确信研究者准确地测量了她想要测量的内容。调查和问卷存在偏差的问题在研究中非常普遍，我们将在后面的章节中对此进行更详细的讨论。

Generalizing from the Research Sample

从研究样本中进行概括

Speakers and writers usually use research reports to support generalizations, that is, claims about events in general. For example, "the medication was effective in treating cancer for the patients in the study" is not a generalization; "the medication cures cancer" is. The ability to generalize from research findings depends on the number, breadth, and randomness of events or people the researchers study.

演讲者和作者通常引用研究报告来支持概括性结论，即对事件的一般性断言。例如，“该药物对研究中的癌症患者有效”并非概括性结论；“该药物可以治愈癌症”才是。能否从研究结果中得出概括性结论取决于研究者所研究的事件或人群的数量、广度和随机性。

The process of selecting events or persons to study is called sampling. Because researchers can never study all events or people about which they want to generalize, they must choose some way to sample; and some ways are preferable to others. You need to keep several important considerations in mind when evaluating the research sample:

选择研究对象（事件或人群）的过程称为抽样。由于研究人员不可能研究所有他们想要概括的事件或人群，因此他们必须选择某种抽样方法；而且有些方法比其他方法更可取。在评估研究样本时，您需要牢记以下几个重要因素：

  1. The sample must be large enough to justify the generalization or conclusion. In most cases, the more events or people researchers observe, the more dependable their conclusion. If we want to form a general belief about how often college students receive help from others on term papers, we are better off studying 100 college students than studying 10.
    样本量必须足够大才能证明概括或结论的合理性。在大多数情况下，研究人员观察的事件或人群越多，他们的结论就越可靠。如果我们想了解大学生在学期论文中寻求他人帮助的频率，那么研究100名大学生比研究10名大学生更有说服力。
  2. The sample must possess as much breadth, or diversity, as the types of events about which conclusions are to be drawn. For example, if researchers want to generalize about college students' drinking habits in general, their evidence should be based on the sampling of a variety of different kinds of college students in a variety of different kinds of college settings. Students at a small private school in the Midwest may have different drinking habits than students at a large public school on the West Coast; thus, a study of students attending only one school would lack breadth of sampling.
    样本的广度或多样性必须与待得出结论的事件类型相匹配。例如，如果研究人员想要概括大学生的饮酒习惯，那么他们的证据应该基于对不同类型大学生在不同大学环境中的抽样调查。中西部一所小型私立学校的学生与西海岸一所大型公立学校的学生饮酒习惯可能不同；因此，仅针对一所学校的学生进行的研究就缺乏样本的广度。
  3. The more random the sample, the better. When researchers randomly sample, they try to make sure that all events about which they want to generalize have an equal chance of getting sampled; they try to avoid a biased sample. Major polls, like the Gallop poll, for example, always try to sample randomly. This keeps them from getting groups of events or people that have biased characteristics. Do you see how each of the following samples has biased characteristics?
    样本越随机越好。研究人员进行随机抽样时，会尽量确保所有想要概括的事件都有相同的机会被抽样；他们会努力避免样本偏差。例如，像盖洛普民意调查这样的大型民意调查，总是力求进行随机抽样。这样可以避免抽到具有特定特征的事件或人群。你看出以下每个样本有哪些偏差特征吗？
a. People who volunteer to be interviewed about frequency of sexual activity.
a. 自愿接受关于性活动频率采访的人。
b. People who are at home at 2:30 p.m. to answer their phone.
b. 下午 2:30 在家接听电话的人。
c. Readers of a popular women's magazine who clip and complete mail-in surveys.
c. 某知名女性杂志的读者剪下杂志内容并填写邮寄调查问卷。

Thus, we want to ask of all research studies, "How many events or people did they sample, how much breadth did the sample have, and how random was the sample?"

因此，我们想问所有研究：“他们抽取了多少事件或人群作为样本，样本的广度如何，样本的随机性如何？”

A common problem that stems from not paying enough attention to the limits of sampling is for communicators to overgeneralize research findings. They state a generalization that is much broader than that warranted by the research. In Chapter 7, we referred to such overgeneralizing as the Hasty Generalization fallacy . Let's take a close look at a research overgeneralization:

传播者常常因为忽视抽样局限性而导致过度概括研究结果。他们提出的概括范围远大于研究本身所能涵盖的范围。在第七章中，我们将这种过度概括称为“草率概括谬误”。让我们仔细分析一下研究中的过度概括：

Alcohol consumption is at an all-time high at colleges nationwide. A recent survey conducted by Drinksville University found that of the 250 people surveyed, 89 percent drink on a semi-regular basis.
全美各大学校园的饮酒量已达到历史新高。德林克斯维尔大学最近的一项调查发现，在接受调查的250人中，89%的人经常饮酒。

Sampling procedures prohibit such a broad generalization. The research report implies the conclusion can be applied to all campuses, when the research studied only one campus. We don't even know whether the conclusion can be applied to that campus, because we don't know how randomly researchers sampled from it. The research report is flawed because it greatly overgeneralizes.

抽样程序不允许如此广泛的概括。该研究报告暗示其结论可以应用于所有校园，而实际上该研究仅针对一个校园。我们甚至不知道该结论是否适用于该校园，因为我们不清楚研究人员是如何随机抽取样本的。该研究报告存在缺陷，因为它过度概括了研究结果。

Remember : We can generalize only to people and events that are like those that we have studied in the research!

请记住：我们只能将结论推广到与我们在研究中研究过的人和事件类似的人和事件！

Biased Surveys and Questionnaires

有偏见的调查和问卷

It's early evening. You have just finished dinner. The phone rings. "We're conducting a survey of public opinion. Will you answer a few questions?" If you answer "yes," you will be among thousands who annually take part in surveys— one of the research methods you will encounter most frequently. Think how often you hear the phrase "according to recent polls."

傍晚时分，你刚吃完晚饭。电话铃响了。“我们正在进行一项民意调查，请问您愿意回答几个问题吗？”如果你回答“愿意”，你将成为每年参与民意调查的数千人之一——这是你最常遇到的研究方法之一。想想你多久会听到一次“根据最近的民意调查”这句话。

Surveys and questionnaires are usually used to measure people's attitudes and beliefs. Just how dependable are they? It depends! Survey responses are subject to many influences; thus, one has to be very cautious in interpreting their meaning. Let's examine some of these influences.

调查问卷通常用于衡量人们的态度和信念。但它们究竟有多可靠呢？这取决于多种因素！调查结果会受到诸多影响；因此，在解读其含义时必须格外谨慎。让我们来探讨一下其中的一些影响因素。

First, for survey responses to be meaningful, they must be answered honestly. That is, verbal reports need to mirror actual beliefs and attitudes. Yet, for a variety of reasons, people frequently shade the truth. For example, they may give answers they think they ought to give, rather than answers that reflect their true beliefs. They may experience hostility toward the questionnaire or toward the kind of question asked. They may give too little thought to the question. If you have ever been a survey participant, you can probably think of other influences.

首先，要使调查问卷的回答有意义，必须保证回答的真实性。也就是说，口头报告需要反映受访者的真实想法和态度。然而，由于种种原因，人们常常会隐瞒真相。例如，他们可能会给出他们认为应该给出的答案，而不是反映其真实想法的答案。他们可能对问卷或问卷中提出的问题抱有敌意。他们可能对问题思考不足。如果您曾经参与过调查，您或许还能想到其他一些影响因素。

Remember : You cannot assume that verbal reports accurately reflect true attitudes.

记住：你不能想当然地认为口头报告能够准确反映真实态度。

Second, many survey questions are ambiguous in their wording; the questions are subject to multiple interpretations. Different individuals may in essence be responding to different questions! For example, imagine the multiple possible interpretations of the following survey question: "Do you think there is quality programming on television?" The more ambiguous the wording of a survey, the less credibility you can place in the results.

其次，许多调查问卷的措辞含糊不清，容易产生多种解读。不同的人实际上可能在回答不同的问题！例如，想象一下以下调查问题可能存在的多种解读：“您认为电视节目质量如何？” 调查问卷的措辞越含糊，其结果的可信度就越低。

You should always ask the question: "How were the survey questions worded?" Usually, the more specifically worded a question, the more likely that different individuals will interpret it similarly.

你应该始终问自己：“调查问卷的问题是如何措辞的？”通常情况下，问题的措辞越具体，不同的人就越有可能做出相似的理解。

Third, surveys contain many built-in biases that make them even more suspect. Two of the most important are biased wording and biased context. Biased wording of a question is a common problem; a small change in how a question is asked can have a major effect on how a question is answered. Let's examine a conclusion based on a recent poll and then look at the survey question.

第三，调查问卷本身就包含许多固有的偏差，这使得它们的可靠性更加值得怀疑。其中最重要的两个偏差是措辞偏差和语境偏差。措辞偏差是一个常见问题；提问方式的细微变化就可能对答案产生重大影响。让我们先来看一个基于近期民意调查得出的结论，然后再分析一下调查问卷中的问题。

A college professor found that 86 percent of respondents believe that President Bush has failed the American people with respect to his handling of the war in Iraq.
一位大学教授发现，86%的受访者认为布什总统在处理伊拉克战争方面辜负了美国人民。

Now let's look closely at the survey question: "What do you think about the President's misguided efforts in the war in Iraq?" Look carefully at this question. Do you see the built-in bias? The "leading" words are "the President's misguided efforts." Wouldn't the responses have been quite different if the question had read: "What do you think about the President's attempt to bring democracy, markets, and freedom to the Iraqi people?" Thus, the responses obtained here are not an accurate indicator of attitudes concerning President Bush's handling of the war in Iraq.

现在让我们仔细看看调查问题：“您如何看待总统在伊拉克战争中的错误举措？”仔细审视这个问题。您是否发现了其中的固有偏见？“总统的错误举措”是引导性词语。如果问题改为：“您如何看待总统试图为伊拉克人民带来民主、市场和自由的努力？”，那么回答岂不是会截然不同？因此，这里获得的回答并不能准确反映人们对布什总统处理伊拉克战争的态度。

Survey and questionnaire data must always be examined for possible bias. Look carefully at the wording of the questions! Here is another example. We have emphasized the word that demonstrates the bias.

调查和问卷数据必须始终检查是否存在可能的偏差。仔细查看问题的措辞！以下是另一个例子。我们已突出显示了体现偏差的词语。

QUESTION: Should poor people who refuse to get a job be allowed to receive welfare benefits?
问：拒绝工作的贫困人口是否应该被允许领取福利金？
CONCLUSION: Ninety-three percent of people responding believe poor people should not receive welfare benefits.
结论：93%的受访者认为穷人不应该领取福利金。

The effect of context on an answer to a question can also be powerful. Even answers to identical questions can vary from poll to poll depending on how the questionnaire is presented and how the question is embedded in the survey. The following question was included in two recent surveys: "Do you think we should lower the drinking age from 21?" In one survey, the question was preceded by another question: "Do you think the right to vote should be given to children at the age of 18 as it currently is?" In the other survey, no preceding question occurred. Not surprisingly, the two surveys showed different results. Can you see how the context might have affected respondents?

情境对问题答案的影响可能非常显著。即使是相同的问题，在不同的民意调查中，答案也会有所不同，这取决于问卷的呈现方式以及问题在调查中的嵌入方式。例如，最近的两项调查都包含了以下问题：“您认为我们应该将饮酒年龄从21岁降低吗？”在其中一项调查中，这个问题前面还有一个问题：“您认为应该像现在这样，赋予18岁的儿童投票权吗？”而在另一项调查中，则没有前面的问题。不出所料，两项调查的结果截然不同。您能看出情境是如何影响受访者的吗？

Another important contextual factor is length. In long surveys, people may respond differently to later items than to earlier items simply because they get tired. Be alert to contextual factors when evaluating survey results.

另一个重要的背景因素是问卷长度。在较长的调查中，人们可能会因为疲劳而对后面的问题做出不同的回答。在评估调查结果时，务必注意这些背景因素。

Because the way people respond to surveys is affected by many unknown factors, such as the need to please or the interpretation of the question, should we ever treat survey evidence as good evidence? There are heated debates about this issue, but our answer is "yes," as long as we are careful and do not generalize further than warranted. Some surveys are more reputable than others. The better the quality of the survey, the more you should be influenced by the results.

由于人们在调查中的回答会受到诸多未知因素的影响，例如取悦他人的需求或对问题的解读，我们是否应该将调查结果视为可靠的证据？关于这个问题一直存在激烈的争论，但我们的答案是肯定的，只要我们谨慎行事，不进行过度概括。有些调查比其他调查更可靠。调查质量越高，你就越应该重视其结果。

Our recommendation is to examine survey procedures carefully before accepting survey results. Once you have ascertained the quality of the procedures, you can choose to generate your own qualified generalization —one that takes into account any biases you might have found. Even biased surveys can be informative; but you need to know the biases in order to not be unduly persuaded by the findings.

我们建议您在接受调查结果之前，仔细审查调查程序。一旦您确认了程序的质量，您可以选择得出自己的合理概括——这种概括应考虑到您可能发现的任何偏差。即使存在偏差的调查也可能提供有价值的信息；但您需要了解这些偏差，以免被调查结果过度影响。

Critical Evaluation of a Research-Based Argument

对基于研究的论证进行批判性评价

Let's now use our questions about research to evaluate the following argument in which research evidence has been used to support a conclusion.

现在让我们运用有关研究的问题来评价以下论证，其中使用了研究证据来支持结论。

Parents who push their children to study frequently end up causing their children to dislike reading, a recent study argues. The researchers studied 56 children in the sixth grade and found that those who reported the greatest dislike for reading were the ones whose parents frequently forced them to read. Alternatively, students who reported enjoying reading had less domineering parents. "The more demanding the parents were with studying, the less likely the child was to enjoy reading on his or her own," claim Stanley and Livingstone in the August issue of Educator's War Chest. The study was conducted at Little Creek elementary school in Phoenix, Arizona. The study found that if not forced to study, children were more likely to pick up a book in their free time. "It seems that there is a natural inclination to rebel against one's parents in children, and one way to manifest this inclination is to refuse to read if the child's parents force the child to study," reported Stanley and Livingstone.
一项最新研究表明，父母经常强迫孩子学习最终会导致孩子厌恶阅读。研究人员调查了56名六年级学生，发现最不喜欢阅读的孩子往往是那些经常被父母强迫阅读的孩子。相反，那些表示喜欢阅读的孩子，他们的父母则不那么专制。斯坦利和利文斯通在《教育者战利品》（Educator's War Chest）杂志八月刊上指出：“父母对孩子学习的要求越高，孩子就越不可能自主地享受阅读的乐趣。”这项研究在亚利桑那州凤凰城的小溪小学进行。研究发现，如果不强迫孩子学习，他们更有可能在空闲时间拿起书本阅读。斯坦利和利文斯通报告说：“孩子们似乎天生就有一种反抗父母的倾向，而这种倾向的一种表现形式就是，如果父母强迫他们学习，他们就会拒绝阅读。”

The research is presented here in an uncritical fashion. We see no sign of strong-sense critical thinking. The report makes no references to special strengths or weaknesses of the study, although it does provides some detail about the research procedures so that we can make judgments about its worth as the basis of a generalization. There is no indication of whether the study has been replicated. Also, we do not know how selective the communicator has been in choosing studies, nor how this research fits into the broader context of research on children and their enjoyment of reading. We do not know what benefits publishing this study may have had for the researchers.

这项研究在此呈现时缺乏批判性思考，我们看不到任何严谨的批判性思维。报告虽然提供了一些研究程序的细节，以便我们判断其作为概括性结论的基础是否可靠，但并未提及该研究的具体优势或不足。报告也没有说明该研究是否已被重复验证。此外，我们不清楚传播者在选择研究时是否经过筛选，也不清楚这项研究在更广泛的儿童阅读兴趣研究领域中处于何种地位。我们更不清楚发表这项研究对研究人员究竟有何益处。

Have the researchers and passage author overgeneralized? The sample is small—56—and it lacks breadth and randomness because it is restricted to one elementary school in the Southwest. We need to ask many questions about the sampling. How were these children selected? How was the study advertised to the parents? Could there have been a bias in the kind of parents willing to sign up for such a study? Would we have gotten similar results if we had randomly chosen families from a large number of schools throughout the country? This passage clearly illustrates a case of overgeneralization!

研究人员和文章作者是否过度概括了研究结果？样本量很小——只有56个——而且由于仅限于美国西南部的一所小学，缺乏广度和随机性。我们需要对抽样过程提出许多问题。这些孩子是如何被选中的？研究人员是如何向家长宣传这项研究的？参与这项研究的家长是否存在某种偏好偏差？如果我们从全国各地的大量学校中随机选择家庭，是否会得到类似的结果？这篇文章显然体现了过度概括的典型案例！

Are the questionnaires biased? Consider being a parent and completing a questionnaire about how controlling you are. Don't you think we could raise doubts about the accuracy of responses to such a questionnaire? Too little information is given about the wording of the questionnaires or about the arrangement of questionnaire items to judge the ambiguity of the item wording and the possibility of biased wording and biased context.

这些问卷是否存在偏见？试想一下，如果你是一位家长，填写一份关于你控制欲有多强的问卷，你会作何感想？难道我们不应该对这类问卷的回答准确性提出质疑吗？问卷的措辞和题项排列方式缺乏足够的信息，让我们无法判断题项措辞的歧义性以及是否存在措辞或语境上的偏见。

We have raised enough questions about the above passage to be wary of its factual claims. We would want to rely on much more research before we could conclude that these claims are dependable.

我们已经对上述段落提出了足够多的疑问，因此对其事实陈述持谨慎态度。在得出这些陈述可靠结论之前，我们需要进行更多研究。

Let's now look at a very different source of evidence.

现在让我们来看一个截然不同的证据来源。

Case Examples as Evidence

案例作为证据

President of a large university: "Of course our students can move on to high paying jobs and further study at large universities. Why, just this past year we sent one of our students, Mary Nicexample, off to law school at Harvard. In her first year Mary remained in the top five percent of her class. Therefore, our students can certainly achieve remarkable success at elite universities."
一位大型大学的校长说：“当然，我们的学生毕业后可以找到高薪工作，也可以继续在顶尖大学深造。就在去年，我们的一名学生玛丽·尼克尔科姆斯就去了哈佛大学法学院。玛丽第一年的成绩就一直名列班级前5%。因此，我们的学生完全有能力在顶尖大学取得卓越的成就。”

A frequently used kind of evidence that contrasts markedly to the kind of research study that we have just described, which emphasized studying large representative samples, is the use of a detailed description of one or several individuals or events to support a conclusion. Such descriptions are usually based on observations or interviews and vary from being in depth and thorough to being superficial. We call such descriptions case examples.

与我们刚才描述的那种强调研究大型代表性样本的研究方法截然不同，一种常用的证据类型是使用对一个或多个个人或事件的详细描述来支持结论。这类描述通常基于观察或访谈，其详尽程度不一，从深入透彻到浅显浅显都有。我们称这类描述为案例。

Communicators often begin persuasive presentations with dramatic descriptions of cases. For example, one way to argue to increase the drinking age is to tell heart-wrenching stories of young people's dying in car accidents when the driver was young and drunk.

沟通者常常以生动的案例描述来展开有说服力的演讲。例如，提高饮酒年龄的一种方法就是讲述年轻人因酒驾或毒驾而死于车祸的悲惨故事。

Case examples are often compelling to us because of their colorfulness and their interesting details, which make them easy to visualize. Political candidates have increasingly resorted to case examples in their speeches, knowing that the rich details of cases generate an emotional reaction. Such cases, however, should be viewed more as striking examples or anecdotes than as proof, and we must be very suspicious of their use as evidence.

案例之所以往往引人注目，是因为它们生动形象、细节丰富，便于理解。政治候选人越来越多地在演讲中引用案例，因为他们深知案例中丰富的细节能够引发情感共鸣。然而，我们应该将此类案例视为引人注目的例子或轶事，而非证据，并对其作为证据的使用保持高度警惕。

Dramatic cases appeal to our emotions and distract us from seeking other more relevant research evidence. For example, imagine a story about a man who tortured and murdered his numerous victims. The human drama of these crimes may lead us to ignore the fact that such a case is rare and that over the past 30 years 119 inmates with capital sentences were found to be innocent and released from prison.

耸人听闻的案件往往能触动我们的情感，分散我们对其他更相关研究证据的注意力。例如，想象一下一个男人折磨并杀害众多受害者的故事。这些罪行的戏剧性可能会让我们忽略这样一个事实：此类案件极为罕见，而且在过去30年中，有119名被判处死刑的囚犯最终被证明无罪并获释。

Be wary of striking case examples as proof!

要警惕那些看似惊人的案例作为证据！

Although case examples will be consistent with a conclusion, do not let that consistency fool you. Always ask yourself: "Is the example typical?" "Are there powerful counterexamples?" "Are there biases in how the example is reported?"

尽管案例可能与结论相符，但不要被这种一致性所迷惑。务必问问自己：“这个例子具有代表性吗？”“是否存在强有力的反例？”“案例的叙述方式是否存在偏见？”

Are there times that case examples can be useful, even if they are not good evidence? Certainly! Like personal experiences, they demonstrate important possibilities and put a personal face on abstract statistics. They make it easier for people to relate to an issue and thus take more interest in it.

案例即便并非确凿证据，有时也能发挥作用吗？当然可以！案例如同个人经历，展现了重要的可能性，并将抽象的统计数据具象化。它们使人们更容易理解问题，从而激发他们对问题的兴趣。

Analogies as Evidence

类比作为证据

Look closely at the structure of the following brief arguments, paying special attention to the reason supporting the conclusion.

仔细观察下列简短论证的结构，特别注意支持结论的理由。

Adults cannot learn all of the intricacies of new computer technology. Trying to teach adults new computer systems is like trying to teach an old dog new tricks.
成年人不可能掌握所有新计算机技术的复杂细节。试图教成年人使用新的计算机系统，就像试图教老狗新把戏一样。
As an educator it is important to weed out problem students early and take care of the problems they present because one bad egg ruins the omelet.
作为教育工作者，及早剔除问题学生并解决他们提出的问题非常重要，因为一个害群之马会毁掉整个煎蛋卷。

These two arguments use analogies as evidence, a very different kind of evidence from what we have previously been evaluating. How do we decide whether it is good evidence? Before reading on, try to determine the persuasiveness of the two arguments.

这两个论点都以类比作为证据，这与我们之前评估的证据类型截然不同。我们如何判断它是否是有效的证据呢？在继续阅读之前，请尝试判断这两个论点的说服力。

Communicators often use resemblance as a form of evidence. They reason in the following way: "If these two things are alike in one respect, then they will probably be alike in other respects as well."

传播者常常以相似性作为证据。他们的推理方式如下：“如果这两件事物在某一方面相似，那么它们在其他方面也可能相似。”

For example, when bipolar disorder (manic depression) was first identified, psychologists frequently treated it similarly to depression because both shared the common characteristics of severe depression. We reason in a similar fashion when we choose to buy a CD because a friend recommends it. We reason that because we resemble each other in a number of likes and dislikes, we will enjoy the same music.

例如，当双相情感障碍（躁郁症）最初被发现时，心理学家常常将其与抑郁症相提并论，因为两者都具有重度抑郁症的共同特征。当我们因为朋友推荐而选择购买CD时，我们的推理方式也类似。我们认为，由于我们在许多喜好方面相似，所以我们会喜欢同样的音乐。

An argument that uses a well-known similarity between two things as the basis for a conclusion about a relatively unknown characteristic of one of those things is an argument by analogy . Reasoning by analogy is a common way of presenting evidence to support a conclusion.

以两个事物之间众所周知的相似性为基础，推断其中一个事物相对不为人知的特征，这种论证方式称为类比论证。类比推理是呈现证据以支持结论的常用方法。

Analogies both stimulate insights and deceive us. For example, analogies have been highly productive in scientific and legal reasoning. When we infer conclusions about humans on the basis of research with mice, we reason by analogy. Much of our thinking about the structure of the atom is analogical reasoning. When we make a decision in a legal case, we may base that decision on the similarity of that case to preceding cases. For example, when judges approach the question of whether restricting pornographic material violates the constitutional protection of free speech and freedom of expression, they must decide whether the potentially obscene pornographic material is analogous to freedom of speech; thus, they reason by analogy. Such reasoning can be quite insightful and persuasive.

类比既能激发洞察力，也能误导我们。例如，类比在科学和法律推理中发挥了重要作用。当我们根据对小鼠的研究推断人类的结论时，我们就是在运用类比推理。我们对原子结构的思考很大程度上也运用了类比推理。在法律案件中做出决定时，我们可能会基于该案件与先前案例的相似性来做出决定。例如，当法官审理限制色情材料是否违反宪法对言论自由和表达自由的保护这一问题时，他们必须判断潜在的淫秽色情材料是否与言论自由具有类比性；因此，他们运用了类比推理。这种推理往往富有洞察力且极具说服力。

Identifying and Comprehending Analogies

识别和理解类比

Accurate analogies are powerful, but are often difficult for people to evaluate. Analogies compare two known things to allow the reader to better understand the relationship to something that is unfamiliar. To be able to identify such comparisons, it is important to understand how analogies are structured. The first part of an analogy involves a familiar object or concept. That object or concept is being compared to another familiar object or concept. The second part is the relationship between the familiar objects or concepts. This relationship is used to create a principle that can be used to assist the understanding of a different object or concept. Finally, the relationship of the new or unfamiliar object or concept is described in the same format as the known object or concept.

准确的类比很有力量，但人们往往难以评估其准确性。类比通过比较两个已知事物，帮助读者更好地理解它们与未知事物之间的关系。为了识别这类类比，理解类比的结构至关重要。类比的第一部分涉及一个熟悉的事物或概念，并将其与另一个熟悉的事物或概念进行比较。第二部分是这两个熟悉事物或概念之间的关系。这种关系被用来构建一个原则，该原则可以帮助理解不同的事物或概念。最后，用与已知事物或概念相同的格式来描述新的或不熟悉的事物或概念之间的关系。

For example, "Relearning geometry is like riding a bike. Once you start, it all comes back to you." In the preceding analogy, riding a bicycle, the known, is used to explain relearning geometry, the unknown. We are familiar with the idea of getting on a bike after a period of time and "it all coming back to us" as we start to ride again. The analogy, therefore, explains relearning geometry in the same way, arguing if one simply starts to do geometry problems, remembering how to do such problems will simply come back to the person.

例如，“重新学习几何就像骑自行车。一旦开始，一切都会重新想起来。” 在前面的比喻中，骑自行车（已知的事物）被用来解释重新学习几何（未知事物）。我们熟悉这样的情况：一段时间没骑车后，再次骑上去就会“一切都会重新想起来”。因此，这个比喻也用同样的方式解释了重新学习几何，认为只要开始做几何题，就能自然而然地想起如何解题。

Once the nature and structure of analogies is understood, you should be able to identify analogies in arguments. It is especially important to identify analogies when they are used to set the tone of the conversation. Such analogies are used to "frame" an argument. To identify framing analogies, look for comparisons that are used to not only explain a point, but also to influence the direction a discussion will take.

一旦理解了类比的本质和结构，你就应该能够识别论证中的类比。尤其重要的是，要识别那些用于设定对话基调的类比。这类类比用于“构建”论证框架。要识别框架类比，就要寻找那些不仅用于解释观点，而且还用于影响讨论方向的比较。

For example, in the 2004 presidential election, the war in Iraq was an important issue. Opponents of the war used the analogy comparing the war in Iraq to the Vietnam War. The use of Vietnam as an analogy to the war in Iraq was not only an attempt to explain what is happening in Iraq now, but also to cause people to look negatively upon the war in Iraq. Conversely, proponents of the war in Iraq used the analogy comparing the war to World War II. World War II carries with it more positive connotations than does the Vietnam War, so this analogy was used to reframe the discussion in terms more favorable to the war in Iraq. Always look for comparisons that attempt to direct the reaction to an object through framing. A careful evaluation of framing analogies will prevent you from being misled by a potentially deceptive analogy.

例如，在2004年总统大选中，伊拉克战争是一个重要议题。反对者将伊拉克战争比作越南战争。他们不仅试图用越南战争来类比伊拉克战争，还试图以此解释伊拉克当前的局势，并引导人们对伊拉克战争产生负面看法。相反，支持伊拉克战争的人则将伊拉克战争比作第二次世界大战。第二次世界大战比越南战争更具正面意义，因此，他们利用二战来重新构建讨论框架，使之更有利于伊拉克战争。务必警惕那些试图通过框架效应引导人们对某个对象产生反应的类比。仔细评估框架效应类比，可以避免被潜在的误导性类比所蒙蔽。

Framing analogies is not the only thing to be wary of when looking for analogies in arguments. One must also be careful when evaluating arguments that use overly emotional comparisons. For example, one person in arguing against the estate tax recently compared the tax to the Holocaust. Who could possibly be in favor of a tax that is the equivalent of the Holocaust? However, we must evaluate the analogy to see whether it is really accurate or simply an emotion-laden comparison intended to coerce people into agreeing with a certain perspective by making the alternative seem ridiculous. After all, regardless of what one thinks about the estate tax, it is not responsible for the deaths of millions of people. Overly emotional analogies cloud the real issues in arguments and prevent substantive discourse. Try to identify comparisons made that contain significant emotional connotations to avoid being deceived by these analogies.

在论证中寻找类比时，需要警惕的不仅仅是类比的框架构建。评估那些使用过于情绪化的类比的论证时，也必须格外谨慎。例如，最近有人在反对遗产税时，将其比作纳粹大屠杀。谁会支持一项等同于纳粹大屠杀的税收呢？然而，我们必须评估这种类比，看它是否真的准确，或者仅仅是出于情感因素，旨在通过使另一种观点显得荒谬可笑来强迫人们接受某种观点。毕竟，无论人们对遗产税持何种看法，它都不是造成数百万人死亡的罪魁祸首。过于情绪化的类比会模糊论证中的真正问题，阻碍实质性的讨论。因此，要努力识别那些带有强烈情感色彩的类比，以免被这些类比所蒙蔽。

Evaluating Analogies

评估类比

Because analogical reasoning is so common and has the potential to be both persuasive and faulty, you will find it very useful to recognize such reasoning and know how to systematically evaluate it. To evaluate the quality of an analogy, you need to focus on two factors.

由于类比推理非常普遍，而且既有可能具有说服力，也有可能存在缺陷，因此，识别这种推理方式并知道如何系统地评估它非常有用。要评估类比的质量，你需要关注两个因素。

  1. The number of ways the two things being compared are similar and different.
    比较两个事物时，它们相似和不同的方式的数量。
  2. The relevance of the similarities and the differences.
    相似之处和不同之处的意义。

A word of caution: You can almost always find some similarities between any two things. So, analogical reasoning will not be persuasive simply because of many similarities. Strong analogies will be ones in which the two things we compare possess relevant similarities and lack relevant differences. All analogies try to illustrate underlying principles. Relevant similarities and differences are ones that directly relate to the underlying principle illustrated by the analogy.

需要注意的是：几乎任何两个事物之间都能找到一些相似之处。因此，仅仅因为相似之处很多，类比推理本身并不会很有说服力。真正有效的类比是指，我们比较的两个事物具有相关的相似之处，而缺乏相关的差异。所有类比都试图阐明其背后的原理。相关的相似之处和差异是指与类比所阐明的原理直接相关的相似点和差异。

Let's check out the soundness of the following argument by analogy.

让我们通过类比来检验以下论证的合理性。

I do not allow my dog to run around the neighborhood getting into trouble, so why shouldn't I enforce an 8 o'clock curfew on my 16-year old? I am responsible for keeping my daughter safe, as well as responsible for what she might do when she is out. My dog stays in the yard, and I want my daughter to stay in the house. This way, I know exactly what both are doing.
我不会放任我的狗在附近乱跑惹事，那我为什么不能对16岁的女儿实行晚上8点的宵禁呢？我有责任保护女儿的安全，也有责任让她在外面做什么。我的狗待在院子里，我也希望女儿待在家里。这样，我就能清楚地知道她们俩在做什么。

A major similarity between a pet and a child is that both are thought of as not being full citizens with all the rights and responsibilities of adults. Plus, as the speaker asserts, he is responsible for keeping his dog and daughter safe. We note some relevant differences, however. A dog is a pet who lacks higher order thinking skills and cannot assess right and wrong. A daughter, however, is a human being with the cognitive capacity to tell when things are right and wrong and when she should not do something that might get her (or her parents) in trouble. Also, as a human, she has certain rights and deserves a certain amount of respect for her autonomy. Thus, because a daughter can do things a dog cannot, the differences are relevant in assessing the analogy. The failure of the analogy to allow for the above listed distinctions causes it to fail to provide strong support for the conclusion.

宠物和孩子之间的一个主要相似之处在于，两者都被认为不具备成年人的全部权利和责任。此外，正如演讲者所言，他有责任确保他的狗和女儿的安全。然而，我们也注意到一些相关的差异。狗是宠物，缺乏高阶思维能力，无法判断是非对错。而女儿是人，拥有认知能力，能够分辨是非对错，并知道何时应该避免做可能给自己（或父母）带来麻烦的事情。此外，作为一个人，她拥有某些权利，其自主性也理应得到一定的尊重。因此，由于女儿能做到狗不能做的事情，这些差异在评估类比时至关重要。该类比未能考虑到上述区别，因此无法为结论提供强有力的支持。

Another strategy that may help you evaluate reasoning by analogy is to generate alternative analogies for understanding the same phenomenon that the author or speaker is trying to understand. Such analogies may either support or contradict the conclusions inferred from the original analogy. If they contradict the conclusion, they then reveal problems in the initial reasoning by analogy.

另一种有助于评估类比推理的策略是，针对作者或发言者试图理解的同一现象，提出其他类比。这些类比可能支持或反驳从原类比中得出的结论。如果它们反驳了原结论，则表明最初的类比推理存在问题。

For example, when authors argue that pornography should be banned because it is harmful to women, as well as to all who view it, they are using a particular analogy to draw certain conclusions about pornography: Pornography is like a form of discrimination, as well as a means by which people are taught women are nothing but sex objects. Others, however, have offered alternative analogies, arguing that pornography is "a statement of women's sexual liberation." Note how thinking about this different analogy may create doubts about the persuasiveness of the original analogy.

例如，当一些作者认为色情作品应该被禁止，因为它不仅对女性有害，也对所有观看者有害时，他们运用了一种特定的类比来得出关于色情作品的某些结论：色情作品就像一种歧视，也是一种将女性物化为性对象的手段。然而，也有人提出了不同的类比，认为色情作品是“女性性解放的宣言”。值得注意的是，思考这种不同的类比可能会让人对原先类比的说服力产生怀疑。

A productive way to generate your own analogies is the following:

以下是一种生成类比的有效方法：

  1. Identify some important features of what you are studying.
    找出你所研究内容的一些重要特征。
  2. Try to identify other situations with which you are familiar that have some similar features. Give free rein to your imagination. Brainstorm. Try to imagine diverse situations.
    试着找出你熟悉的、具有类似特征的其他情境。尽情发挥你的想象力，进行头脑风暴，尝试想象各种不同的情境。
  3. Try to determine whether the familiar situation can provide you with some insights about the unfamiliar situation.
    试着判断熟悉的情况是否能为你理解不熟悉的情况提供一些启示。

For example, in thinking about pornography, you could try to think of other situations in which people repeatedly think something is demeaning because of the way people are treated in a given situation, or because of what watching something might cause others to do. Do segregation, racist/sexist jokes, or employment discrimination come to mind? How about arguments' claiming playing violent video games, watching action movies, or listening to heavy metal music causes children to act violently? Do they trigger other ways to think about pornography? You should now be capable of systematically evaluating the two brief analogical arguments at the beginning of this section. Ask the questions you need to ask to determine the structure of the argument.

例如，在思考色情作品时，你可以试着想想还有哪些情境下，人们会反复认为某些事物有损尊严，原因可能是人们在特定情境下受到的待遇，也可能是观看某些内容可能导致他人做出某种行为。种族隔离、种族歧视/性别歧视的笑话，或者就业歧视，这些例子是否让你联想到？还有，那些声称玩暴力电子游戏、看动作电影或听重金属音乐会导致儿童暴力行为的论点呢？它们是否会引发你对色情作品的其他思考？现在，你应该能够系统地评估本节开头提到的两个简短的类比论证。提出你需要提出的问题，以确定论证的结构。

Then, ask the questions to evaluate the argument. Look for relevant similarities and differences. Usually, the greater the ratio of relevant similarities to relevant differences, the stronger the analogy. An analogy is especially compelling if you can find no relevant difference and you can find good evidence that the relevant similarities do indeed exist.

然后，提出问题来评估论点。寻找相关的相似点和不同点。通常，相关相似点与相关不同点的比例越大，类比就越有力。如果找不到任何相关不同点，并且能够找到充分的证据证明相关相似点确实存在，那么这个类比就特别令人信服。

We found a relevant difference that weakens each of our two initial sample analogies. Check your evaluation against our list.

我们发现了一些相关的差异，这些差异削弱了我们最初提出的两个类比示例。请对照我们的列表检查您的评估。

(First example) Learning computer skills involves cognitive capabilities well within those of your average adult; teaching "an old dog new tricks" involves training an animal with lower cognitive abilities, who is set in his ways, how to obey a command he may never have heard before. Learning computer skills is not the same as classically conditioning an animal.
（第一个例子）学习计算机技能所需的认知能力完全在普通成年人的范围内；而“教老狗新把戏”则是指训练一只认知能力较低、习惯性很强的动物，让它服从一个它可能从未听过的指令。学习计算机技能与对动物进行经典条件反射训练截然不同。
(Second example) The interactions of students in a classroom environment are very complex. The effect any one student might have on the group cannot easily be determined, just as the effects the group might have on the individual are difficult to predict. Conversely, a rotten egg will definitely spoil any food made from it. Also, it is problematic to think of people as unchanging objects, such as rotten eggs, that have no potential for growth and change.
（第二个例子）课堂环境中学生之间的互动非常复杂。任何一个学生对群体的影响都难以确定，正如群体对个体的影响也难以预测一样。反之，一个臭鸡蛋肯定会毁掉用它做成的任何食物。此外，把人看作像臭鸡蛋一样一成不变的物体，认为他们没有成长和改变的潜力，也是有问题的。

Analogies that trick or deceive us fit our definition of a reasoning fallacy; such deception is called the Faulty Analogy fallacy.

欺骗或误导我们的类比符合我们对推理谬误的定义；这种欺骗被称为错误的类比谬误。

F: Faulty Analogy : Occurs when an analogy is proposed in which there are important relevant dissimilarities.

F：错误的类比：当提出一个类比时，其中存在重要的相关差异。

In one sense, all analogies are faulty, because they make the mistaken assumption that because two things are alike in one or more respects, they are necessarily alike in some other important respect. It is probably best for you to think of analogies as varying from very weak to very strong. But even the best analogies are only suggestive. Thus if an author draws a conclusion about one case from a comparison to another case, then she should provide further evidence to support the principle revealed by the most significant similarity.

从某种意义上说，所有类比都是有缺陷的，因为它们错误地假设，如果两个事物在一个或多个方面相似，那么它们在其他重要方面也必然相似。或许你最好把类比理解为从非常弱到非常强的不同程度。但即使是最好的类比也只是启发性的。因此，如果作者通过比较一个案例得出关于另一个案例的结论，那么她应该提供进一步的证据来支持由最显著的相似之处所揭示的原则。

Summary

概括

This chapter has continued our focus on the evaluation of evidence. We have discussed the following kinds of evidence: observation, research studies, case examples, and analogies. Each source has its strengths and weaknesses. Usually, you can rely most on those claims that writers or speakers support directly by extensive scientific research. However, many issues have not been settled by scientific research, and consequently, communicators must rely on research that is not conclusive and on other sources of evidence. You should be especially wary of claims supported by biased observation, dramatic case examples, poorly designed research, or faulty analogies. When you encounter any evidence, you should try to determine its quality by asking, "How good is the evidence? "

本章继续探讨证据评估。我们讨论了以下几种证据类型：观察、研究、案例和类比。每种证据来源都有其优势和劣势。通常，您可以最信赖那些作者或演讲者直接引用大量科学研究支持的论断。然而，许多问题尚未得到科学研究的解决，因此，传播者必须依赖那些尚未得出结论性的研究和其他证据来源。您尤其应该警惕那些基于带有偏见的观察、夸张的案例、设计不佳的研究或错误的类比而得出的论断。当您遇到任何证据时，都应该尝试通过问自己“这个证据有多可靠？”来判断其质量。

Practice Exercises

练习题

Critical Question : How good is the evidence?
关键问题：证据的可靠性如何？

Evaluate each of these practice passages by examining the quality of the evidence provided.

通过检查所提供的证据质量来评价以下每篇练习文章。

Passage 1
第一段
Are children of alcoholics more likely to be alcoholics themselves? In answering the question, researchers sampled 451 people in Alcoholics Anonymous to see how many would say that one, or both, of their parents were alcoholics. People in AA used in the study currently attend AA somewhere in Ohio, Michigan, or Indiana and were asked by people in charge of the local AA programs to volunteer to fill out a survey. The research found that 77 percent of the respondents had at least one parent they classified as an alcoholic. The study also surveyed 451 people randomly from the same states who claim not to be heavy drinkers. Of the non-heavy drinkers, 23 percent would label at least one of their parents as alcoholic.
酗酒者的子女更容易成为酗酒者吗？为了解答这个问题，研究人员对451名匿名戒酒互助会（AA）成员进行了抽样调查，了解有多少人认为自己的父母一方或双方是酗酒者。参与研究的AA成员目前在俄亥俄州、密歇根州或印第安纳州的某个AA机构参加活动，并由当地AA项目的负责人邀请他们自愿填写调查问卷。研究发现，77%的受访者认为他们至少有一位父母是酗酒者。该研究还随机抽取了来自同一州的451名自称不酗酒的人进行调查。在这些不酗酒的人中，23%的人认为他们至少有一位父母是酗酒者。
Passage 2
第二段
I think California's "three strikes law" is a great idea. Why should criminals be given unlimited chances to continue to re-offend? We give a batter only three attempts to swing and hit a ball, so why does a criminal deserve any better? Three swings and misses and you are out; three offenses and convictions and you are in, jail that is.
我认为加州的“三振出局法”是个好主意。为什么罪犯应该有无限次的再犯机会？我们只给击球手三次挥棒击球的机会，为什么罪犯就应该有更多机会？三次挥棒落空就出局；三次犯罪定罪就进监狱。
Passage 3
第三段
One of the greatest symbols of the U.S. is the American flag. While cases in the past have defended desecration of the flag as symbolic speech I argue, "Where is the speech in such acts?" I do not believe allowing people to tarnish the flag and thus attack everything that America stands for is the same as allowing free speech. If you have something bad to say about the U.S., say it, but do not cheapen the flag with your actions. Many Americans died to keep that flag flying.
美国国旗是美国最伟大的象征之一。虽然过去有些案例将亵渎国旗的行为辩解为象征性言论，但我认为，“这种行为哪里体现了言论自由？”我不认为允许人们玷污国旗，从而攻击美国所代表的一切，就等同于允许言论自由。如果你想对美国说些坏话，那就说出来，但不要用你的行为来贬低国旗。许多美国人为了让这面国旗高高飘扬而献出了生命。
Those who want to support flag burning and other such despicable acts are outnumbered. Last month, 75 people were surveyed in a restaurant in Dallas, Texas, and were asked if they supported the unpatriotic desecration of the American flag in an attempt to express some sort of anti-American idea. Ninety-three percent responded that they were not in favor of desecration of the American flag. Therefore, our national lawmakers should pass a law protecting the American flag against such horrible actions.
支持焚烧国旗和其他此类卑劣行径的人寥寥无几。上个月，在德克萨斯州达拉斯市的一家餐厅，我们对75人进行了调查，询问他们是否支持这种不爱国的亵渎美国国旗的行为，以此来表达某种反美思想。93%的人表示他们不赞成亵渎美国国旗。因此，我们的立法者应该通过法律保护美国国旗免受此类恶劣行径的侵害。

Sample Responses

示例回复

Passage 1
第一段
CONCLUSION: Children of alcoholics are more likely to become alcoholics than are children of non-alcoholics.
结论：酗酒者的子女比非酗酒者的子女更容易成为酗酒者。
REASON: More alcoholics than non-alcoholics reported a substantially higher rate of having an alcoholic parent.
原因：与非酗酒者相比，酗酒者中报告父母酗酒的比例要高得多。

Note that the results presented are from one study without reference to how typical these results are. We also do not know where this information was published, so we can make no assessments regarding how rigorously the study was reviewed before publication. However, we can ask some useful questions about the study. The sample size is quite large, but its breadth is questionable. Although multiple states were sampled, to what extent are the people in the AA programs in these states typical of alcoholics across the nation? Also, how do alcoholics in AA compare to alcoholics who have not sought help? Perhaps the most important sampling problem was the lack of a random sample. While the self-reported non-alcoholics were randomly selected in the three states, the respondents in AA were selected on a voluntary basis. Do those who volunteered to talk about their parents differ greatly from those who did not volunteer? If there is a difference between the volunteers and non-volunteers, then the sample is biased.

请注意，此处呈现的结果仅来自一项研究，并未说明这些结果的普遍性。我们也不知道这些信息发表在哪里，因此无法评估该研究在发表前是否经过严格审查。然而，我们可以就这项研究提出一些有价值的问题。样本量相当大，但其覆盖面值得商榷。尽管样本涵盖了多个州，但这些州的匿名戒酒互助会（AA）成员在多大程度上能代表全国的酗酒者？此外，AA中的酗酒者与未寻求帮助的酗酒者相比有何不同？或许最重要的抽样问题是缺乏随机抽样。虽然三个州的自述非酗酒者是随机抽取的，但AA中的受访者是自愿参与的。那些自愿谈论父母情况的人与那些没有自愿参与的人之间是否存在显著差异？如果自愿者和非自愿者之间存在差异，那么样本就存在偏差。

How accurate are the rating measurements? First, no definition for alcoholic for those answering the survey is given beyond currently being in AA. In addition, we are not told of any criteria given to the research participants for rating parents as alcoholic. Thus we are uncertain of the accuracy of the judgments about whether someone was an alcoholic. Also, problematic is the fact that the selection of the supposed control group of non-alcoholics is based on self-assessment. We know that there is a socially acceptable answer of not being an alcoholic, and people tend to give socially acceptable answers when they are known. This response tendency could also bias the sampling in the supposed control group. We would want to know more about the accuracy of these ratings before we could have much confidence in the conclusion.

这些评级测量结果的准确性如何？首先，除了目前参加匿名戒酒互助会（AA）之外，调查问卷并未对“酗酒者”给出明确的定义。此外，我们也不清楚研究参与者在评估父母是否酗酒时所依据的具体标准。因此，我们无法确定这些判断是否准确。另一个问题在于，所谓的非酗酒者对照组的选择是基于自我评估的。我们知道，对于“不酗酒”这一说法，存在一种社会认可的答案，而人们在被他人知晓的情况下往往会给出符合社会规范的答案。这种回答倾向也可能导致所谓对照组的抽样出现偏差。在得出更有把握的结论之前，我们需要了解更多关于这些评级准确性的信息。

Passage 2
第二段
CONCLUSION: Three strikes law for criminal offenses are desirable.
结论：对刑事犯罪实行“三振出局”法是可取的。
REASON: Allowing a criminal to offend three times is like allowing a batter in baseball to swing and miss three times.
理由：允许罪犯三次犯罪，就好比允许棒球击球手三次挥棒落空一样。

The author is arguing the desirability of the three strikes law by drawing an obvious analogy to baseball. The similarity the author is focusing on is that three chances for a batter to hit a ball is much like the three chances awarded to convicted offenders to shape up or to be put in jail for a long time. But simply saying three criminal offenses deserves harsh punishment ignores the complexity involved in criminal sentencing. For example, while a swing and a miss is a strike regardless of the type of pitch the pitcher throws, we might feel context is very important for sentencing criminals. What if the third offense is something very minor? Does it make sense to punish the criminal severely for a third offense regardless of what the other two were? Because of an important relevant difference, we conclude that this analogy is not very relevant.

作者通过棒球比赛来论证“三振出局”法的合理性。他着重强调的相似之处在于，击球手有三次击球机会，这与罪犯有三次改过自新的机会，否则将面临长期监禁。然而，仅仅说三次犯罪就应该受到严厉惩罚，忽略了刑事量刑的复杂性。例如，虽然挥棒落空无论投手投什么球都算作一次好球，但我们可能会认为，在量刑时，具体情况至关重要。如果第三次犯罪情节非常轻微呢？是否应该不考虑前两次犯罪的性质，就对第三次犯罪处以重罚？由于存在重要的相关差异，我们认为这种类比并不恰当。

CRITICAL QUESTION SUMMARY: WHY THIS QUESTION IS IMPORTANT

关键问题总结：为什么这个问题很重要

How Good Is the Evidence?

证据有多充分？

When an author offers a reason in support of a conclusion, you want to know why you should believe that reason. By identifying the evidence offered in support of a reason, you are taking another step in evaluating the worth of the reason. If the evidence that supports the reason is good, the reason better supports the conclusion. Thus, you might be more willing to accept the author's conclusion if the author offers good evidence in support of a reason, which in turn provides good support for the conclusion.

当作者提出理由支持其结论时，你会想知道为什么应该相信这个理由。通过识别支持该理由的证据，你就能更深入地评估该理由的价值。如果支持该理由的证据充分，那么该理由就能更好地支撑其结论。因此，如果作者提供了充分的证据来支持其理由，从而有力地支撑了结论，那么你可能更愿意接受作者的结论。

#↩

CHAPTER 10 ARE THERE RIVAL CAUSES?

第十章 是否存在相互竞争的事业？

We begin this chapter with a story.

本章以一个故事开始。

An inquisitive little boy noticed that the sun would show up in the sky in the morning and disappear at night. Puzzled by where the sun went, the boy tried to watch the sunset really closely. However, he still could not figure out where the sun was going. Then, the boy also noticed that his babysitter showed up in the mornings and left at night. One day he asked his babysitter where she went at night. The babysitter responded, "I go home." Linking his babysitter's arrival and departure with the coming of day and night, he concluded that his babysitter's leaving, caused the sun to also go home.
一个好奇的小男孩注意到，太阳早上会出现在天空中，晚上就会消失。他很困惑太阳去了哪里，于是仔细观察日落。然而，他仍然找不到太阳的踪迹。后来，小男孩又注意到他的保姆早上来，晚上走。有一天，他问保姆晚上去了哪里。保姆回答说：“我回家了。”小男孩把保姆的来去和昼夜的更迭联系起来，得出结论：保姆的离开，就是太阳回家的原因。

This story clearly illustrates a common difficulty in the use of evidence: trying to figure out what caused something to happen. We cannot determine an intelligent approach to avoiding a problem or encouraging a particular positive outcome until we understand the causal pattern that gave rise to the phenomenon in the first place. For example, we want to know what caused the steady rise in oil prices in the United States over the last few years. Or, why the suicide rate among professionals increased over the last 10 years?

这个故事清楚地揭示了证据运用中一个常见的难题：试图弄清某件事发生的原因。如果我们不首先理解导致该现象发生的因果模式，就无法找到避免问题或促成某种积极结果的有效方法。例如，我们想知道过去几年美国油价持续上涨的原因是什么？或者，为什么过去十年专业人士的自杀率上升了？

The story also shows a very common difficulty in using evidence to prove that something caused something else—the problem of rival causes . The fictional little boy offered one interpretation of his observations: the sun sets at night because my babysitter goes home. We expect that you can see another very plausible explanation for why the sun sets.

这个故事也揭示了用证据证明某件事导致另一件事时一个非常常见的难题——相互矛盾的原因。故事中的小男孩对他的观察给出了一种解释：太阳晚上落山是因为我的保姆回家了。我们相信你能想到太阳落山的另一种非常合理的解释。

Although rival causes will rarely be as obvious as they are in our story, you will frequently encounter experts presenting one hypothesis to explain events or research findings when other plausible hypotheses could also explain them. Usually, these experts will not reveal rival causes to you because they do not want to detract from the sound of certainty associated with their claims; you will have to produce them. Doing so can be especially helpful as you decide "how good is the evidence?" The existence of multiple, plausible rival causes for events reduces our confidence in the cause originally offered by the author.

尽管其他可能的解释很少像我们故事中那样显而易见，但你经常会遇到这样的情况：专家提出一种假设来解释事件或研究结果，而实际上还有其他合理的假设也能解释它们。通常，这些专家不会主动透露其他可能的解释，因为他们不想削弱自己论断的确定性；你需要自己去寻找这些解释。这样做在你判断“证据的可靠性”时尤为重要。多种合理的解释会降低我们对作者最初提出的解释的信心。

Searching for rival causes will always be appropriate when a speaker or writer presents you with some evidence and offers a cause to explain it.

当演讲者或作者提出一些证据并提出一个理由来解释它时，寻找其他可能的原因总是恰当的。

Critical Question : Are there rival causes?
关键问题：是否存在相互竞争的原因？
Attention : A rival cause is a plausible alternative explanation that can explain why a certain outcome occurred.
注意：竞争原因是指可以解释为什么会发生某种结果的合理替代解释。

When to Look for Rival Causes

何时寻找竞争对手

You need to look for rival causes when you have good reason to believe that the writer or speaker is using evidence to support a claim about the cause of something. The word cause means "to bring about, make happen, or affect." Communicators can indicate causal thinking to you in a number of ways. We have listed a few.

当你有充分理由相信作者或发言者正在使用证据来支持关于某事原因的论断时，你需要寻找其他可能的解释。原因一词的含义是“导致、促成或影响”。传播者可以通过多种方式向你表明其因果思维。我们列举了一些例子。

These clues to causal thinking should help you recognize when a communicator is making a causal claim. Once you note such a claim, be alert to the possibility of rival causes.

这些因果思维线索应该能帮助你识别沟通者何时提出因果主张。一旦你注意到此类主张，就要警惕是否存在其他可能的原因。

The Pervasiveness of Rival Causes

相互竞争原因的普遍性

On the afternoon of March 28, 1941, Virginia Woolf wrote two letters, sealed them, and placed them on the mantle. She quickly put on her coat, grabbed her walking stick, and headed outside. She crossed the meadows to the river Ouse, where she put large stones into her coat pocket and threw herself into the river, committing suicide.

1941年3月28日下午，弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫写了两封信，封好后放在壁炉架上。她迅速穿上外套，抓起拐杖，走到屋外。她穿过草地来到乌斯河边，把几块大石头放进口袋，然后纵身跃入河中，结束了自己的生命。

Authors have offered numerous hypotheses to explain this event, including the following:

作者们提出了许多假设来解释这一事件，其中包括以下几种：

  1. Virginia Woolf had a fear of impending madness. She had a history of mental illness and depression. Also, given the recent outbreak of World War II and her history of an inability to deal with aggression, Virginia decided it would be best if she took her own life.
    弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫一直害怕自己会陷入疯狂。她曾患有精神疾病和抑郁症。此外，鉴于第二次世界大战刚刚爆发，以及她以往无法应对暴力行为的状况，弗吉尼亚认为结束自己的生命是最好的选择。
  2. Some psychologists argue Virginia Woolf had an intense attachment with her father. The attachment was so strong that Virginia developed to be much like her father in many significant ways. One important event in Virginia's life, therefore, was watching her father's deteriorating health when Virginia was in her early twenties. She never forgot about her father's suffering and deterioration. So, when Virginia was 59 years old and feeling that her writing was beginning to deteriorate, she took her life in order to avoid identifying with, and in essence becoming, her dying father.
    一些心理学家认为，弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫与她的父亲有着强烈的依恋。这种依恋如此之深，以至于弗吉尼亚在许多重要方面都变得像她的父亲。因此，在她二十岁出头的时候，亲眼目睹父亲的健康状况每况愈下，成为她生命中一件意义重大的事。她从未忘记父亲的痛苦和病情恶化。所以，当弗吉尼亚59岁，感到自己的写作水平开始下滑时，她选择了结束自己的生命，以避免认同并最终变成她垂死的父亲。
  3. Virginia Woolf was disillusioned with her marriage to Leonard Woolf. The two had a sexless marriage, and Virginia found companionship in an extra-marital lesbian relationship. Virginia's homosexuality put tremendous strain on the marriage that was in turn only made worse by the fact that Leonard probably had several affairs. Virginia was a very jealous person and did not take lightly to these affairs. Her dissatisfaction with the condition of her marriage led her to take her life.
    弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫对她与伦纳德·伍尔夫的婚姻感到失望。两人婚姻毫无性生活，弗吉尼亚在婚外情中寻求慰藉。弗吉尼亚的同性恋倾向给婚姻带来了巨大的压力，而伦纳德可能还有其他婚外情，更是雪上加霜。弗吉尼亚生性嫉妒，对这些婚外情无法容忍。最终，她对婚姻的不满导致了她的自杀。

Woolf s own writing leads to any number of possible causes for her suicide.

伍尔夫自己的作品为她的自杀提供了许多可能的解释。

Now, let's leave Virginia Woolf's suicide for a moment and examine a different event in need of explanation—the findings of a research study.

现在，让我们暂时放下弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫的自杀事件，来考察另一件需要解释的事情——一项研究的发现。

A researcher reported that eating celery helps curb aggression. 151 women were surveyed, and 95 percent who reported eating celery on a regular basis also reported low levels of aggression, or overall irritability. Of the portion of women who do not eat celery on a regular basis, 53 percent reported frequent feelings of irritability, agitation, and aggression.

一项研究报告称，食用芹菜有助于抑制攻击性。该研究调查了151名女性，其中95%经常食用芹菜的女性表示，她们的攻击性或整体易怒程度较低。而在不经常食用芹菜的女性中，53%的人表示经常感到易怒、烦躁和具有攻击性。

In this study, the researcher probably began with the hypothesis that eating celery causes reduction of aggressive impulses, and he found evidence consistent with that hypothesis. But let us offer several rival, or different, causes for the same findings.

在这项研究中，研究者可能首先假设食用芹菜会降低攻击性冲动，并且他找到了与该假设相符的证据。但让我们提出几种可能与之竞争或不同的解释，来说明为何会出现相同的结果。

  1. Research participants were highly suggestible, and the expectation of low levels of aggression was responsible for the reported differences; like the sugar pill placebo effect in medicine, believing that eating celery lowers aggression might have stimulated a number of physical and mental processes that caused participants to feel less aggression.
    研究参与者非常容易受到暗示，对低水平攻击性的预期是造成报告差异的原因；就像医学中的糖丸安慰剂效应一样，相信吃芹菜可以降低攻击性可能会刺激许多生理和心理过程，使参与者感到攻击性降低。
  2. Participants wanted to please the researchers; thus, they reported feeling low levels of aggression, even though they did experience some aggressive feelings.
    参与者想要取悦研究人员；因此，即使他们确实体验到了一些攻击性情绪，他们也报告说自己感受到的攻击性水平很低。
  3. Nothing is known about the women involved in the study. It is entirely plausible that those who eat celery are health conscious, and thus are more likely to exercise. The increased amounts of exercise can be an outlet for aggression, and thus lower feelings of aggression. Those who do not eat celery regularly may not exercise as often and thus do not have an outlet for their aggression.
    我们对参与这项研究的女性一无所知。食用芹菜的女性很可能更注重健康，因此也更倾向于锻炼。增加运动量可以释放攻击性，从而降低攻击性。不经常食用芹菜的女性可能运动量较少，因此缺乏释放攻击性的途径。

Now, let's leave the research laboratory for a moment and move to the national pages of our newspapers and examine an argument related to crime statistics.

现在，让我们暂时离开研究实验室，转到报纸的国内版面，来看一下与犯罪统计数据相关的论点。

Since 1993, the levels of serious violent crime in the United States have decreased steadily. It is obvious that the heavy focus we place on law enforcement is no longer necessary. People are becoming civic minded and are choosing to no longer pursue a life of crime. Money spent on law enforcement can now better be spent elsewhere.

自1993年以来，美国的严重暴力犯罪率持续下降。显然，我们不再需要像过去那样过度依赖执法。人们的公民意识日益增强，不再选择犯罪道路。因此，原本用于执法的资金可以更好地用于其他方面。

The hypothesis offered by the writer is that people's increasing civic engagement is the cause of the decrease in violent crimes over the last 12 years. But, let's again generate some plausible rival causes:

作者提出的假设是，民众公民参与度的提高是过去12年暴力犯罪率下降的原因。但是，让我们再列举一些可能的其他原因：

  1. Violent crime rates have decreased because of the increased focus on law enforcement the writer is specifically calling to be cut. An increased concern with law enforcement, and not the civic concerns of citizens, caused violent crime levels to decrease.
    暴力犯罪率下降的原因是人们更加关注执法部门，而作者却呼吁削减这方面的预算。暴力犯罪率的下降并非源于对公民福祉的关注，而是源于对执法部门的日益重视。
  2. Recent legislative actions have increased the punishments associated with violent crimes. These increased punishments make the costs of committing a violent crime far outweigh the benefits of committing violent crimes. People are not more civic minded, rather they are looking out for their own personal interests.
    近期立法行动加大了对暴力犯罪的惩罚力度。这些加重的惩罚使得暴力犯罪的成本远远超过了其带来的收益。人们的公民意识并没有增强，而是更加关注自身利益。
  3. The booming economy in the 1990s could have decreased the number of people in poverty. Given that the poor are typically the perpetrators of what we call violent crimes, fewer poor people would lower the violent crime rate.
    上世纪90年代经济的蓬勃发展本可以减少贫困人口的数量。鉴于穷人通常是暴力犯罪的实施者，贫困人口的减少自然会降低暴力犯罪率。

Now, let's examine some important lessons that can be learned from Virginia Woolf s suicide, the celery research study, and the crime statistics.

现在，让我们来探讨一下我们可以从弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫的自杀、芹菜研究和犯罪统计数据中学到的一些重要教训。

Lessons Learned

经验教训

  1. Many kinds of events are open to explanation by rival causes.
    许多类型的事件都可以用多种相互矛盾的原因来解释。
  2. Experts can examine the same evidence and "discover" different causes to explain it.
    专家们可以检验相同的证据，并“发现”不同的原因来解释它。
  3. Most communicators will provide you with only their favored causes; the critical reader or listener must generate rival causes.
    大多数传播者只会向你提供他们所支持的理由；批判性的读者或听众必须提出与之相悖的理由。
  4. Generating rival causes is a creative process; usually such causes will not be obvious.
    产生竞争性诉求是一个创造性的过程；通常这类诉求并不明显。
  5. Finally, the certainty of a particular causal claim is inversely related to the number of plausible rival causes. Hence, identifying the multiple rival causes gives the critical thinker the proper sense of intellectual humility.
    最后，某一特定因果关系主张的确定性与可能存在的竞争原因的数量成反比。因此，识别出多个竞争原因能够使批判性思考者培养恰当的理性谦逊。

In the following sections, we explore the implications of these lessons for the critical thinker.

在接下来的章节中，我们将探讨这些经验教训对批判性思考者的意义。

Detecting Rival Causes

检测竞争对手的原因

Locating rival causes is much like being a good detective. When you recognize situations in which rival causes are possible, you want to ask yourself questions like:

找出可能的竞争原因就像当一名优秀的侦探。当你意识到可能存在竞争原因时，你需要问自己一些问题，例如：

? Can I think of any other way to interpret the evidence?
我还能想到其他解释这些证据的方法吗？
? What else might have caused this act or these findings?
还有什么其他原因可能导致这一行为或这些发现？
? If I looked at this from another point of view, what might I see as important causes?
如果我换个角度来看，我认为哪些因素会是重要的原因呢？
? If this interpretation is incorrect, what other interpretation might make sense?
如果这种解释是错误的，那么还有哪些解释可能更合理？

The Cause or A Cause

原因或原因

The youth are exhibiting an alarming increase in the rate of depression among elementary aged children. Talk show hosts begin to interview the experts about the cause. It is genetic. It is the prevalence of teasing among peer groups. It is parental neglect. It is too much TV news coverage of terrorism and wars. It is lack of religion. It is stress. The experts may claim to have the answer, but they are not likely to know it. That is because a frequently made error is to look for a simple, single cause of an event when it is really the result of a combination of many contributory causes— a cause that helps to create a total set of conditions necessary for the event to occur.

青少年抑郁症的发病率在小学生群体中呈现令人担忧的增长趋势。脱口秀主持人开始采访专家，探讨其原因。有人说是遗传因素，有人说是同龄群体中普遍存在的嘲笑，有人说是父母疏于照顾，有人说是电视新闻中充斥着恐怖主义和战争报道，有人说是缺乏宗教信仰，还有人说是压力过大。专家们或许声称找到了答案，但他们很可能并不真正了解。这是因为人们常常犯的错误是，试图寻找某个事件的单一原因，而实际上，事件是由多种因素共同作用的结果——这些因素共同促成了事件发生的必要条件。

Multiple contributory causes occur more often than do single causes in situations involving the characteristics or activities of humans. In many cases, the best causal explanation is one that combines a considerable number of causes that only together are sufficient to bring about the event. So, the best answer experts can give to the talk show hosts' question is "We don't know the cause for such events, but we can speculate about possible causes that might have contributed to the event." Thus, when we are searching for rival causes, we need to remember that any single cause that we identify is much more likely to be a contributory cause than the cause.

在涉及人类特征或活动的各种情况下，多种因素共同作用的情况比单一因素更为常见。很多时候，最佳的因果解释是将相当多的因素结合起来，这些因素只有共同作用才足以导致事件发生。因此，专家们对脱口秀主持人提出的问题能给出的最佳答案是：“我们不知道这类事件的根本原因，但我们可以推测一些可能促成事件发生的原因。”由此可见，当我们寻找可能的共同原因时，我们需要记住，我们所识别出的任何单一原因，更有可能是促成因素而非根本原因。

When communicators fail to consider the complexity of causes, they commit the following reasoning fallacy:

当传播者未能考虑到原因的复杂性时，他们就犯了以下推理谬误：

F: Causal Oversimplification : Explaining an event by relying on causal factors that are insufficient to account for the event or by overemphasizing the role of one or more of these factors.

F：因果过度简化：用不足以解释事件的因果因素来解释事件，或者过分强调一个或多个因果因素的作用。

In some sense, almost all causal explanations are oversimplifications; thus you want to be fair to communicators who offer explanations that do not include every possible cause of an event. Causal conclusions, however, should include sufficient causal factors to convince you that they are not too greatly oversimplified, or the author should make clear to you that the causal factor she emphasizes in her conclusion is only one of a number of possible contributing causes— a cause, not the cause.

从某种意义上说，几乎所有的因果解释都属于过度简化；因此，我们应该公平对待那些解释并未涵盖事件所有可能原因的传播者。然而，因果结论应该包含足够的因果因素，以使读者相信其并非过于简化，或者作者应该明确指出，她在结论中强调的因果因素只是众多可能原因之一——只是其中一个原因，而非唯一原因。

Rival Causes and Scientific Research

竞争原因和科学研究

Scientific research attempts to isolate some of the most important contributing causes from other extraneous causes and provides a major source of hypotheses about what causes events in our world. Researchers start with tentative beliefs— hypotheses—about causes of events. For example, when a massive wave killed thousands of people, researchers generated many hypotheses about the cause of tsunamis.One hypothesis was that tsunamis are caused by massive underwater earthquakes.

科学研究试图从其他无关因素中分离出一些最重要的致因，并为我们理解世界事件的成因提供了重要的假设来源。研究人员从对事件成因的初步信念——假设——开始着手研究。例如，当一场巨浪夺去数千人的生命时，研究人员提出了许多关于海啸成因的假设。其中一个假设是，海啸是由强烈的海底地震引起的。

Once a hypothesis has been firmly established by dependable research evidence, it changes from a hypothesis to a law. In the domain of complex human behavior, however, there are very few established general laws. Stated claims like "fundamentalism causes terrorism," and "tax cuts cause economic growth" sound like laws, but we need to remain skeptical of the generalizability of such claims. They must currently be viewed as hypotheses, not laws, and are best stated as follows: "fundamentalism may be a contributing cause in the decision to resort to terrorism," and "tax cuts may be a contributing cause in stimulating economic growth."

一旦某个假设被可靠的研究证据确凿地证实，它就从假设变成了定律。然而，在复杂的人类行为领域，已确立的普遍规律却寥寥无几。诸如“原教旨主义导致恐怖主义”和“减税促进经济增长”之类的说法听起来像是定律，但我们必须对这些说法的普遍适用性保持怀疑。它们目前只能被视为假设，而非定律，最好表述为：“原教旨主义可能是导致诉诸恐怖主义的原因之一”，以及“减税可能是刺激经济增长的原因之一”。

Then, what should you do when speakers or writers use findings from research studies to conclude that one event causes another? First, remember that their conclusion should be viewed as a cause, not the cause. Then try to find out as much as you can about the research procedures used to produce the findings that support the hypothesis. Finally, try to determine rival causes that might explain the findings. The more plausible rival causes that can account for the findings, the less faith you should have in the hypothesis favored by the communicator.

那么，当演讲者或作者引用研究结果得出“一个事件导致另一个事件”的结论时，我们应该怎么做呢？首先，要记住他们的结论应该被视为原因之一，而不是唯一的原因。其次，尽可能多地了解用于得出支持该假设的研究结果的研究方法。最后，尝试找出可能解释这些结果的其他原因。能够解释这些结果的合理原因越多，你就越应该对传播者所支持的假设持怀疑态度。

Let's use the following argument to practice detecting rival causes.

让我们用以下论证来练习识别相互竞争的原因。

Playing violent video games for long periods of time appears to increase the likelihood that a child will physically assault another child. The results confirm the general suspicion that violent video games cause violence in children. The relevant research findings are from the Center for Preventing Youth Violence, which enrolled 1,001 male children from across the United States. One-third of the children played "violent" video games, one-third played "non-violent" video games, and the remaining third did not play any video games. The children played several hours of video games alone every day for two weeks. At the end of the two weeks, the children from the different groups were put into a room with toys so that they could play together. Those children who played violent video games were more likely to get into physical altercations with other children than were those who played "non-violent" video games, or no video games at all.
长时间玩暴力电子游戏似乎会增加儿童对其他儿童实施肢体攻击的可能性。研究结果证实了人们普遍的怀疑，即暴力电子游戏会导致儿童暴力行为。相关研究结果来自预防青少年暴力中心，该中心招募了来自美国各地的1001名男童。其中三分之一的儿童玩“暴力”电子游戏，三分之一玩“非暴力”电子游戏，其余三分之一则不玩任何电子游戏。这些儿童每天独自玩几个小时的电子游戏，持续两周。两周后，研究人员将不同组的儿童安排在一个摆放着玩具的房间里，让他们一起玩耍。结果发现，玩暴力电子游戏的儿童比玩“非暴力”电子游戏或完全不玩电子游戏的儿童更容易与其他儿童发生肢体冲突。

Should parents take away all of their children's "violent" video games? Not until they consider rival causes! How else might one explain these group differences?

家长应该没收孩子所有“暴力”电子游戏吗？在考虑其他可能的原因之前，不应该这样做！否则，又该如何解释这些群体间的差异呢？

First, let's outline the reasoning:

首先，让我们概述一下理由：

CONCLUSION: (Researchers' hypothesis) Playing violent video games appears to cause an increase in violence among children.
结论：（研究者假设）玩暴力电子游戏似乎会导致儿童暴力行为增加。
REASON: (Researchers' evidence) Research study showed children who played violent video games were more likely to get into physical altercations with other children than were those children who did not play violent video games .
原因：（研究人员的证据）研究表明，玩暴力电子游戏的儿童比不玩暴力电子游戏的儿童更容易与其他儿童发生肢体冲突。

Note that the words appears to cause in the conclusion tell us the researchers are making a causal claim about the evidence. But other hypotheses can explain this evidence.

请注意，结论中“似乎导致”一词表明研究人员对证据提出了因果关系的主张。但其他假设也可以解释这些证据。

The report fails to tell us how the children were selected into the three different groups. It is possible that the children were allowed to self-select what games they play, and perhaps children who are more likely to be violent tend to choose "violent" video games. If so, it is possible the researcher has the causal link reversed. Also, nothing is revealed as to how the "play" situation was set up for the children. Perhaps the room or selection of toys was set up in such a way to encourage physical altercations among those who played the "violent" video games. We bet you can think of other reasons these groups— violent video game players and not—differ in their likelihood of resorting to physical violence.

报告并未说明儿童是如何被分入三个不同组的。有可能儿童可以自行选择玩的游戏，而那些更容易出现暴力倾向的儿童或许更倾向于选择“暴力”电子游戏。如果是这样，研究人员可能弄反了因果关系。此外，报告也没有说明儿童的“游戏”环境是如何设置的。或许房间或玩具的摆放方式是为了鼓励玩“暴力”电子游戏的儿童发生肢体冲突。我们相信您一定能想到其他原因，导致这些群体——无论是否玩暴力电子游戏——在诉诸暴力的可能性上存在差异。

We cannot make you aware of all possible rival causes. In the following selections, however, we provide several clues for finding common rival causes.

我们无法让您了解所有可能的竞争原因。但是，在以下内容中，我们将提供一些线索，帮助您找到常见的竞争原因。

Rival Causes for Differences Between Groups

群体间差异的相互竞争原因
